story:
Who We Are

We are a group of four students from the University of Tennessee, Knoxville that are working together to support a local cause. Our team includes Alec North, Briana Sproles, Cannon West, and Rebecca Pirkle. We have decided to support East Tennessee Children's Hospital (ETCH) because, as Knoxville residents, the hospital is close to home and has deep roots in our community. Their dedication to seeing children reach optimal health is evident, and because of that, we are striving to help ETCH reach their goals. 

Since 1937, ETCH has been a leader in children's health in East Tennessee-providing excellent, comprehensive family-centered care, education and wellness. It is a private, independent non-profit organization that does not discriminate based on race, religion, or the parent's ability to pay for their child's medical bill. ETCH shows their love for the well-being of children by putting together countless events, including summer camps, that cost little to nothing at all for their patients who want to attend. 

Every year, ETCH organizes a camp called the Donald M. Gally summer camp for children with special needs. It is held at the Kiwanis Fresh Air Camp in Knoxville for two weeks each July.  Children ages 5 through 15 years have a wide range of complex special needs and serious physical, emotional, and learning limitations. Because so much is involved with the operation of the camp and the camp costs very little for each child who attends, much of the funding for the camp comes from donations and fundraising to remain functioning every year. 



What We Need 

The Donald M. Gally summer camp is fully funded by donations. Along with Rehab Center physical therapists and registered nurses, camp staff includes an adaptive physical education teacher, three activity assistants and volunteers to work with 25 children each week. The cost is $390 per child. We are trying to raise a total of $1600 in order to pay for 4 children to attend camp this summer free of cost. A large portion of the camp's funding comes in one of the most generous and sincere forms-donations. 

What You Get 

We greatly appreciate donations of any amount and offer a variety of perks for contributions of $10 or more. For each donation of $10, $25, $100, or the full sponsorship of a child at $390, on behalf on ETCH and our group of thankful students, you can claim an e-mail from our team thanking you for your participation, personal shout outs on social media, free food from Chick-fil-A, or a personal "Thank you" letter from our team respectively.



Who It Helps

Donations to ETCH will not only help further the progress of the hospital's vision for their patients, but will aid in helping the children that the hospital supports. With about 142,000 children taken care of every year, further outside funding to help with extra opportunities such as the Donald M. Gally summer camp is always a present issue. Each of the donations received will go toward sending 4 children to the Donald M. Gally summer camp with all expenses paid.

For many of the special needs patients that attend the camp, it may be the only camping activity like this that they attend this year. While the children are at camp Gally, they have the opportunity to be involved in a number of activities including: swimming, a carnival, zoo animals, games, arts and crafts, singing, and nature walks. The kids are encouraged to engage in each of these activities, which are facilitated by staff therapists, special education teachers and adaptive recreation specialists.

ETCH already does so much for the children in the Knoxville community, so these donations are designed to help them do what they do best-care for the medical needs and well-being of local children. Every donation that supports ETCH and the children they serve is a donation well appreciated.

How Else You Can Help 

If you would like to contribute to our campaign but cannot currently donate, there are other ways that you can to help.

Spread the word about this campaign and our goals to your friends and family by liking and sharing our Facebook page. On the ETCH website, www.etch.com, there is a list of needed items you are able to donate, as well as many volunteer opportunities available. We greatly appreciate any and all contributions to Camp Gally and East Tennessee Children’s Hospital.

story:
Don't let our homeless go hungry!

Malmö can be a tough place to be homeless. It's cold, it's windy, and most people don't even carry cash around, which makes begging super difficult.

That's why Buddha Mag has decided that the beautiful people of Malmö can help spread some love and warmth in our city, by donating a falafel rulle (the most popular food in town) to the homeless. 

1 falafel, 2 times a week.

So here's the deal, when you help fund this project, we will buy 50 falafel wraps at 25 krs (USD2.80) each and deliver them to our homeless friends around the city, twice a week. Areas covered include: Central Station, Gågatan, Triangeln, Möllan, Södervärn, Värnhem, and Fristad. We'd keep going weekly until the money runs out, and then repeat (if you're nice)!

All purchase receipts and photo updates of our work will be posted on our campaign site on Buddhamag.org

So buy less shit, and give someone a meal.
Let's Feed Malmö!

story:
PROJECT: REOPENING OF THE LIBERTY BELL TEMPLE in TRENTON, NJ

Goal to transfer the California Incorporated Temple to Jersey

Watch this below video after the autoplay video ends further below please

All the battles I’ve fought have lead to this. In the past I’ve had visions and goals that have come to fruition—“Weedstradamus.”

My decades-long fight to legalize marijuana in my home state of New Jersey is now within reach. My vision for 2015 is to successfully reopen the Liberty Bell Temple (III), and I need your help. I believe timing, karma, and righteousness have guided me to this critical point. I need all the green angels out there to join this religious reefer revolution—if you believe in what I stand for (peace, individualism, and freedom), now is the time to support my most ambitious project to date—transposing a West Coast utopia onto the front lines of New Jersey's politics of pot, something we can all be a part of.

BACKGROUND: In 2005 I  became a founding member of the United Cannabis Ministries, a national organization of cannabis churches. In September of 2008 I opened the Liberty Bell Temple II Inc., in Los Angeles (HOLLYWOOD) as the city's only independent and incorporated Rastafarian Temple. The LBT promoted music, solace, and spirituality and provided the sacrament of Ganja to its congregants. In the sea of 980 medical marijuana dispensaries in Los Angeles at the time, the LBT was one of only two RELIGIOUSLY THEMED entities operating in HOLLYWOOD, the other being Craig X's Temple 420. A destination for locals, tourists, and internet-inspired travelers, the LBT quickly became a Hollywood Boulevard social Mecca catering to socially conscience Cannabis Consumers as well as celebrities. It was a positive for the community. 

At one point, July 2010, the City of Los Angeles attempted to close the TEMPLE based on the city's medical marijuana laws. The TEMPLE hired David Welch of the D|R Welch Attorneys at Law P.C.  and sought an injunction in California Superior Court:"During the raid on Liberty Bell Temple II on July 14, 2010, and per our court complaint, the police allegedly made threatening remarks in an attempt to chill the practice of Rastafari by the members of Liberty Bell Temple II," cites Welch. "These acts are a clear violation of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act and the California Constitution. We will seek an injunction by the courts to prevent further police activity against the members of Liberty Bell Temple II and their practice and congregation in their Rastafarian faith." (Details: http://tinyurl.com/PR-LBT2) 

Legally the LBT2inc., sought to be treated just like the 980 secular medical marijuana dispensaries. On December 10, 2010, Judge Moher issued an injunction (http://tinyurl.com/Judge-Mohr) allowing medical marijuana dispensaries to operate in Los Angeles and on 1-4-11 he issued a order of “enjoiner” for The Liberty Bell Temple allowing the TEMPLE's legal operation as a Religious Cannabis Church. (http://tinyurl.com/LBT2-enjoiner). This was the first successful court-approved cannabis church ever.

DISASTER STRIKES: On December 13, 2011, (http://tinyurl.com/LADEA-RAID) DEA agents raided the Liberty Bell Temple II plus the TEMPLE's Lounge and grow facilities as well as my home. They seized everything and rendered the TEMPLE insolvent. On February 6th the TEMPLE Closed. (https://youtu.be/6kGUJl1hBcs)


NEW VISION: To transfer the Religious Incorporation from California, to New Jersey asap. After all my years of fighting the good fight, challenging laws and establishing precedents, and in light of the current state of the marijuana laws, I believe the time is right to reopen: In Trenton, NJ. It's high time for a rebirth.

WHO WOULD COME: Thousands would become members, dozens would attend daily. Instead of going to traditional churches, bars, bowling alleys, and other uncomfortable places to socialize with Cannabis Consumers, I would like you to flock to TRENTON to be the congregation of the new LIBERTY BELL TEMPLE.

CURRENT SITUATION:

#1 Choice - A suitable building has been found—but I have no cash to acquire it.      ( SEE VIDEO ABOVE) A storefront location in a neighborhood could suffice, but right now there is a real building with great attributes that's ideal for this THC-inspired vision—for sale. While I believe I could make a Temple out of almost any location, this building could truly be the perfect permanent headquarters of New Jersey's Cannabis-Consuming Community, POLITICAL Headquarters of "unfunded" GrassRoots Activist.  I’d like to ask my supporters and the Cannabis-Consuming Citizens of America to help me achieve this vision, which we would all reap the rewards of—to help me reopen the LIBERTY BELL TEMPLE in TRENTON, NJ, to all comers through the acquisition of this building. I think i put me dues in.

Situated in South Trenton in a commercial/residential zone, the two-story building is adjacent a existing Christian churches and a major bank, It's 1,200 square feet of space per floor plus an enclosed backyard. The first floor is currently set up as a nightclub with a bar and booths and a pool table, and the building comes with an existing liquor license, which would be a bonus to have for fund-raising purposes, social events, and private gatherings. Total price: $249,000 to purchase the entire building. The landlord is willing to hold the mortgage and transfer the city liquor license for one-third down ($70,000), followed by monthly payments of $2,000. Like other religious institutions, this TEMPLE would generate a substantial monthly income through membership fees, donations, and special events.

#2 Choice - I've also located a storefront at 322 East State Street, This location has a commercial kitchen in it. This kitchen would generate a income for myself as well as money to operate the temple (SANCTUARY ROOM), and to fund cannabis legalization projects #legalizenj here in New Jersey.   If this is the start of a great Temple in a storefront - so be it. It will out grow its walls, so fast I will laugh at those who didn't support plan #1 because there will be other #1 buildings.

I BELIEVE I COULD BE THE FACE OF THIS TEMPLE AGAIN


There's been a lot of news about Cannabis Churches,
I want to be the Corporate director of The Liberty Bell Temple III, and I want YOU to become a member. ( We will give every member of our congregation a laminated membership card. )

I want to run the daily operations of this TEMPLE as the director, but it would be staffed by green collar activists, and religious persons - it would become the headquarters of the local unfunded marijuana-legalization organizations and social-awareness causes. I want to openly operate this TEMPLE where congregants can partake of their sacrament in peace and in good company. It would be an immoveable object, a static headquarters for the NJ marijuana-legalization movement and for stoners of all stripes - under our spiritual house.

The LBT3 would once again be a Mecca for potheads, intellectuals, spiritual herbalists—from everyday folks who love herb and one another to green-collar activists who are putting their hearts and souls into amending the unnecessary and unfair marijuana laws (in New Jersey and beyond) to the suit-and-tie types (if they feel like coming through). Special events would include chess nights, Karaoke days, fish fry's, political bull sessions, and religious-reasoning sessions. The sky's the limit on what we can do. "LETS GET HIGH"

I’ve made appeals to the community before, and they have come through, but this is the biggest endeavor I’ve ever asked the Cannabis Community to undertake. I've always believed the religious component of legalization is important, and I have always championed this aspect of the multifaceted argument in favor of legalization. The religious concept is sound, the legal protection is ingrained in the First Amendment and ensured by the Religious Restoration Act. The TEMPLE can work. In fact, it has:

Precedent:

JAH RASTAFARI CENTER: Browns Mills, NJ (1998 –2007)

Liberty Bell Temple II, Los Angeles, CA (9/2008–2/2012)

I loved what I did in Los Angeles, but the government's actions have lead me back to my home turf of New Jersey, and the NJ battle for legalization that I could never truly abandon. My efforts weren’t a cakewalk in California—my KARMA says I was meant to come back to NJ where the frontline battle is. California is where I honed my skills. Now I'm home—New Jersey is my Home. It's where my heart is. I’m a Jersey guy. In a spiritual way I feel guided to be here now, I feel this in my heart, I’m ready to do this here and now.

This TEMPLE is for all of us. If you support what I’ve been saying for all these years and believe in what I’m doing, please contribute.

This TEMPLE is something that we can all celebrate as we make strides to free ourselves from the yoke of cannabis prohibition.

        ___________________________________________________________________


CURRENT LEGAL NJ ARGUMENTS FOR NJ COURT OF APPEALS:

I HAVE CHALLENGED THE STATE OF NEW JERSEY'S CRIMINAL MARIJUANA LAWS, - ONE STRONG ARGUMENT INCLUDED IN THIS HISTORIC APPEAL IS - THE STATE FAILED TO PROVIDE A RELIGIOUS EXEMPTION TO ITS CRIMINAL LAWS, AS IT HAS DONE FOR A SECULAR (medical) PURPOSE (currently there is no religious cannabis case in New Jersey since 2010 medical laws).

On MAY 4th, 2015 - Oral Arguments scheduled for 9:30am :

Hughes Justice Complex,

NJ Court of Appeals, (Part B)

25 Markets Street,

Trenton , NJ

STATE OF NEW JERSEY vs FORCHION, A-004052, A-004477-12,



LISTEN TO THIS CLICK IMAGE

story:
Kurzbeschreibung

Unsere beiden kurdischen Freunde Hawar und Khelan sind aus dem Irak nach Deutschland geflohen. Seit August leben sie in einem Camp in Hamburg, wo sie zurzeit in unbeheizten Zelten untergebracht sind.

Khelan erwartet ein Baby; ihr Mann ist in Norwegen und wartet auf die Möglichkeit, nach Deutschland zu kommen. Hawar ist Khelans Cousin und begleitet sie so lange, bis Khelans Ehemann bei ihr sein kann. Da die Umstände im Camp mit ungefähr 800 Menschen gerade für Schwangere unzumutbar sind, haben wir die Erlaubnis der Behörden erhalten, die beiden privat unterzubringen.

Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst

Glücklicherweise haben wir eine günstige Wohnung für die beiden gefunden (Warmmiete 340 € mtl.), die wir für 8 Monate zur Untermiete anmieten können - so lange, bis die Hauptmieterin von ihrem Auslandsaufenthalt zurückkehrt.

Bis das Asylverfahren abgeschlossen ist, zahlt der Staat noch nicht für die beiden. Mit eurer Hilfe möchten wir Hawar und Khelan schon jetzt ermöglichen, in einer normalen Wohnung zu leben, anstatt im Zelt überwintern zu müssen. Wir hoffen, dass sie so nach den Strapazen der Flucht etwas Ruhe und Erholung zu finden.

Sollte das Asylverfahren vor Ablauf der 8 Monate abgeschlossen sein, werden wir die Wohnung anderen befreundeten Flüchtlingen zur Verfügung stellen und Hawar und Khelan in einer staatlich finanzierten Wohnung unterbringen.

Auch wenn wir unser Kampagnenziel von 2720,- € nicht erreichen sollten, wird selbstverständlich der gesamte erreichte Betrag in die Finanzierung der Wohnung fließen.

Die Folgen

Hawar und Khelan wird der Start in Deutschland mit eurer Hilfe sehr viel besser gelingen können. Ihr sorgt dafür, dass sie Ruhe finden können und sich besser in ihrem neuen Umfeld zurechtfinden werden.
Trotz allem wird es sicher nicht leicht für sie werden, hier ein neues Leben zu beginnen. Mit ihren handwerklichen Berufen (Khelan ist Schneiderin, Friseurin und Schmuckdesignerin, Hawar ist Maler) und dem Engagement, mit dem die beiden schon jetzt etwas Deutsch gelernt haben, haben sie aber gute Anknüpfungspunkte. Wir werden sie dabei unterstützen und begleiten, haben aber selbst nicht ausreichend finanzielle Mittel, um dies auch materiell zu gewährleisten.

Wie ihr helfen könnt

Natürlich brauchen wir also eure finanzielle Unterstützung :) Aber auch die Verbreitung unserer Kampagne ist eine große Hilfe. Auch wenn ihr selbst vielleicht gerade kein Geld geben könnt: Gebt unseren Aufruf bitte an eure Freunde weiter. Es ist wichtig, dass unsere Kampagne weitergetragen wird. Denn wenn wir persönlich und im Kleinen helfen, können wir gemeinsam etwas Großes bewirken.

Vielen herzlichen Dank!!
story_txt:
Kurzbeschreibung
Unsere beiden kurdischen Freunde Hawar und Khelan sind aus dem Irak nach Deutschland geflohen. Seit August leben sie in einem Camp in Hamburg, wo sie zurzeit in unbeheizten Zelten untergebracht sind. 
Khelan erwartet ein Baby; ihr Mann ist in Norwegen und wartet auf die Möglichkeit, nach Deutschland zu kommen. Hawar ist Khelans Cousin und begleitet sie so lange, bis Khelans Ehemann bei ihr sein kann. Da die Umstände im Camp mit ungefähr 800 Menschen gerade für Schwangere unzumutbar sind, haben wir die Erlaubnis der Behörden erhalten, die beiden privat unterzubringen. 
  Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst 
Glücklicherweise haben wir eine günstige Wohnung für die beiden 
gefunden (Warmmiete 340 € mtl.), die wir für 8 Monate zur Untermiete 
anmieten können - so lange, bis die Hauptmieterin von ihrem 
Auslandsaufenthalt zurückkehrt.
Bis das Asylverfahren 
abgeschlossen ist, zahlt der Staat noch nicht für die beiden. Mit eurer 
Hilfe möchten wir Hawar und Khelan schon jetzt ermöglichen, in einer normalen 
Wohnung zu leben, anstatt im Zelt überwintern zu müssen. Wir hoffen, dass sie so nach den Strapazen der Flucht etwas Ruhe und 
Erholung zu finden. 
Sollte das Asylverfahren vor Ablauf der 8
 Monate abgeschlossen sein, werden wir die Wohnung anderen befreundeten Flüchtlingen 
zur Verfügung stellen und Hawar und Khelan in einer staatlich finanzierten 
Wohnung unterbringen.Auch wenn wir unser Kampagnenziel von 2720,- € nicht erreichen sollten, wird selbstverständlich der gesamte erreichte Betrag in die Finanzierung der Wohnung fließen.    Die FolgenHawar und Khelan wird der Start in Deutschland mit eurer Hilfe sehr viel besser gelingen können. Ihr sorgt dafür, dass sie Ruhe finden können und sich besser in ihrem neuen Umfeld zurechtfinden werden.    Trotz allem wird es sicher nicht leicht für sie werden, hier ein neues Leben zu beginnen. Mit ihren handwerklichen Berufen (Khelan ist Schneiderin, Friseurin und Schmuckdesignerin, Hawar ist Maler) und dem Engagement, mit dem die beiden schon jetzt etwas Deutsch gelernt haben, haben sie aber gute Anknüpfungspunkte. Wir werden sie dabei unterstützen und begleiten, haben aber selbst nicht ausreichend finanzielle Mittel, um dies auch materiell zu gewährleisten.    Wie ihr helfen könnt
Natürlich brauchen wir also eure finanzielle Unterstützung :) Aber auch die Verbreitung unserer Kampagne ist eine große Hilfe. Auch wenn ihr selbst vielleicht gerade kein Geld geben könnt: Gebt unseren Aufruf bitte an eure Freunde weiter. Es ist wichtig, dass unsere Kampagne weitergetragen wird. Denn wenn wir persönlich und im Kleinen helfen, können wir gemeinsam etwas Großes bewirken.
Vielen herzlichen Dank!!

story:
Who we are

We are a national network of student groups working to improve the lives of refugees in Greece, volunteering for local refugee projects, and campaigning for refugees. 


Course of action:

Protect the rights of refugees

- Inform refugees about their rights and their obligations.

- Systematic dialogue with all governmental authorities and human rights organizations aiming to the protection and aid of refugees and asylum seekers.

- Pressure Greek authorities to guarantee a properly working and fair asylum system.

- Provide the refugees with blankets, food, drinks, tents and medical facilities



United Nations’ refugee agency says that more than 2,500 people have lost their lives while crossing the Mediterranean this year (Picture: Reuters)


How you can help

- Donate
- Sent us clothes, toys, shoes, tents, ...
- Share our campaign


We can do this together!

All the money will be used for buying food, medical supplies, tents, ....
We keep you informed by mail of all our actions.


Our Facebook group, with already more then 1000 users:

Help Greece Migrants

story:
Short Summary

In 2002, when I was invited to Japan to peace at a peace conference, I met a survivor of World War II, Mrs. Iga, who told me she used to go to a peace lantern ceremony every August, but now her health doesn't always allow her to. I told her I'd attend one on her behalf each year, and the Bay Area Peace Lantern Ceremony was born.

For the 14th year, people of all ages will gather on Aug. 8, 2015 to remember the victims of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombings and all victims of war, and to decorate lantern shades expressing our visions for a peaceful future. The event has become a local institution, and is even written up in travel guidebooks.

This year, however, it has taken off like never before, with 10,000 people saying they plan to attend! The organizers of this event are a small band of volunteers, with no large organization behind us. We are scrambling to accommodate all the fresh interest in our peace-building event.

We need your support to provide resources for a fulfilling and safe experience for thousands of people. A good first experience for these people (many of whom are young, new peace activists) will help inspire participants to keep working toward a more peaceful future. — Steve Freedkin, founder, Peace Lantern Ceremony

What We Need & What You Get

In the next several days we must reserve and pay for:

  • A larger sound system so participants can hear the program and important announcements
  • Signs to direct the crowds
  • Dozens more tables and chairs, along with supplies for making and decorating lantern shades
  • Portable restrooms, lighting, and other safety/comfort accommodations
  • Numerous other materials and supplies

Some of our volunteers are lending money out of their own pockets to get us started, but we can't afford to cover all the increased costs of hosting so many people on such short notice. (The RSVP's started flooding in just a couple of weeks ago.

Your contribution will help make all this possible. In addition:

  • Donations of $125 and up entitle you to be a sponsor of one of the lantern-decorating tables. We'll purchase a table and prominently display that it was made possible by you.
  • Donations of $50 and up entitle you to be listed on our Web site as a sponsor of the event (yourself or your business/organization).
  • For a donation of $30 and up, we can send you a beautiful Peace Lantern Ceremony tee-shirt.
  • For a donation of $20 and up we can send you a package of four lovely Peace Lantern Ceremony notecards.

Long-term

If we are able to meet the challenge and — with your help — make this year's event a success, the groundwork will be laid for a much larger annual event that is designed to funnel thousands of new activists into projects to help eliminate nuclear weapons once and for all and build a more peaceful future.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to financial contributions, we also need volunteers — before, during, and after the event — and donations or loans of supplies (tables, chairs, sound system, lighting, art supplies, etc.). For more information on these needs, please see our volunteer form at: http://peacelanterns.org/volunteer.html

  • Please invite friends to join in supporting this emergency appeal.
  • Use Indiegogo's sharing tools to spread the word!

story:
“The Spirit of the Lord is upon Me,Because He has anointed Me to preach the gospel to the poor; He has sent Me to heal the brokenhearted, To proclaim liberty to the captives and recovery of sight to the blind, To set at liberty those who are oppressed;”  (Luke 14:18)


Almost 30 million people are living as slaves worldwide .. but there is hope.


Patricia King


Today , in the 21st Century, we are faced with modern day slavery and the largest category of slavery is sex slavery; the sexual exploitation of children and women. In 2009, according to UNICEF, there were about 1.8 million children exploited for the sex trade. It is a billion dollar industry for organized crime.


For my wife and I, God had put on our hearts to serve and seek the lost. The very vulnerable, the outcast of society but they are God's beloved, the children and women exploited in sex slavery. For 5 years now, the Lord made it clear to us through much prayers, scriptures, dreams and visions, that He had called us to reach out to the broken hearted.

One of these countries is Cambodia where XP missions are in need of financial support to continue their fight against human trafficking. 

Some ministries and services that are run by XP missions include:


  • Ministry in slum and garbage dump communities
  • Ministry to women working in the sex industry
  • Ministry to children rescued from sex slavery
  • Street Evangelism 
  • Prayer and intercession for the city, nation, and social justice issues
  • Partnering activities with other local ministries and christian missionaries.
  • Teenage girls' and boys ministry
  • Ministry to street kids
Please see below a short 4 minute clip about one woman's horror story of human trafficking :


We are looking to raise $10,000  for XP missions to support them in their work and ministry against sex slavery. 


Ways to help:


1. MAKE A MONETARY CONTRIBUTION TO OUR INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN:

You may make a contribution of any amount you like. There is no amount that is too small.  Every dollar helps!

2. LIKE & SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN ON FACEBOOK:

Many of the donations and funds will come from complete strangers who heard about this campaign via Facebook. Please Like and Share so we can spread the word. !! 

This is a private campaign, hence it is not tax deductible
Thank you in advance for your support and your generosity. 

Amir

story:
Heroes Don’t Always Wear Capes:

Honoring Dads Around the World this Father’s Day

Hero is a Greek word used to describe a person or character who faces danger, combating adversity through impressive feats of ingenuity, bravery or strength—often sacrificing their own personal concerns for a greater good. Most often the word is attributed to fictional characters of epic proportions. But if you think about it, heroes are all around us, quietly creating a better world for us all, one small act at a time. At Just Like My Child Foundation (JLMC), we want to take this time to honor our Dads for their daily heroic actions.

In most cultures, fathers are regarded as secondary caregivers. However in parenting, the importance of a father's role should not be diminished. Dads can represent authority, safety, security, and certainty for children.  Research shows that an increased amount of father-child involvement may increase a child’s social stability, educational achievement, and their potential to have a successful marriage. Children who have a father or father-figure in their lives tend to be more curious about the world around them, develop greater problem solving skills, and tend to have higher self-esteem. Impressive results for the guy who's often considered a secondary caregiver!

Saluting Heroic Dads in Uganda

We’ve all heard stories about Dads being able to lift a car off their child in Herculean fashion. JLMC wants to salute the Dads in Uganda who are using their strength to remove obstacles for their kids to reach their full potential. These Dads are willing to stand out in their community in support of their girl child and stand up for their children’s rights in defiance of a cultural norm. When going against custom, they face criticism, ostracism, and sometimes personal danger. They face incredible hardships, financial uncertainty, and peer pressure by making their children’s well-being a top priority. These are the Dads whose bravery we honor. They are ignoring gender norms to become an emotional safe space, trusted mentors, and lifelong advocates for their children.

JLMC has met many of these fathers in our decade of working in Uganda. In fact, their leadership is often more potent for community change: when a father leads, the community will follow. Men in Uganda possess more power and privilege than women do. In an area where nearly 50% of girls drop out of school by age 15, where 86.9% of rape victims are between the ages of 9 and 17, and where 31% of girls ages 15-19 have been pregnant or have had a child, JLMC counts on these male role models to help deliver the first step in implementing our Girl Power Project. 

The first step is to introduce laws of the land and human rights to a community, creating a network of support that promotes gender equality, law enforcement and the reduction of domestic violence and rape. It lays the foundation for girls’ and women’s empowerment in communities. These male change agents are convincing men and boys to question harmful and traditional norms regarding manhood. They are heroes without capes.

Honor a Heroic Dad in Your Life

25% of JLMC’s staff are Father’s who are proud to represent The Girl Power Project and lead their community in change. While JLMC is unabashedly proud of our commitment to women and girls, we have greatly relied on male donors, partners, board members, Dads, husbands, and sons to support our work. And they, too, have benefitted from our exchange.  

This holiday, honor the hero in your Dad (or another Dad you know) by giving a gift in his name to help JLMC reach more communities, engage more heroic Fathers, and ultimately, change the world! Your gift will help us reach more communities through Project Justice and the Girl Power Project. As thanks for your support, JLMC will cloak the Dad you honor in a virtual cape! Here's how your gift will be used:

$6 — Trains One Human Rights Legal Volunteer 

Human Rights Legal Volunteers (often fathers and men) are trained to act as first responders of legal issues in their community. They learn how to help victims of crime get services, like going to the hospital and the police, and they help follow up on legal cases—especially those that have to do with the sexual assault of girls. 

$50 — Trains 8 Human Rights Legal Volunteers 

YOUR GIFT: When you contribute at this level, we'll send you a Father's Day E-Card that you can use as a gift to pass onto the father in your life who makes a difference.

$100 — Helps a Human Rights Legal Volunteer host an open dialogue with everyone in his community (24 needed in 2017)

Human Rights Legal Volunteers host open dialogues with everyone in their community. They discuss human rights, children's rights, girls' rights, the laws of the country, and ways to refer crimes to the appropriate authorities. It's a safe space where people can ask questions, obtain advice, seek mediation, and discuss further resources within the community. These discussions create a network of support that promotes gender equality, law enforcement, and the reduction of domestic violence and rape within a community. 

YOUR GIFTS: We'll send you (or an awesome Dad you know) a shout out on Just Like My Child Foundation's social media channels AND a Father's Day E-Card you can use to honor a heroic Dad in your life.

$300 — Sponsors a workshop that reaches an ENTIRE community (2 needed in 2017)

This three day workshop trains 50 Human Rights Legal Volunteers in neighboring villages—reaching a whole community! This community-wide training creates a sustainable social safety net and referral system that girls can rely on now and into the future.

YOUR GIFTS: All of the above PLUS a Photo from Uganda of the individuals that you've touched with your contribution. Share it with a father in your life who's sticking up for what's right and pushing their kids to reach their full potential.

$2,000 — Brings 10 communities together in a forum where Human Rights Legal Volunteers can share and learn from each other (2 needed in 2017)

As many as 80 Human Rights Legal Volunteers from as many as 10 communities come together to share the experience of their work advocating for children's rights in their villages. Volunteers share their successes, discuss legal cases in their villages, and how they managed their challenges. In addition, 10 Human Rights Legal Volunteers are recognized for the outstanding impact they've made in their village with the gift of a bicycle that provides increased mobility of their work.

YOUR GIFTS: All of the above PLUS a personalized video from Uganda. You'll hear directly from the fathers and volunteers whose skills and relationships you've strengthened. 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you can't contribute, you can still help us make a difference! 

  • Use the share buttons above to share this campaign on Facebook and help spread the word!
  • Follow our work on Instagram @justlikemychild and tag a heroic Dad you know, who's protecting their kids and lifting them up to reach their full potential.

story:
¿POR QUÉ PAYÉ?

 

Mi nombre es Ainara Aristegui, empiezo este proyecto con mi mejor amiga Luna Bellver por aparente casualidad, o también podría decirse, causalidad.

 

Hace un año a finales del 2016 las dos hablábamos y soñábamos sobre el futuro.En 5 meses terminábamos nuestra formación académica y para celebrar dicha etapa decidimos hacer un viaje de un mes juntas. Ambas comprometidas con el medio ambiente y los derechos humanos queríamos y necesitábamos hacer un voluntariado. Anduvimos meses y meses buscando en plataformas de intercambio de labores, en ONGs y más pero no dimos con nada que se nos ajustara a nuestra disponibilidad y circunstancias.Por lo tanto, comentamos el plan en busca de ayuda y sugerencias y nuestras madres nos facilitaron el contacto de un indigena arahuaco, Moisés, el cual lleva todo el ámbito de comunicación y "negociación" con el exterior. Desde entonces, hemos estado en contacto con él en miras de dar a conocer, no vender, su estilo de vida y ayudarles a crecer como tribu, mediante la venta de sus productos artesanales en el resto del mundo.

 

Nuestro objetivo es donar a la comunidad un alto porcentaje de los beneficios obtenidos por la venta de los productos arahuacos. De tal manera, podremos invertir en la comunidad, primordialmente en educación y, más adelante en otros aspectos que sean imprescindibles.

 

En cuanto a la verosimilidad de este proyecto podréis ser capaces de ver el progreso y mejoras en la web interactiva que realizaremos una vez obtenido el capital mínimo para poder invertirlo y empezar a fondo, con amor e ilusión este proyecto humanitario.

 

Finalmente, quiero mencionar y resaltar que cualquier tipo de ayuda es útil, ya sea aporte monetario, o solidaridad profesional.

 

¡No dudéis en promocionarnos, es gratuito!

 

 

 

Tú nos ayudas a ayudar y nosotras hacemos lo mismo por tí

 

 

 
  • Ahora mismo estamos en una etapa embrionaria del proyecto y la mayoría de la financiación va a ir destinada a la creación de contenido para empezar a crear la web y poder distribuir mediante un canal fiable y honesto.
  • Los fondos van a ir destinados a la parte de producción del proyecto y en caso de que fuesen mayores de lo esperado los donaremos en su totalidad a proyectos de construcción de infraestructuras y educación dentro de la comunidad. 
 

 

 

El impacto

 

Para hacer este gran sueño realidad primero tenemos que convivir con la comunidad para conocer de cerca los conflictos y los productos, a parte de ser esencial para poder compartirlos con todos vosotros, mediante redes sociales y un blog para compartir la historia que se crea en cada paso del camino:

 
  • Es un proyecto que puede influir positivamente en muchísimos aspectos que necesitan de urgente cambio en nuestra sociedad, desde los principios más básicos.
  • Es un proyecto que hacemos con total entrega y dedicación a un bien mayor y podemos aseguraros que en cada paso estaréis presentes y  seréis parte del cambio que vamos a generar juntos. Lo más difícil es empezar, sin embargo, estamos seguras de que con vuestra ayuda podremos dar el primer paso, como bien dijo Lao Tzu " el viaje de miles de millas empieza con un solo paso" .

 

  

Riesgos y desafíos

 

Hay muchos riesgos como la seguridad en un país como Colombia. Establecer la medida equilibrada de producción y demanda. Que los medios de distribución sean honestos y efectivos... Id creando un equipo humano que se una al proyecto en la medida de que crezca y se consolide. Y un amplio etc que se irá creando a lo largo del camino. Aunque para nosotras esto no es mas que la gasolina que nos hace seguir queriendo aprender y mejorar. Y siendo fiel a nuestros valores y principios creemos que con la ayuda de las personas correctas para cada desafío podremos seguir ayudando a crear un mundo mejor en una constancia evolutiva.

 

 

¡Ayúdanos como y con lo que puedas!

 

Comparte nuestro proyecto con tus amigos, familia, el mundo y todo aquel que creas que pueda sentirse llamado a hacerlo realidad. 

Sé parte de nuestro equipo humano y colabora con nosotras para seguir generando esperanza mediante tus talentos y habilidades, ya sean de marketing, diseño web, programación, venta online, creatividad, experiencia en el sector o tu buena voluntad. 


 

 

Step forward Stand out and make it happen.
story_txt:
¿POR QUÉ PAYÉ? Mi nombre es Ainara Aristegui, empiezo este proyecto con mi mejor amiga Luna Bellver por aparente casualidad, o también podría decirse, causalidad.
 
Hace un año a finales del 2016 las dos hablábamos y soñábamos sobre el futuro.En 5 meses terminábamos nuestra formación académica y para celebrar dicha etapa decidimos hacer un viaje de un mes juntas. Ambas comprometidas con el medio ambiente y los derechos humanos queríamos y necesitábamos hacer un voluntariado. Anduvimos meses y meses buscando en plataformas de intercambio de labores, en ONGs y más pero no dimos con nada que se nos ajustara a nuestra disponibilidad y circunstancias.Por lo tanto, comentamos el plan en busca de ayuda y sugerencias y nuestras madres nos facilitaron el contacto de un indigena arahuaco, Moisés, el cual lleva todo el ámbito de comunicación y "negociación" con el exterior. Desde entonces, hemos estado en contacto con él en miras de dar a conocer, no vender, su estilo de vida y ayudarles a crecer como tribu, mediante la venta de sus productos artesanales en el resto del mundo.
 
Nuestro objetivo es donar a la comunidad un alto porcentaje de los beneficios obtenidos por la venta de los productos arahuacos. De tal manera, podremos invertir en la comunidad, primordialmente en educación y, más adelante en otros aspectos que sean imprescindibles.
 
En cuanto a la verosimilidad de este proyecto podréis ser capaces de ver el progreso y mejoras en la web interactiva que realizaremos una vez obtenido el capital mínimo para poder invertirlo y empezar a fondo, con amor e ilusión este proyecto humanitario.
 
Finalmente, quiero mencionar y resaltar que cualquier tipo de ayuda es útil, ya sea aporte monetario, o solidaridad profesional.
 
¡No dudéis en promocionarnos, es gratuito!   Tú nos ayudas a ayudar y nosotras hacemos lo mismo por tí   
Ahora mismo estamos en una etapa embrionaria del proyecto y la mayoría de la financiación va a ir destinada a la creación de contenido para empezar a crear la web y poder distribuir mediante un canal fiable y honesto.
Los fondos van a ir destinados a la parte de producción del proyecto y en caso de que fuesen mayores de lo esperado los donaremos en su totalidad a proyectos de construcción de infraestructuras y educación dentro de la comunidad. 
   El impacto Para hacer este gran sueño realidad primero tenemos que convivir con la comunidad para conocer de cerca los conflictos y los productos, a parte de ser esencial para poder compartirlos con todos vosotros, mediante redes sociales y un blog para compartir la historia que se crea en cada paso del camino: 
Es un proyecto que puede influir positivamente en muchísimos aspectos que necesitan de urgente cambio en nuestra sociedad, desde los principios más básicos.
Es un proyecto que hacemos con total entrega y dedicación a un bien mayor y podemos aseguraros que en cada paso estaréis presentes y  seréis parte del cambio que vamos a generar juntos. Lo más difícil es empezar, sin embargo, estamos seguras de que con vuestra ayuda podremos dar el primer paso, como bien dijo Lao Tzu " el viaje de miles de millas empieza con un solo paso" .

   

Riesgos y desafíos Hay muchos riesgos como la seguridad en un país como Colombia. Establecer la medida equilibrada de producción y demanda. Que los medios de distribución sean honestos y efectivos... Id creando un equipo humano que se una al proyecto en la medida de que crezca y se consolide. Y un amplio etc que se irá creando a lo largo del camino. Aunque para nosotras esto no es mas que la gasolina que nos hace seguir queriendo aprender y mejorar. Y siendo fiel a nuestros valores y principios creemos que con la ayuda de las personas correctas para cada desafío podremos seguir ayudando a crear un mundo mejor en una constancia evolutiva.  

¡Ayúdanos como y con lo que puedas! Comparte nuestro proyecto con tus amigos, familia, el mundo y todo aquel que creas que pueda sentirse llamado a hacerlo realidad. 
Sé parte de nuestro equipo humano y colabora con nosotras para seguir generando esperanza mediante tus talentos y habilidades, ya sean de marketing, diseño web, programación, venta online, creatividad, experiencia en el sector o tu buena voluntad.

story: As you may know, many of our people are suffering from food deserts and a down spiraling economy. Basic necessities are becoming more and more difficult to come by. Therefore we ask you at the National Black United Front to join us and our community partners as we prepare care packages for those in need.

Therefore we ask you at the National Black United Front to join us and our community partners as we prepare care packages for those in need.

story:
At Voice of Freedom we feel privileged to work with extraordinary women in our participatory photography projects. Our latest project grew out of a workshop last November at the Piam Onlus shelter in the small city of Asti, in northern Italy. 

We worked with ten Nigerian women. We gave them cameras and encouragement, and let them know that they could tell their own stories, in their own way, and we would help find a community that would listen to them. The women produced a body of powerful photography. Now we need your help to put on an exhibition of this work.

One of the women we worked with, Mercy, told us what the project means to her: “I hope it has impact, I hope it speaks of somebody’s story and I hope it helps to solve somebody’s problem.”

 

Masking tape on the walls

After we ran that workshop we put on a simple exhibition of the women’s work, enlarging a couple of each woman’s photographs, and fixing them with masking tape on the shelter’s walls.

The women invited their friends and partners, social workers and, for the few who had jobs, co-workers to the exhibition. It brought tears to our eyes to see how much it meant to them, how proud and empowered they were on seeing their work taken seriously.

Now we are excited to be staging a much more ambitious exhibition of these women’s photographs, professionally printed and hung, at Polo del '900, a magnificent cultural centre in the heart of Turin.

 

How much will it cost?

Canon and  The VII Foundation are covering part of the costs, and we’re hoping our Indiegogo campaign can cover the modest amount remaining, only £5,000 (plus an amount to cover Indiegogo fees).

 

Why this exhibition is important

“We trust you to bring our stories to the world,” Mercy says.

Mercy knows more than anyone how important it is to inform the Italian public about the plight of human trafficking and modern-day slavery in this country on the front lines of the migrant crisis.

Trafficking is perilous. Many die at sea. They are raped and prostituted in Libya and forced to work for pimps on the street in Italy before they are rescued, if they are rescued.

Mercy and many of her friends know many who did not survive the journey into Italy, but were among the some 3,000 people who die crossing the Mediterranean every year. Human trafficking has become a 5bn euro a year business, money made by exploiting some of the most vulnerable people in the world. 

The terror and loneliness they suffer must be awful. Yet some of these women have been able to communicate about it. They have overcome their trauma to tell their stories, in part because it's so important to them that the world see them as whole people. They are whole people — and this beautiful, humane photography is a testament to that.

Exhibition at the shelter - a woman talks about her work. Photo: Leila Segal

 

Who We Are 

Voice of Freedom works within the discipline of participatory photography - a recognised tool for advocacy and social activism. A facilitator works with the group, teaching them to use a camera so they can define, communicate and improve their situation. 

This makes powerful material that we show, with the women’s consent, in exhibitions to raise awareness of trafficking. The material is unique in that it is the women themselves who are telling the stories. The women own all the rights to their photographs.

 

What We’ve Done

Work by women on our earlier projects has been shown widely, to support international anti-trafficking campaigns. Examples include:

  • Amnesty International - major exhibition of work by women survivors of the Sinai torture camps, at Amnesty UK to highlight the issue of trafficking in the region.
  • Anti-Slavery International has twice featured galleries of work from Voice of Freedom on its website — see here and here.
  • A 10-page cover story and feature in Anti-Slavery International's Reporter Magazine using work by women on Voice of Freedom to support its Victim Protection Campaign for better treatment of trafficking victims in the UK.
  • Walk Free Foundation shared work from the project on its Facebook page, reaching an audience of 6 millions followers worldwide, to highlight the urgent need for action to combat modern-day slavery.

  • Work by women on Voice of Freedom is showcased at The Rights Lab, which ‘gathers some of the most impactful images and collections in the contemporary anti-slavery moment.’ 

You can also read an article by Voice of Freedom founder Leila Segal in Anti-Slavery International's Reporter Magazine last year on her experience of working with trafficked women, here.

'I wanted to talk about freedom.' Photo: Chloe

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope you can help us with a contribution, but whether you can or not, please help get the word out and share our campaign with your friends and your social media networks. Don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools.

 

Credits

The photos in our short video are by Chloe, Gloria, Desta Getaneh, Efe Bella, Zenebech Zeleke and Unity Jay, courtesy of Voice of Freedom. It was edited by Clare Elliot.

We ran the photography workshops at the Piam Onlus shelter, where Princess Okokon and her husband Alberto Mossino help women escape slavery. Watch a moving Guardian interview with Princess and Alberto about trafficking in Italy here.

story:
THE GHOST PEOPLE OF TANZANIA

They are called, zeru zeru, which in Swahili translates to the ghost people - these are the persecuted people with albinism (PWA) in Tanzania. Currently, Tanzania holds the world’s largest population of people living with albinism with 1 in every 1,400 individuals. But for country with such a large albinism population there is little awareness on the fact that albinism is a genetic condition. As a result of these misconceptions, the albinism population lives under the daily threat of abuse, abductions, and ritual killings. 

Witchcraft is at the root of Tanzanian culture, and  ‘Albino elixir’ has become a formula of which waganga wa kenyeji (African witch doctors) brew albino body parts fueling beliefs. They spread the lie that these potions bring wealth, power, and good fortune.

 

PWA have been kidnapped, tortured, and the murdered because of this misbelief.

 

Over the years, the situation has severely worsened, with the body parts of PWA selling for over $75,000 on the black market.This large sum of money in a country with great poverty has dismantled many communities as neighbors, friends, family members have evolved into murderers. This persecution over pigment has been mythologized for “medicine” and voodoo killings, and has created the genocide of the albino population.

 

THE VISUAL ADVOCACY PROJECT

In late August, I will be spending five weeks in Tanzania to create a visual advocacy project exploring the identities of Tanzanian PWA. The aim for every photograph produced is to combat the discrimination and attacks against people with albinism through education and advocacy.

Through powerful testimony and public art, I hope to create a bridge for Tanzanian society to become informed on truths of the condition and advocate for the inclusive human rights of people with albinism.

I will push the boundaries of the medium by exposing the photographs in the means of large-scale diptychs throughout Tanzania, bringing art into the streets - as a means of a public space for an encounter between a subject and it’s audience. One side of the diptych will be a photograph of a PWA conveying their unique personality and identity. The other will display a written passage, sharing their experience and voice. Please reference mockup below:

            

    

Bringing these images to a privileged space such as a gallery or online publication will not allow me to reach my targeted audience. These visual documents need to be seen by the very society that created these fallacies.

To go about the project, I will be collaborating with Tanzanian organization: Under the Same Sun. UTSS is passionately committed to ending discrimination and violence against persons with albinism and facilitating social inclusion and participation. Through the guidance of UTSS, I will have the opportunity to conduct thorough field researching techniques and become integrated into the albinism community as sensitively as possible.

You can read more about them here: www.underthesamesun.com

                

When human rights are ignored, the marginalization of certain persons within a society prevent such a group from becoming involved and benefitting from development. People with albinism have been rendered worthless by a society that denies their existence, yet their bodies hold a high commercial value for those that believe they hold magical power. These individuals live their entire life hidden. Hidden from the sun, hidden from light, hidden from others, hidden in the shadow of the world.

IMPACT

1 - Allows these individuals to tell their own story rather than someone tell it for them.  Let them speak of their experiences, emotions, thoughts - as they have been silenced for so long.

2 - Education breaks the cycle of injustice, poverty and marginalization. 

3 - To treat people with albinism with dignity, respect, and equality. To eradicate stigma and discrimination and for PWA to have the same opportunities for health, safety, gainful employment and personal fulfillment as everybody else.

 

WHAT IS NEEDED & WHAT YOU WILL GET

 

*** This project is entirely self funded and your support truly matters! ***

I am NOT asking donations for my flights, visa, vaccines, accommodations or travel expenses: 100% of your donations will go to executing this fundamental project!

All donations raised will go towards:

  • buying school supplies for the students with albinism: ($1,000.00)
  • buying medical supplies such as sunscreen, protective sunglasses, and hats for the Tanzanian albinism community: ($1,500.00)
  • buying the print supplies: paper, printing costs, wheatpaste: ($800.00)
  • visiting albinism communities all over Tanzania: ($300.00)
  • buying all the local perk items *which also benefits the local economy of the community
  • buying the perk fine art prints and books
  • future exhibitions, marketing, and showcasing the work
  • indiegogo fees: (5% + processing fees)

 

In return, besides my infinite gratitude and love, you will:

  • feel good about supporting such an awesome photography project!
  • know that you made a push towards fair and equal human rights.
  • provide many people with albinism the opportunity to have access to proper medical resources.
  • help break the cycle of injustice, poverty and marginalization.
  • give Tanzanian people with albinism the opportunity to express their VOICE.
  • receive beautiful perks that will remind you of your generosity and participation in this project!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Sharing and spreading the word this campaign would be AMAZING!  A repost on any social media, email forwarding or knock-on-your-neighbors-door.  A little help goes a long way.

For any additional questions on the project or just want to know more, please do not hesitate to reach out:

- hello@shotbysoraya.com

- www.sorayamatos.com

 

(*Please note that the as an individual advocating  for the dignity of persons with albinism,  the term “Person with Albinism (PWA)” is preferred over its similar variants over the term “albino.” This is not only because of the historically derogatory use of “albino,” but also because the term, PWA, puts the person before their condition)

_______________

Image Credits:

#1: Justin Dingwall - www.justindingwall.com

#2-3, 9 - 10: Daniel Rodrigues - www.danielrodriguesphoto.com

#4 - 8: Ana Palacios - www.ana-palacios.com

story:
RO

 

Aproape 10.000.000 de romani locuiesc in afara granitelor.
Chiar daca tara noastra a progresat pe anumite planuri, sistemul de sanatate nu este unul dintre ele. Intelegem de ce ai plecat din tara ta si mai intelegem si ca trebuie sa iti fie foarte greu acolo unde esti. Ai lasat in urma oamenii apropiati tie, pentru a le oferi un viitor mai promitator si mai sigur. Exact acesta este si scopul nostru, scopul Beard Brothers.


La inceputul lunii februarie, raportul anual SMURD a dezvaluit o serie de informatii ingrijoratoare despre echipamentele si vehiculele SMURD.
 

”Cele mai importante probleme sunt legate de ambulantele cu care lucram si aparatura de pe ele, sunt ambulante vechi cu aparatura veche. Problemele apar cand mergi la o interventie si constati, pe drum, ca ambulanta nu mai trage si ceri dispeceratului sa trimita alta. Sunt si situaţii si mai grave cand ajungi la caz si se defecteaza ambulanta cu un pacient in stare critica in masina, atunci esti intr-o situatie disperata.” – medicul sef UPU-SMURD Cluj, Cristian Ursu.

 

”La capitolul ambulante stam cel mai prost, avem o singura ambulanta cu vechime de 6 ani în interventie, restul sunt de la 7 ani in sus. Se strica frecvent, au fost ambulante stricate, nu am avut bani sa le reparam si, astfel, au fost zone din judet care nu au mai fost acoperite” – Seful ISU Cluj, Ion Moldovan.


Poate ca ati auzit despre noi sau poate ca nu. Dar noi v-am auzit. Stim ca Romania este in continuare “acasa” pentru voi si ca aveti inca speranta ca lucrurile se vor schimba in bine. Mai stim si ca doriti sa ne ajutati, dar nu ati avut ocazia sa o faceti. Acum o aveti! O ambulanta noua costa 150.000 euro. Cu ajutorul celor de acasa am reusit sa strangem mai mult de jumatate din suma. Acum avem nevoie de voi, pentru ca dorim sa strangem o parte din suma ramasa cu ajutorul vostru.

Frumusetea acestei platforme este ca poti dona in orice moneda!

Cum ne mai poti ajuta?

Da un share, ca sa raspandesti vestea.

 

EN

 

Almost 10 million Romanians are living abroad. Although our country has progressed in some areas, health care isn’t one of them. We understand why you left, we also understand that it was and still is incredibly hard. You’ve left someone close behind in order to give them a better and safer future. And that’s exactly what we, Beard Brothers, are trying to achieve.

 

At the beginning of February, SMURD’s yearly report uncovered a series of worrying information regarding SMURD’s equipment and vehicles.

 

* SMURD - Mobile Emergency Service for Resuscitation and Extrication

 

”The most serious problems concerning the ambulances we work with and their equipment, they are old ambulances and the equipment is outdated. It has happened that on our way to a job the ambulance will stall, so you ask the dispatcher to send another one. Even worse, sometimes the ambulance breaks down while on it’s way with a critical patient, then you are in a desperate situation” - Chief Physician of UPU-SMURD, Cristian Ursu.

 

“Our ambulances are our weak point, only one of them being 6 years old, the other ones have been in service for 7 years or longer. They break down often, sometimes there are no funds available for repairs, leaving areas in our county uncovered.” -  Chief of ISU Cluj, Ion Moldovan.

 

Maybe you’ve heard of us, maybe you haven’t. But we heard you. We know Romania’s still “home”, we know you still have some hope left that things will get better and we know you want to help, you just didn’t have the opportunity. So here it is! A new ambulance costs 150.000 Euro, and with the help of your dear ones at home we’ve raised more than half. And now we need you! We’d like to raise a fraction of  that amount with your help.

The beauty of this platform is that you can donate in any currency!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please SHARE this page with all your friends!

story:
(Hrvatski prijevod ispod)

 

Who We Are and What We Do

 

Borders: none is a humanitarian association with the basic aim to help refugees in integration into society. We believe that friendship and knowledge are the biggest gifts you can give to someone who was forced to flee their own home. And we strongly believe there are no boundaries in human potential.

Experiences from Europe show us that most of the refugees end up doing jobs far below their potential and many of them end up homeless. This happens for several reasons but mostly due to the lack of a professional network. The result is reduced opportunities in job finding.

Our project is a web development course for refugees in which we teach them HTML, CSS, JavaScript and Java. 
In our first course none of the participants had any prior knowledge of programming, and through the course, over two months they gained the knowledge of HTML, CSS and the basics of JavaScript and made their first website. In our next course, we would like to enroll more students, provide them with better equipment and raise the quality of our lectures. That is why we need you to back us up.

 

What Will You Fund 

If you donate to our cause we'll spend your money on:

  • Equipment - we are always in a need for new computers for our students
  • Software licenses 
  • Rental costs for venue 
  • Other supplies - whiteboard, whiteboard materials, printing costs, licenses for software tools, drinks, coffees, teas for our students...
  • Other unexpected costs during next year

What you can get: 

To see what you can get, take a look at our list of perks - we hope you find something for yourself :) 

If you don't need anything we still hope you will find this important and back us up by donating to our cause 

 

What You Really Get :)

 

Genuine happiness. 

Since software developer is deficitary job position, the visible result of this course is most likely their employment in some IT company in near future. But there are far more important benefits for them in this story. Through learning a new skill, they gain back their self-confidence, learn they can be winners and connect to like-minded people in their new environment by becoming friends with them. They start to identify themselves as "developers" and part of a group. That's what makes us happy the most and we are proud to be a little part of this. And that's what'll make you happy :)

 

You Want To Be a Part of This?

You liked our story so much that you want to join us? Sure! Coffee is always a good idea, let's meet. You can find our contact on our website.

At least, use share buttons and share us on social networks :)

 

Tko smo i što radimo

 

Borders: none je humanitarna udruga kojoj je osnovni cilj pomoći izbjeglicama u integraciji. Vjerujemo da su društvo i znanje najveći pokloni koje možemo pokloniti nekome tko je bio prisiljen pobjeći iz vlastitog doma.  Također, snažno vjerujemo da ne postoje granice ljudskog potencijala.

Iskustva iz Europe pokazuju nam kako većina izbjeglica završi radeći poslove daleko ispod njihovog potencijala, a mnogo njih postanu i beskućnici. Ovo se događa iz nekoliko razloga, ali najviše zbog nedostatka profesionalne mreže. Rezultat toga je smanjena mogućnost pronalaska posla. 

Naš projekt je  tečaj programiranja za izbjeglice u kojem ih podučavamo HTML, CSS JavaScript i Javu. 
Na našem prvom tečaju nitko od polaznika nije imao ranija znanja u programiranju te su kroz tečaj od dva mjeseca stekli znanje HTMLa CSSa i osnovnog JavaScripta i napravili svoju prvu web stranicu. U sljedeće tečajeve, želimo uključiti više studenata, pružiti im bolju opremu i podići kvalitetu naših predavanja. Zato trebamo vas da nas podržite.

Kako je programer danas deficitarno zanimanje, vidljiv rezultat našeg tečaja je vjerojatno njihovo zapošljavanje u nekoj od IT kompanija u bliskoj budućnosti. Ali osim toga, postoje mnogo važniji benefiti u cijeloj priči. Kroz učenje novih vještina, vraća im se samopouzdanje, uče kako mogu biti pobjednici te se povezuju s ljudima koji dijele njihove interese u novoj okolini i postoju prijatelji s njima.  Počinju se identificirati kao "programeri" i dio profesionalne grupe. To je dio koji nas najviše veseli :)

Za što ćeš donirati? 

Ako doniraš za naš cilj, novac ćemo potrošiti na:

  • Opremu - uvijek smo u potrazi za novom opremom za naše studente
  • Licence za alate koje koristimo u radu
  • Troškove najma 
  • Ostalo - whiteboard, whiteboard materijale, troškove printanja, pića, kave, čajeve za naše studente
  • Ostale neočekivane troškove tijekom godine

Što možeš dobiti ovime: 

Možeš nešto potražiti na našoj listi benefita (perks) ili... 

Ako ne želiš ništa, ipak se nadamo da ćeš ovo smatrati važnim ciljem i podržati nas donacijom!

 

Što zaista dobivaš :)

Istinsku sreću. 

Kako je programer danas deficitarno zanimanje, vidljiv rezultat našeg tečaja je vjerojatno njihovo zapošljavanje u nekoj od IT kompanija u bliskoj budućnosti. Ali osim toga, postoje mnogo važniji benefiti u cijeloj priči. Kroz učenje novih vještina, vraća im se samopouzdanje, uče kako mogu biti pobjednici te se povezuju s ljudima koji dijele njihove interese u novoj okolini i postoju prijatelji s njima.  Počinju se identificirati kao "programeri" i dio profesionalne grupe. To je dio koji nas najviše veseli i sretni smo što možemo biti dio toga :) A to je nešto što će i tebe najviše veseliti. :)

 

Želiš biti dio ove priče?

Toliko ti se svidjela naša priča da nam se želiš pridružiti? Kava je uvijek odlična ideja, ajmo se naći! Naš kontakt možeš naći na našoj web stranici. 

Ako išta drugo, barem podijeli našu priču na društvenim medijima :)

story:
Our Story

The five artists of Living Melody Collective (Haylee Anne, Angela Bortone, Jessica Caldas, Danielle Deadwyler and Angela Davis Johnson) are partnering with local activist, Liliana Bakhtiari, to paint a school bus to mobilize the vote in Georgia.  In response to voter machine concerns, and voter suppression tactics like recent events in Randolph County, Living Melody Collective will draw inspiration from the history of voting rights and trace the changes in the voting systems through history from paper ballot to our current electronic system. We are crowd-funding this mural through Indiegogo and painting it in time for voter engagement leading up to the upcoming midterm elections November 6th.

For Living Melody Collective, this piece will be a natural expansion of their mission to create beautiful artistic disruptions for social justice and the community. This school bus project comes on the heels of a 32 ft mural for the Center for Civil and Human rights that addressed Dr. King's late work with homelessness and exclusivity filtered through the scope of the current housing crisis in Atlanta. Their partnership with Liliana Bakhtiari is a collaborative civic engagement through art. For the artists, this is not just a static mural but a mobile installation that will create a conversation around the importance of voting, and motivate people to engage. 

This project is a continuation of Liliana Bakhtiari’s platform of commitment to community, accessibility and equality for all humans. Liliana's 2017 run for city council was founded on the principles of positivity, equity and accessibility, building off of her extensive history of organizing and activism. She made national headlines as a queer, Muslim daughter of Iranian-Azeri immigrants and refugees during her first run for political office. As her next move after running for office, Bakhtiari bought this school bus in Bartow County to support progressive candidates, including Stacey Abrams for Governor during the midterm elections this November. 

What We Need

Our goal is $15K. This money goes toward supporting the artists who have already volunteered their time and supplied all of the high-quality automotive paint and other painting supplies. We also need to get this mural around Georgia, which means gas money. With your generous contributions, we will be able to make it to the outer limits of Georgia and engage voters every day up until November 6th.

The Impact

This effort is a continuation of Liliana Bakhtiari’s platform of commitment to community, accessibility, and equality for all humans. 

We are hoping not only to raise awareness around the current gubernatorial election, but also to bolster excitement for other statewide and down ballot races that have the potential to drastically impact Georgia's future and so often go un-noticed. It is important to us to reach people from all landscapes, all socio-economic backgrounds, and all ideologies. It is more important now than ever to unite as Georgians in order to imagine a better Georgia for everyone.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that there is a lot of good work going on leading up to this important election. We are all stretched thin and giving as much as we can. Remember that just $5 or $10 is a huge help with this grassroots movement. If you cannot manage a financial contribution at this time, we can still use your help!

  • Help us spread the word! Please share this fundraising campaign with your friends and family. Indiegogo makes it super easy to share.
  • Volunteer! We have a few spots for volunteers to join is on our tour around Georgia. You can sign up by emailing liliana@lilianaforatlanta.com

story:
Olive Trees For Palestine

Support Local Economies in the 3rd Oldest City in the World

 

The Boulder-Nablus Sister City Project (BNSCP) fosters relationships through cultural, educational and professional exchanges, inspiring lifelong friendships that promote understanding and peace through person-to-person “citizen diplomacy.”

Through ongoing conversations with our Sister City we have found that one of the largest requests from the community is the desire for olive trees. These trees are historically very important to local communities as they provide oil, income, cohesion, collaboration and cooperation among residents.

BNSCP chose the goal $5,430 as this is the elevation of Boulder. This amount will provide 815 one and a half year-old saplings to be planted in villages adjacent to Nablus. A collective of community partners are currently working on designating the right villages to plant the trees. 

In March of this year, a delegation will travel to Nablus, Palestine and spend a day helping farmers to plant the olive tree saplings. You are welcome to join the delegation. Get more information here. 

As a part of the International Sister City Program, BNSCP has been able able to cultivate relationships between communities in Nablus and Boulder through a whole range of projects since 2011. We have also taken dozens of Coloradans to the West Bank on delegations to meet with local residents and representatives.  

For more information on the BNSCP please visit http://bouldernablus.org/ and Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/BoulderNablusSisterCity/

With your help we look forward to a better future. 

Together let's support our friends in Nablus.

From Boulder to Nablus we thank you for your support! 

 

Helping you to understand the dire situation in Palestine and why we need to plant more olive trees are the following articles:

Fact Sheet: Olive Trees – More Than Just a Tree in Palestine:

"Olive trees carry more than an economic significance in the lives of Palestinians. They are not just like any another trees, they are symbolic of Palestinians’ attachment to their land. Because the trees are draught-resistant and grow under poor soil conditions, they represent Palestinian resistance and resilience. The fact that olive trees live and bear fruit for thousands of years is parallel to Palestinian history and continuity on the land. Palestinians are proud of their olive trees; they take care of them with care and appreciation. Palestine has some of the world’s oldest olive trees, dating back to 4,000 years. Some families have trees that have been passed down to them for generations and the olive harvest season in October bears a socio-cultural meaning where families come together to harvest olive trees bearing in mind that their forefathers and mothers had tended to the same trees several years ago.

In addition to their symbolic meaning, olives are a main source of income for around 80,000 Palestinian families. According to UN figures, around 48% of the agricultural land in the West Bank and Gaza is planted with olive trees. Olive trees account for 70% of fruit production in Palestine and contribute around 14% to the Palestinian economy. 93% of the olive harvest is used for olive oil production while the rest is used for olive soap, table olives and pickles. Much of the olive production is for local consumption with a small amount of olives being exported primarily to Jordan. With the growing interest in organic food and fair trade, Palestinian olives are now also reaching European and North American markets."

Why Israelis have cut down 800,000 Palestinian Olive Trees: 

"Olive tree felling is a longtime strategy of Israel’s occupation regime in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Since 1967, an estimated 800,000 Palestinian olive trees have been destroyed by Israeli authorities and settlers." 

Destruction of Palestinian olive trees is a monstrous crime:

"Over the last 40 years, over a million olive trees and hundreds of thousands of fruit trees have been destroyed in Palestinian lands. The Israel Defense Forces have been accused of uprooting olive trees to facilitate the building of settlements, expand roads and build infrastructure.

The uprooting of centuries-old olive trees has caused tremendous losses to farmers and their families."

Palestinian olive harvest season: A symbol of resistance

"If the olive trees knew the hands that planted them, their oil would become tears," Mahmoud Darwish once said.

The olive harvest is a tradition as ancient as Palestine, and paints a poetic narrative of the relationship between the people and their land. Olive trees survive the toughest conditions and grow their roots deeply into the earth, which they call home.

For thousands of years, these trees have stood as a symbol of resistance, firm against all odds of nature; similar to the Palestinians themselves, who are standing firm against all the challenges of occupation and believing in the words of Mahmoud Darwish: "We have on this land what makes life worth living."
story_txt:
Olive Trees For Palestine
Support Local Economies in the 3rd Oldest City in the World
 
The Boulder-Nablus Sister City Project (BNSCP) fosters relationships through cultural, educational and professional exchanges, inspiring lifelong friendships that promote understanding and peace through person-to-person “citizen diplomacy.”
Through ongoing conversations with our Sister City we have found that one of the largest requests from the community is the desire for olive trees. These trees are historically very important to local communities as they provide oil, income, cohesion, collaboration and cooperation among residents.
BNSCP chose the goal $5,430 as this is the elevation of Boulder. This amount will provide 815 one and a half year-old saplings to be planted in villages adjacent to Nablus. A collective of community partners are currently working on designating the right villages to plant the trees. 
In March of this year, a delegation will travel to Nablus, Palestine and spend a day helping farmers to plant the olive tree saplings. You are welcome to join the delegation. Get more information here. 
As a part of the International Sister City Program, BNSCP has been able able to cultivate relationships between communities in Nablus and Boulder through a whole range of projects since 2011. We have also taken dozens of Coloradans to the West Bank on delegations to meet with local residents and representatives.  
For more information on the BNSCP please visit http://bouldernablus.org/ and Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/BoulderNablusSisterCity/
With your help we look forward to a better future. 

Together let's support our friends in Nablus.
From Boulder to Nablus we thank you for your support!

"Olive trees carry more than an economic significance in the lives of Palestinians. They are not just like any another trees, they are symbolic of Palestinians’ attachment to their land.
