story:
Important

The Indiegogo online donating period has come to an end, but you can still donate by sending a cheque made out to 'Clynfyw CIC' and sent to - Jim Bowen, Clynfyw Farm, Abercych, Boncath, SA37 0HF. Thanks.

Background

Over the past month people in Carmarthenshire, Pembrokeshire and across south Wales have been collecting items to send to refugees in Europe. A 20ft container full of tents, sleeping bags, clothes and toiletries left west Wales for the Greek island of Kos on Friday October the 2nd. The container will arrive with the charity 'Kos Kindness​' before the end of the month. The donated items will then be distributed to the 100's of refugees who are arriving on the island daily.  We will also donate the container itself, as a lack of storage has been a major problem for them over the past few weeks.

What We Need

To do this we need to raise around £5,000. We are organising concerts (Carmarthen 03/10/15 - raised £809) (Llandysul, 04/10/15 raised £340), we will be packing bags at Tesco (17/10/15) and Morrisons (TBC) to raise funds, and a local group has already pledged money (Coda Ni, £1,000), but we also need your support so that we can pay for this 1st container, and hopefully send another one in the future. Any donation will be greatly appreciated.

We will update you with pictures and more information here and on our Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/WalesSupportsRefugees

Kos Kindness

"As many will be aware there is a great influx of refugees arriving on the Island on a daily basis and Kos Kindness has extended its support to ensure that as much help as is possible is given to the families and children arriving. We distribute, baby food, baby wipes, sanitary items, food, baby child and adult clothing and shoes and basic need requirements such as toothbrushes, toothpaste, shampoo, soap, back packs pop up tents, sleeping bags etc. as well as passing out toys for the children who have landed on our Island with nothing. A smile when a teddy is passed over is a joy to behold. We are a registered charity in Greece. You can follow our work here - https://www.facebook.com/Kos-Kindness-159755314181314/ "

Thanks for your support.

-------------------------------------------------------

Pwysig

Mae'r cyfnod cyfrannu arlein trwy Indiegogo wedi dod i ben, ond gallwch dal gyfrannu trwy anfon siec yn daliadwy i 'Clynfyw CIC' a'i bostio at - Jim Bowen, Clynfyw, Abercych, Boncath, SA37 0HF. Diolch.

Y Cefndir

Dros yr wythnosau diwethaf bu pobl yn Sir Gaerfyrddin, Sir Benfro ac ar hyd de Cymru yn casglu nwyddau i’w anfon at Ffoaduriaid yn Ewrop. Fe adawodd container 20' yn llawn pebyll, sachau cysgu, dillad a deunydd ymolchi orllewin Cymru am Kos ar ddydd Gwener Hydref yr 2il. Bydd y container yn cyrraedd yr elusen 'Kos Kindness' cyn ddiwedd y mis. Bydd y nwyddau wedyn yn cael eu dosbarthu i'r cannoedd o ffoaduriaid s'yn cyrraedd yr ynys yn ddyddiol. Byddwn hefyd yn gadael y container gyda nhw, gan fod gofod ar gyfer storio wedi bod yn broblem fawr iddyn nhw dros yr wythnosau diwethaf.

Beth sydd angen arnom

Er mwyn gwneud hyn mae angen codi oddeutu £5,000. Rydym yn trefnu cyngherddau (Caerfyrddin 03/10/15 - codwyd £849) (Llandysul, 04/10/15 codwyd £340), pacio bagiau yn siopau Tesco (17/10/15) a Morrisons, ac mae grŵp lleol eisoes wedi addo arian (Coda Ni, £1,000), ond mae angen eich cefnogaeth chi arnom hefyd, fel bod modd i ni dalu am y container 1af, a gobeithio anfon un arall yn y dyfodol. Byddwn yn gwerthfawrogi unrhyw rodd. Byddwn yn eich diweddaru gyda lluniau a mwy o wybodaeth yma ac ar ein Tudalen Facebook https://www.facebook.com/WalesSupportsRefugees

Mae Kos Kindness yn elusen gofrestredig yng ngwlad Groeg. Gallwch ddilyn eu gwaith yma https://www.facebook.com/Kos-Kindness-159755314181314/

Diolch am eich cefnogaeth.

story:
My name is Brian. I am an ex-soldier and Federal Agent; an organised crime operations specialist. (I am the guy who strips on stage in the video for this campaign).

For around 17 years I have been working on counter-slavery operations around the world. In this time, I have been to dozens of countries and seen the faces of the trafficked and enslaved making the things we buy; the teenagers on fishing boats, the children (and toddlers!) in mines and plantations, the women and girls in factories stitching our clothes. And we have all seen tragedies like Rana Plaza which should never have happened.

More than 90% of slavery is in the private sector; owned by big business. And they exist because we buy their stuff.

That's 10s of millions of children, teeangers, women, and men. I started slavefreetrade to end slavery in supply chains; that is where we find about 80% of all slavery today.

This campaign is to help get slavefreetrade up and running. You can help us free 45 million people in modern slavery.

Your contributions get us operational. You help us get in the blockchain and other advanced tech needed, bring in the staff needed, and put it all together as working programmes, to get slaves liberated.

You help us get slave-free labelling onto products in stores so that we, the consumer, can start telling business how we want our things made.

We have hurdles in front of us, of course. Not the least of which is big business (much of which is strongly against our form of transparency). And, of course, slavers don't want us doing what we are doing. But we don't scare that easily.

If you cannot contribute financially, or want to help in other ways, take a look at these ideas:

1) Get the word out and make some noise about slavefreetrade. The stronger the movement behind slavefreetrade, the more liberating our impact.

2) Ask the stores where you shop if they stock certified slave-free. If they don't, tell them that is what you want of the things you buy.

3) Join us! All volunteers are very, very welcome to help improve our programmes, and to spread the word.

4) Use the Indiegogo share tools!

We have hurdles in front of us, of course. Not the least of which is big business (much of which is strongly against our form of transparency). And, of course, slavers don't want us doing what we are doing. But we don't scare that easily.
If you cannot contribute financially, or want to help in other ways, take a look at these ideas:
1) Get the word out and make some noise about slavefreetrade. The stronger the movement behind slavefreetrade, the more liberating our impact.
2) Ask the stores where you shop if they stock certified slave-free. If they don't, tell them that is what you want of the things you buy.
3) Join us! All volunteers are very, very welcome to help improve our programmes, and to spread the word.
4) Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Fresno Resistance

We are an intersectional, silo-breaking, leftist collective led by queer/undocumented/women of color. Our goal is to lead the local resistance and challenge systems of oppression. We have no allegiance to any political party. White fragility, respectability politics and a general defense of the status quo will not be tolerated. Misogyny, racism, xenophobia, Islamophobia, transphobia, homophobia are strictly prohibited.

We are calling on the community to help us cover bail and legal defense fees related to our work. Fresno PD continues to target community organizers in an effort to silence and instill fear in the community. Several organizers have been charged and we need your support.

Your contribution will help us continue fighting to make Fresno a better place for everyone.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate please share this campaign with friends and family.

story:
Where We Are Going

The Hult Prize is an international start-up accelerator that brings together the brightest college and university students from around the globe to solve today’s most pressing social problems. This year's competition is focused on the global refugee crisis and challenges students like us to think critically and creatively about unlocking the human potential of refugees throughout their journeys. As a result, thousands of teams have competed both domestically and abroad to secure spots in one of the five regional competitions. As the winning team from William & Mary's local competition, we earned a spot in the San Francisco regional competition in March.

While in San Francisco, we hope to present our business plan. Our business model would allow us to digitally connect refugees to resources while they are on the move, and work with them to increase their employability upon arrival in a third country or country of resettlement, all while functioning as a profitable business venture. We have used the interdisciplinary academic, extracurricular, and professional experience of our team to inform our business strategy and social impact plan. We cannot wait to present in San Francisco to a group of esteemed judges and extremely qualified peers.

What We Need

In order to present at the regional competition, however, we must travel to and stay in San Francisco for several nights. As full time students, the expense of the trip is well above our budgets. Although we were told that the trip was originally funded through our business program, due to administrative lack of communication, we were left with an abundance of hope but zero funding. We have estimated that the cost of travel, housing, and basic necessities while we are in San Francisco will total only $3,500 for our whole team. As we move closer and closer to the competition dates, every cent counts.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate at this time, but know of folks who are, please share our story! And if you know of resources available to us in San Francisco, please let us know! We accept words of encouragement and restaurant recommendations too!

story:
We are a group of women creating an integrated, diverse farm that serves multiple purposes, including:

• Ecological benefits for rivers, groundwater, soil, habitat creation, wildlife food, insectaries , carbon sink
• A welcoming beautiful food-producing landscapes for our community, including natural playgrounds and hide-outs
• Outdoor teaching and learning space
• Opportunities for participation 
• An abundance of food to share - our fresh vegetables are donated to the Kennett Food Cupboard.

This spring, we got the approval from Kennett Township to move our operation onto public land at Spar Hill Farm. While we have been hard at work, there are many things still missing to turn this first year into a bountiful success.

What We Need

To successfully grow an abundance of food and medicinal plants this first season on new land and to integrate an increasing number of volunteers, we need:

$1,500 deer fencing

$2,000 irrigation supplies

$500 limestone

$1,000 project management software

$1,500 signage

$1,500 tools and other supplies

$500 harvest crates

$1,000 restroom rental

$500 organic pest control, cover crops and organic fertilizers

Total: $10,000

 

The Impact

Your contribution will make a huge difference in our community. We are serving food-insecure households by directly donating the food we grow to the Kennett Food-Cupboard and Free Food for All. 

With the funds you provide, we will be able to protect our crops from deer and drought, bugs and fungal diseases. This way, our efforts and hard work will come to fruition and will feed many families.

Furthermore, a successful season will generate many highly motivated, proud and happy volunteers. Especially during this pandemic, we need to take care of each others emotional well-being - and participating in a beautiful and abundant community garden can do just that!

story:
The Gateway Campaign Continues!  This is a global campaign and donations can be accepted at www.freesetgateway.com.  Thanks for your support!


Freeset is a fair trade business offering employment to women who are trapped in Kolkata's sex trade. We make quality jute bags and organic cotton t-shirts, but our business is freedom. 

Freeset seeks to buy the  Gateway Building situated at the entrance to Sonagacchi - India's most infamous sex district. This 20,000 square foot will give more women and girls the opportunity to choose freedom from prostitution, as we expand our capacity and support the growth of new freedom businesses. 

  • Sex slavery is a growing problem in our world, and India's sex trade is booming. 
  • Freeset is addressing this problem, but to do more we need your help.
  • In helping, you become part of the freedom story—offering women in the sex trade an alternative source of employment, thereby reducing the economic issues that lead to young girls being sold or tricked into the sex trade industry. 


In 1999, Kerry and Annie Hilton left New Zealand to move to Kolkata with a very broad goal: to help the poor and the needy. After naively leasing an apartment right beside Sonagacchi, their goal became much clearer: to give women forced into prostitution by trafficking and poverty the choice of freedom.

Once in the sex trade, women have little or no hope of leaving it or earning their freedom. Society has labeled them unclean—outcasts. 

The women and girls desperately needed an alternate source of income. The Hilton's realized that by training the women with new skills they could start a business that would provide sustainable employment and a path to freedom. This was the beginning of Freeset.

You can learn more about Freeset here


Our ultimate goal is $3 Million, but we are breaking it up into 5 steps. As we complete each goal, we become one step closer to helping more women and girls choose freedom from a life of sex slavery. 

Our timeline is very short. The owners of the property will close on the sale by the end of June 2015, so we need to raise $2 Million of our goal by June 30th.  This is a global campaign - with multiple fundraising efforts across the global.  Freeset USA is leading this Indiegogo campaign.  If you would like to make a larger donation via check, please send an email to gateway@freesetglobal.com.

Freeset has already made two down payments on the building.  Step 1 is raising $200,000 to make a 3rd down payment on the Gateway Building. 

Step 2 is raising an additional $200,000, which will allow us to make a 4th down payment on the building. 

At Step 3, we will be over halfway to purchasing the building! 

At Step 4 the building can be purchased and closing costs can be paid. Our team can now begin the necessary renovations on the building. Once the renovations are underway, we can begin to turn the building into a workspace and sanctuary for many hundreds more women. 

Step 5 is raising an additional $700,000, which would push us to the finish line of our $3 Million goal. $200,00 of this will provide for the renovations. The other $500,000 will provide funding for the social services necessary for these women and their families to more fully achieve freedom: healthcare, education, counseling, literacy training, and childcare. 


Your donations to Freeset USA will help fund the acquisition and renovation of the 20,000 square foot Gateway Building as well as provide community services to the women of Sonagacchi. This building will bring an additional 300+ women to sustainable freedom by providing a safe workspace and community. When you take into account the benefits of Freeset’s businesses and social services on the women’s children and extended communities, the true impact will number in the thousands.

Here are some photos that members of our team have taken on their most recent visit to the building. 

The exterior of the Gateway Building as seen from Central Avenue. 

View from the Gateway Building courtyard looking skyward.  

Panorama from the rooftop of the Gateway Building. 


Other Ways You Can Help - Spread The Word!

We know that our goal is an ambitious one, and there are many other ways you can help us meet this goal other than just donating to the cause. 

It's amazing how much good work can simply come from talking about something. Share this campaign with your friends, family, and co-workers and together we can provide hundreds of women with the freedom that they deserve. 

We will be providing updates on this project across our social media platforms throughout  the course of this campaign. One of the easiest ways to spread the word is by simply retweeting, sharing, and repinning the content we have created!  

Freeset on Facebook

Freeset on Twitter

Freeset On Pinterest


Donation Safeguards

Freeset USA is an independent U.S. Nonprofit section 501(c)(3) organization dedicated to ending human trafficking and modern slavery. Freeset USA will conduct independent reviews and monitor the use of funds raised through the Gateway Campaign to ensure contributions are used for the intended charitable purposes of starting and expanding freedom businesses and social services through Freeset. In compliance with government guidelines and tax rules, Freeset USA must retain full control and discretion over the funds raised to ensure that the funds are distributed in a manner consistent with and in the best interest of its tax-exempt purposes, including the discretion to use the funds for other tax exempt purposes as it deems appropriate. 

All contributions from US residents are tax deductible to the full extent of law.

story:
~ G I R L S * R O C K * A S H E V I L L E  ~

Girls Rock Asheville is a volunteer-powered non-profit that relies on the support of the greater Asheville community and beyond. Our camp is committed to supporting families of all kinds and providing a great experience for all campers regardless of income, and that's why no camper is turned away if they are unable to pay for camp. We are one of the few camps in the area offering an affordable camp with full and partial scholarships. 

The money raised in this Indiegogo Campaign will contribute to funding our 2nd annual camp, which will be held at The Mothlight in West Asheville June 22-27. During this week, campers will form bands, learn to play an instrument, write a song, attend workshops, and perform in a final showcase on Saturday, June 27. We have reached our registration goal, so now it is time to rally supporters of Girls Rock Asheville and make it possible to empower girls and trans* youth through music education and community. Last year's camp was incredibly successful and GRAVL continues to inspire in creating a safe, educational, nurturing, creative, and fun environment for girls and trans* youth to create with confidence.

Here are some of the goods/services that the money raised through this Indiegogo Campaign will go towards, and what your support will enable:

-  Insurance

-  Camp space and show venue

-  T-shirts to give out at camp

-  Showcase programs, zines, band pics

-  Projector for presentations and videos

-  Last minute gear and supplies (cords, aux. equipment, repairs)

-  Printing cost for GRAVL promotional materials

____________________________________________________________________________

While monetary support is certainly appreciated, there are other ways you can help! We are seeking donations of musical equipment, printing of materials, and food for campers/volunteers. Want to be a band coach or instrument instructor?! 

Check out our volunteer opportunities and application! 

_________________________                   __________________________________________

Thanks and Shout-outs:

Very special thanks to The Mothlight, host of the inaugural GRAVL Camp, 2014, and host of GRAVL Camp and Showcase 2015!

Many thanks to all of our ongoing donors, partners, and sponsors, including:

The Odditorium, YWCA, Girls on the Run, Peggy Foreman, Margaret Foreman, Angela Baker-James, Trudy Duffy, Amy Mandel, Katina Rodis, Kate Kinney Barber, Scrounger's Paradise, Posh Hammer, The Altamont, Lockie Hunter, The Hop, Orbit Video, Rylie Stone, Cooperman Drums, Harvest Records, King Daddy's, Autumn Greenfield, Golden Seed Productions, Altamont Brewing Co., Navitat, Freaks and Geeks, Malaprops, Sam Squared, Guitar Trader, Mary Driscol, Meg B., Russ White, Tia Mizner, Mado, Marcel, Amah Mitchell, Jim Holland, Kevin Stanford (Knives and Daggers), New Mountain, The Orange Peel, Luke Wood, Tenni (Zombie Queen), Simon Eaton, Trish Young, Brian and Liz Farrand, Steven Hogan, Tom Peters, The Orange Peel, New Mountain, Blue Mountain Pizza, Leland Robbins-Murphy, Blackout Effectors, Justin Whitlow, Josh Carpenter, Kevin Barber, Xbenx, Lynn Rogers, Josey Dixon, Scott and Joel (Gutterhound), Joey Cain, Nicholas Prosser, Jim Coleman, Girls Rock Charleston, and so many more amazing folks!

A shout-out to the following amazing Asheville eateries who are donating food for this year's camp:

Rosetta’s Kitchen, Homegrown, Neo Burrito, Asheville Pizza and Brewing Co.

____________________________________________________________________________

* T H A N K * Y O U * L O V E * G I R L S * R O C K * A S H E V I L L E *

W E B S I T E : http://girlsrockasheville.org/

story:
***Continue scrolling down for the text in Croatian***

 

Did you know that eating disorders are serious psychological disorders with at least 40 000 people suffering from them in the Republic of Croatia?

 

Did you know that around 10% of persons suffering from anorexia die from the consequences connected to the illness?

 

Did you know that anorexia has the highest death rate of all psychological disorders?

 

Persons with eating disorders feel guilt, shame, anger. They feel invisible and isolated. Their voice is not heard. Their problems are not recognised. We at Centre BEA are trying to change that.

 

The story about the Centre for eating disorders BEA

 

Centre BEA is available every day throughout the year to persons suffering from eating disorders and their families. Many sufferers consider Centre BEA as the first step they need to take, and it is the most difficult one.

 

After years of work and experiences in the area of eating disorders, we founded the Centre for eating disorders BEA in 2012 in Zagreb, the Republic of Croatia. Within the scope of our activities, we offer daily support to people suffering from eating disorders and their families, we implement prevention programmes and educate the public via public health projects. Together with experts from Croatia, we have participated in the making of Strategic Guidelines for Improvement of Prevention and Treatment of Eating Disorders in the Republic of Croatia.

 

 

Why did we launch a crowdfunding campaign?

 

During our work so far, we have noticed that the need for our services is unfortunately increasing. Even though it is generally thought that persons with eating disorders are guilty for their problems, it is important to stress out that eating disorders are serious psychological disorders that can leave deep and permanent consequences, both physical and psychological. Therefore, we believe that every person suffering from eating disorders deserves access to timely support and professional help.

We at the Centre BEA make people become visible, make their voice become heard and their problems recognised.

Even though we have been continuously working from 2012, we still lack adequate space in which we would be able to conduct our activities on a daily basis and offer help and support to persons suffering from eating disorders, and their families.

 

How will we spend our funds?

The city of Zagreb provided us with space that needs to be completely adapted and organised for work. In order to achieve our goal we need 20 000 USD and the overall amount of donations will be invested in the construction and decoration of space in which sufferers can continue receiving adequate help and understanding.

Through ongoing activities of the Centre BEA and public lectures, we will continue sharing the awareness about this extremely important social issue that is still not discussed often enough. However, most importantly, we will be available for the people we are here for in the first place – persons suffering from eating disorders.

 

Become the part of our campaign „I am here too. Can you see me?“:

 

- by purchasing perks

- donating any amount (the possibility of anonymous donation – your name and surname will not be published)

- sharing this campaign on social networks

- inviting friends to get involved in the campaign and donate

 

www.centarbea.hr

 

I ja sam tu. Vidiš li me?

Stvorimo zajedno sigurno mjesto za oboljele od anoreksije i bulimije.

Jeste li znali da su poremećaji hranjenja ozbiljni psihički poremećaji od kojih u Hrvatskoj boluje najmanje 40 000 osoba?

Jeste li znali da oko 10% osoba koje boluju od anoreksije umre od posljedica povezanih s bolešću?

Jeste li znali da anoreksija ima najveću stopu smrtnosti od svih psihičkih poremećaja?

Osobe s poremećajem hranjenja osjećaju krivnju, sram, ljutnju. Osjećaju se nevidljivo i izolirano. Njihov glas se ne čuje. Njihovi problemi nisu prepoznati. A mi iz Centra BEA trudimo se to promijeniti.

 

Priča o Centru za poremećaje hranjenja BEA

Centar BEA svakog je dana tijekom cijele godine na raspolaganju osobama s poremećajima hranjenja i njihovim obiteljima. Mnogim oboljelim osobama Centar BEA je prva stepenica koju treba prijeći. Ujedno i ona najteža.

Nakon višegodišnjeg rada i iskustva u području poremećaja hranjenja, 2012. godine osnovali smo Centar za poremećaje hranjenja BEA u Zagrebu, Hrvatska. U sklopu naših aktivnosti svakodnevno pružamo podršku oboljelima od poremećaja hranjenja i njihovim obiteljima, provodimo preventivne programe i educiramo javnost putem javno zdravstvenih projekata. Zajedno sa stručnjacima iz Hrvatske, sudjelovali smo u izradi Strategijskih smjernica za unaprijeđenje prevencije i liječenje poremećaja hranjenja u Hrvatskoj.

 

Zašto smo pokrenuli crowdfunding kampanju?

Tijekom dosadašnjeg rada, primijetili smo kako je potreba za našim radom, nažalost, sve veća. Iako postoji uvriježeno mišljenje kako su osobe s poremećajem hranjenja same krive za svoje poteškoće, važno je istaknuti kako su poremećaji hranjenja ozbiljan psihički poremećaj koji može ostaviti duboke i trajne posljedice, kako fizičke tako i psihičke. Stoga vjerujemo da svaka osoba oboljela od poremećaja hranjenja zaslužuje pristup pravovremenoj podršci i stručnoj pomoći.

Mi u Centru BEA omogućujemo osobama da postanu vidljive, da se njihov glas čuje i da njihovi problemi budu prepoznati.

Iako djelujemo kontinuirano od 2012. godine i dalje nam nedostaje adekvatan prostor gdje bismo svakodnevno provodili svoje aktivnosti i pružali pomoć i podršku osobama koje boluju od poremećaja hranjenja i njihovim obiteljima.

 

Na što ćemo utrošiti sredstva?

Od Grada Zagreba dobili smo prostor kojeg treba u potpunosti adaptirati, prilagoditi i urediti za rad. Za ostvarenje našeg cilja potrebno nam je 20 000 USD, a cjelokupan iznos prikupljenih donacija uložiti ćemo u uređenje i opremanje prostora, u kojemu će oboljele osobe i dalje nailaziti na razumijevanje i adekvatnu pomoć.

Kroz kontinuirane aktivnosti Centra BEA i javna predavanja i dalje ćemo širiti svijest o ovome izrazito ozbiljnom društvenom problemu, a o kojemu se još uvijek premalo govori. No ono što je najvažnije, biti ćemo na raspolaganju onima zbog kojih i postojimo- osobama oboljelim od poremećaja hranjenja.

 

Postanite i vi dio naše kampanje “ I ja sam tu. Vidiš li me?”:

- kupnjom nagrada

- donacijom bilo kojeg iznosa (mogućnost anonimne donacije - vaše ime i prezime neće biti objavljeno)

- dijeljenjem ove kampanje na društvenim mrežama

- pozivanjem svojih prijatelja da se uključe u kampanju i doniraju bilo koji iznos

 

www.centarbea.hr
story_txt:
***Continue scrolling down for the text in Croatian*** Did you know that eating disorders are serious psychological disorders with at least 40 000 people suffering from them in the Republic of Croatia? Did you know that around 10% of persons suffering from anorexia die from the consequences connected to the illness? Did you know that anorexia has the highest death rate of all psychological disorders? Persons with eating disorders feel guilt, shame, anger. They feel invisible and isolated. Their voice is not heard. Their problems are not recognised. We at Centre BEA are trying to change that. 


The story about the Centre for eating disorders BEA Centre BEA is available every day throughout the year to persons suffering from eating disorders and their families. Many sufferers consider Centre BEA as the first step they need to take, and it is the most difficult one. After years of work and experiences in the area of eating disorders, we founded the Centre for eating disorders BEA in 2012 in Zagreb, the Republic of Croatia. Within the scope of our activities, we offer daily support to people suffering from eating disorders and their families, we implement prevention programmes and educate the public via public health projects. Together with experts from Croatia, we have participated in the making of Strategic Guidelines for Improvement of Prevention and Treatment of Eating Disorders in the Republic of Croatia.
 

 
Why did we launch a crowdfunding campaign? During our work so far, we have noticed that the need for our services is unfortunately increasing. Even though it is generally thought that persons with eating disorders are guilty for their problems, it is important to stress out that eating disorders are serious psychological disorders that can leave deep and permanent consequences, both physical and psychological. Therefore, we believe that every person suffering from eating disorders deserves access to timely support and professional help.
We at the Centre BEA make people become visible, make their voice become heard and their problems recognised.
Even though we have been continuously working from 2012, we still lack adequate space in which we would be able to conduct our activities on a daily basis and offer help and support to persons suffering from eating disorders, and their families.
 
How will we spend our funds?
The city of Zagreb provided us with space that needs to be completely adapted and organised for work. In order to achieve our goal we need 20 000 USD and the overall amount of donations will be invested in the construction and decoration of space in which sufferers can continue receiving adequate help and understanding.
Through ongoing activities of the Centre BEA and public lectures, we will continue sharing the awareness about this extremely important social issue that is still not discussed often enough. However, most importantly, we will be available for the people we are here for in the first place – persons suffering from eating disorders.

 
Become the part of our campaign „I am here too. Can you see me?“: - by purchasing perks
- donating any amount (the possibility of anonymous donation – your name and surname will not be published)
- sharing this campaign on social networks
- inviting friends to get involved in the campaign and donate www.centarbea.hr

story:
Features Perks:

 

  

 

What is Girls Town?

Girls Town Kenya Hydroponic Farm will be a for profit, female only, hydroponic farm on the outskirts of Nairobi, Kenya. The farm will offer safety, shelter, and vocational opportunities for the street girls who currently work as community sexual workers in Nairobi. The girls will grow vegetables to sell for market. Girl's Town has already been guaranteed that all produce grown will be purchased.  Your investment is to start the project, the revenue already guaranteed will sustain it. Profits will be reinvested to purchase more land and equipment to expand the farm and save more girls. 

 

Background

Girls Town is being founded by Marianne Stevenson who is President and Founder of AERObridge, a U.S. nonprofit organization which has been working in Kenya for 4 years. AERObridge is a US-based 501(c)3 nonprofit organization which utilizes donated cargo space to efficiently move donations and respond to needs in areas affected by humanitarian crises and disasters. Since 2012, AERObridge has partnered with individuals, orphanages, and schools in Kenya to provide basic necessities and school supplies for children in need. 

It was through one of these partners that the idea for Girls Town Kenya Hydroponic Farm was born. In June 2016, the director of New Horizon Boys Orphanage told Marianne about some girls who were living in the Mathare slum of Nairobi who were not in school and in danger as adolescent females.  Two of the girls had families but could not afford food, much less school.  Searching the slums for food would eventually lead to beatings and rape.  The only safe solution was to find sponsorship for boarding schools. Within months, Marianne secured enough donations to pay for a year’s tuition for the girls. 

One of the girls identified at this same time had no family, Mercy was a street girl. The unspeakable horrors of life as a community sexual worker on the streets of Nairobi had left her virtually unable to operate within the confines of a traditional educational system so boarding school was not an option. Marianne arranged for counseling for her, but eventually it became evident that she needed an alternative to school.  She needed a vocation. 

 

The Project

Girls Town will be that vocation. The Farm will provide an opportunity for Mercy, and others like her, to live and learn in a safe environment. The girls will learn about farming and grow vegetables to sell on the market. The farm will be financially self-sustaining, with profits from the sales going to cover the girls’ wages, ongoing operating costs, and eventually to purchase more land, allowing us to help more girls. 

 

Your Impact

Help us provide this life-changing opportunity to Nairobi’s street girls. Your funds will be used to purchase the infrastructure and provide critical services that will allow these girls to successfully leave the street life behind. View the line item breakdown below to understand what your contribution means to this project.

Capital Expenses:

  • Land: $15,000 per acre X 2 acres = $30,000
  • Housing: $20,000
  • Main building/kitchen: $5000
  • Fence: $1300
  • Latrine: $500
  • Hydroponic system: $4000 per 240 square meters X 4 areas $16,000
  • Reservoir: $1000
  • Well $700
  • Chicken Coop $1000

One Time Start up Costs:

  • Kenyan corporate structure fee: $10,000

  • Attorney fees: $15,000

  • Start up living expenses (mattress, sheets, pillow, blanket, toiletries, box): $60 per child X 50 children = $3000

  • Shared kitchen items: $300

Operational Expenses:

  • Hydroponic nutrients: $1750
  • Seedlings: $1000
  • Chickens: $5 per chicken X 50 chickens = $250
  • Director: $250 per month X 12 months =  $3000
  • Security: $200 per month X 12 months = $3000

  • Electricity: $700/yr

  • Accountant- $1500/yr

Total:  $115,000

 

Our Qualifications

Girl's Town is uniquely positioned to be able to create real and lasting change for these girls who have been abused, exploited, and forgotten.  Marianne has developed relationships and partnerships with entities ranging from government organizations like the US Department of Defense to international organizations such as Clean the World to grassroots organizations like Shumen Orphanage in Kenya. In creating this network, the Girl's Town is able to tap into significant resources to help some of the most vulnerable people in some of the poorest areas of the world. 

In addition to having this diverse network of partners, Marianne created AERObridge with virtually no overhead costs. The organization is 100% volunteer run. Marianne Stevenson, along with four other individuals from the business aviation field, founded the organization in 2005 in response to Hurricane Katrina. She accepted the unpaid position of President & CEO, and since that time she has worked tirelessly to ensure that the organization is ready and able to respond to disasters and humanitarian crises throughout the world.  

Despite having no paid staff, Marianne has facilitated 340,000 pounds of donations (or $6 million worth of donations) within the United States and to eighteen of the poorest countries in the world, including Kenya. This experience within the framework of Kenya’s charitable sector will prove invaluable when establishing this new venture. 

 

The Risks & Challenges

As with any new business, building Girls Town will have challenges.  We’ve included below some of the biggest risks and our carefully considered options. 

Risk: We do not raise enough funds to create Girls Town. 

Response: In addition to crowd funding, Girl's Town is pursuing traditional routes such as grants  and in-person donor requests. By expanding our funding base, we are mitigating the risk that we will not reach our goal. However, if we determine that this is an unattainable goal, the project scope will narrow to include only the aspects we are able to adequately fund. For example, the farm may begin with less land or fewer girls being served. In the case that we are unable to create any part of the farm, Marianne will work with our partners in Kenya to determine the most effective way to use the funds to assist those girls who are still living on the streets. 

Risk: Security of the girls and the farm.

Response: The safety and security of the girls is the primary goal of the Girls Town Farm. We understand that leaving the street life is difficult and potentially dangerous for the girl. The Farm will be surrounded by fencing, and will be open only to those who are authorized to enter.  We will employ a female security team and have guard dogs on property.

Risk: We will have too many/not enough girls to serve.

Response: There are approximate 40,000 girls living on the streets of Kenya. The need is clear. However abuse, coercion, addiction, and fear can make it incredibly difficult to leave this lifestyle behind. Girl's Town will work with our partners on the ground in Kenya to identify girls who are ready and willing to make this transition. The girls will be assessed and spaces will be prioritized based upon the urgency of need and readiness to change. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t donate, you can help us get the word out!  Share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter. Share with people you think may be interested. Check out the Aerobridge website to read about other projects we’re working on and other ways you can help.  Check out our YouTube video about the Girls Town Kenya Hydroponic Farm project. 

If you need more information or questions about Aerobridge or Girls Town Kenya Hydroponic Farm, please email Marianne Stevenson, President & CEO of Aerobridge, at mstevenson@aerobridge.com. 

Thank you for your support!

 

UPDATE: In November, Marianne returned to Kenya (with her 12 year old son) to further the preparations to make Girls Town Hydroponic Farm a reality.

**NOTE** Some people may find parts of this entry upsetting. 

Yesterday was a super busy day! I must say I am incredibly proud of my son, he rolled with everything without a single complaint. 
We started our day by going to one of the roughest slums called Mathare Slum. We were met by one of my colleagues who lives and works with the street children. We got the privilege to meet Mercy, one of young ladies in the video. She was one of the main reasons I became interested in beginning a female only hydroponic farm for street girls. Abandoned at ten by her mother, she had to survive on the streets. When I asked her the worst part of the streets, she said "eating out of the dustbins (trash)". She also commented that she didn't like being alone. Having survived rapes and years of prostitution, those were her thoughts. 

We walked the slums, hopping over squishy mud puddles, sometimes with no way to avoid just stepping in the 3 inch thick mud. We went to where the children sleep, a square area about the size of the park opposite my villa. Only, this area is used for trash, so they sleep on it. As my colleague introduced us to all the children, she introduced us to Faith. She is another street girl. I was told that last month, 4 men raped her. She doesn't want to talk about it, even with my colleague, as she says she is "already healed." The simple fact is that on the streets, it wasn't the first time, and it won't be the last. 

We continued on, creating quite the parade of street children and other children all vying to hold our hands. My son held hands, talked with all the kids and picked his way through the muddy streets without the slightest indication that there was anything alien to him about the world they live in. 

After our walk, we went back to the mission where the priest in charge asked me when the farm would be able to take Mercy, as she cannot stay any longer. He said she was only supposed to stay one night, and it has been a year. She is only part time at the mission and the strain of the situation was clear in the priests voice. Currently in the slums, the locals are putting rat poison in the food and giving it to the street children. One boy woke up to 5 of his friends being dead. The streets are so unsafe for these children. 

We gave out some gifts of toiletries, pillows, stuffed toys and departed to look at land options for Girl's Town. We drove for 2 hours but covered a short distance. Between traffic and bad roads, it took a while to get to the area with land. We looked at housing options and land until evening. We even encountered a 2 year old that would not stop wailing at the sight of 4 white people. He thought the "mazunga" (white person) was there to eat him. I am serious! 

Then after a long day, we went to have dinner which was the first food since breakfast. We were all tired and went back to the hotel to sleep. My son never complained a bit.
