story:
• At any given time there are a half million Americans who are without the safety and comfort of a permanent home.
  • The fallacy of homelessness is that for those who live it, there is or was a choice. The perception is often that homelessness exist as a differentiator of “lazy” people from hard workers.
  •  If the economic collapse of 2008 did anything positive, it proved once and for all that absolutely any human being is susceptible to the perils of homelessness.
  •  Homelessness does not discriminate.
  •  In the changing landscape of technology, manufacturing, ecologically motivated industrial reform, jobs are lost.
  • As the population never stops growing while politics change what kind of healthcare or housing or work we have available to us, there will always be people left out, people unprepared for the change that comes to them
  • While homelessness is a sad fact of human civilization today and may always be, we can never turn a blind eye to the people who fall victim to it.

 

 

 

 

Hosting at least 10% of our current Baltimore City homeless population becomes a win/win for the guest as well as the OOH team, community.

260 people from Baltimore City will inspire others and create per outing the ripples that will touch the hearts of many. Providing showers, toilets and laundry services in a mobile environment not only delivers hygiene but it rekindles dignity and hope for hundreds per site event. With 9,500 showers expected to be delivered every year, the projection would be to increase our availability, increase the number of showers, and support services.

 

 

 

 

This mission is much more than providing hygiene; it’s about eliminating barriers to opportunity and reconnecting people with their dignity. OOH hopes to shatter the illusion of ‘otherness’ that dehumanizes the homeless. We aim to seed hope and rebuild humanity with safe, private showers. This is OOH’s charge.

Of the thousands of showers expected to be delivered,  we anticipate that many are actively working to change their circumstances - seeking employment and housing, pursuing higher education, and working to overcome health-related and substance, alcohol, and mental health issues.  This pilot program’s best practices will serve as an important road map to other areas, including Washington, DC.

 

Every night, there are 3,500 homeless men, women and children in Baltimore City and 11,623 homeless people within the greater Washington DC region. Due to the lack of access to existing shelters.

The Organization of Hope will provide Mobile Hygiene services to the homeless to increase their access.

There are only 13 emergency shelters in Baltimore City and only 7 places in the Washington DC area.

Both venues face this challenged daily, with the number of people to be served and limited capacities to accommodate them The Organization of Hope team will be coming out to deliver the hygiene service.

For the homeless community to shower outside of a shelter. Living and maintaining hygiene, laundry, and sanitation needs due to a lack of access, presents a severe challenge, and reduces the opportunity to embrace an excellent quality of life.

 

 

 

  The Organization of Hope, in collaboration with Baltimore City organizations and government agencies, is committed, along with our Community; Brick, and Mortar, In/Kind partners have directly targeted and will engage the Baltimore homeless community beginning February 1, 2018.

 With the first Baltimore City Mobile Hygiene unit. The unit will be dispatched to a designated site location and will consist of four safe and private stalls and one ADA safe and private stall for toilet and shower utilization for approximately 50-60 guests a day, with one hour allocated to each guest. In addition,  the unit will provide a sink, 2 washers, 2 dryers, and appropriate disposal receptacles.

Our Mobile Hygiene team will effectively embrace Radical Hospitality by providing an experience for our guests that revitalizes and re-humanizes.

 

•  Launch the first Baltimore City Mobile Hygiene unit and complete approximately 50-60 showers a day,  9,500 yearly

•  Collaborate with existing Baltimore City organizations and government agencies to deliver our services where they are needed most

•  Effectively embracing radical hospitality by providing an experience to our guests that revitalizes and re-humanizes.

To provide showers, toilets, and laundry services in a mobile environment to deliver hygiene and rekindle dignity for our homeless citizens.

•  Opportunity unfolds when people are treated with dignity; in turn boosts resilience, which is critical to overcoming adversity.

  • When it comes to dignity, society has different standards for those with resources vs. those who lack them.
  • Delivering an unexpected level of care, to people moving through homelessness restores dignity, rekindles optimism, and fuels a sense of opportunity.

 

 

 

 

We anticipate that many of our homeless population are actively working to change their circumstances by seeking employment and housing, pursuing higher education. Working to overcome health-related, substance abuse, and mental health issues, all these are difficult when the basic hygiene needs are not available.  The Organization of hope will provide those basic hygiene needs.

 

 

 

 

 

Our goal is to create a self-perpetuating model that will drive the OOH project well into the future. Scalability is critical to ensuring the longevity of the program. Year one start-up and operational costs suggest an initial investment of approximately $400,000, with roughly 10% coming from non-government donations.

 

Year 1 expense breakdown:

  • Start-up, truck, and trailer ($144, 000; 34%),
  • Salaries ($203,000; 39%),
  • and operational expenses ($105,000; 27%).

We expect dramatic growth in years two and three as we expand to new locations. Inorganic growth will be driven by grassroots social campaigns. Additional revenue will be generated through mobile advertising, public and corporate donations, and the '$ per shower per day' campaign.

We believe that start-up funding plus reoccurring donation funding will enable the OOH mobile hygiene to run for at least five years and well beyond.

 

 

 

 

OOH/Bridging Hope which is a 501(c)(3) was founded in 2009

to enrich lives and improving communities. 

 

 
 

 

Our strategy is practical as well as dynamic. We believe in a hands-on approach, and offer highly-crafted, evidence-based programs and services to individuals (and animals) in need.

OOH's goal is to re-build communities by making them stronger and more vibrant, and to instill hope in all we serve!

 

 

 

In 2009, Dr. Patricia Williams followed her vision and dream to develop a community service organization dedicated to enriching and improving communities throughout the Greater Washington/Baltimore Metropolitan Area and founded the organization of Hope at the OOH.

Dr. William as the Founder and Managing Director is responsible for the management of the organization’s board relations, corporate affairs, strategic planning, and organizational governance/ culture efforts. The Organization of Hope currently provides a minimum of 12 unique treatment services assisted by a valued diverse team of customer service oriented professionals, corporate sponsors, community partners, and volunteers.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, please contact OOH or follow us at the information below 

Locations
218 East Lexington Street, Suites 600/700
Baltimore, MD 21202

1231Good Hope RD SE, Gallery H
Washington, DC 20020

Mailing Address
PO Box 1466
Temple Hills, MD20748


Phone & Fax:

1.855.9.OOHHOPE (1.855.966.4467)
Office Mobile: 1.443.653.8227/Office Mobile: 1.443.805.8927
 

Email ID:

Info@OrganizationOfHope.Org

OrganizationofHope@gmail.com
 

Follow Us
Facebook/Instagram: Organization Of Hope
Twitter: @orgofhope

 

 

 

 

This pilot program’s best practices will serve as an essential roadmap to other areas including The Washington DC. It is a reasonable fact that there are currently a half million Americans who are without the safety and comfort of a permanent place to call home.

At any given time, life’s interruptions and disruptions could occur. Homelessness does not discriminate, which is precisely the primary reason why we should search our hearts, consolidate our resources, and reach out with compassion to the thousands who need our help.

Together, we can make a positive, measurable impact that will sustain their hope and allow the homeless to begin experiencing the gift of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

 

 

 

Donate, now!  

Not only will you feel showered with the good feelings of helping people in need, but you'll also cash in on some sweet perks! 

You can also: Spread the word!

Share this campaign on:

Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, carrier pigeon - whatever it takes to get the word out.

Post a comment or ask us a question on our campaign page.

story:
Who is Survivor Arts Collective?

Survivor Arts Collective was founded sixteen years ago by Isabella Gitana, a Rape Crisis Counselor Advocate, artist, somatic bodyworker, and survivor who identifes as a queer, working class, Xicana Indigenous human. It is a peer, queer and trans led collective that facilitates support groups and peer-to-peer counseling for all survivors of sexual and relationship violence. We are passionate about working together with our community, offering trauma-informed care, bystander intervention, and transformative justice community education training, as well as our grassroots community mutual aide and care network. Follow us on Instagram @SurvivorArtsCollective

What is mutual aid?

Mutual aid is the idea that “we must cooperate to survive!” (P. Kropotkin) Mutual aid is solidarity with our neighbors rather than charity. Our survival, as survivors of sexual and domestic violence, depends on cooperation of all resources we have available. 

Why do survivors of sexual and domestic violence need our help?

There are many communities that are under-resourced to help the people reflected in the following statistics. Bear in mind that statistics don’t show accurate data because some folks do not feel safe to report to formal systems such as law enforcement and rape crisis centers.
 
• On average, there are 433,648 survivors of sexual violence each year in the United States.
• 1 out of every 6 cis* women has been the victim of attempted or completed rape in her lifetime.
• Cis males ages 18-24 who are college students are approximately 5 times more likely than non-students of the same age to be a victim or sexual violence.
• 1 out of every 33 cis men has been the victim of attempted or completed rape in his lifetime.
• 1 out of every 2 transgender, genderqueer and gender nonconforming folks has been the victim of attempted or completed rape in their lifetime.
• 21% of transgender, genderqueer and gender nonconforming college students have been sexually assaulted, compared to 18% cis females and 4% cis males.
• Native Americans are at the greatest risk of sexual violence and are twice as likely to experience sexual violence in comparison to other races.
• An estimated 86% of all inmates have experienced sexual violence while in prison or jail.
• There is an alarming trend in US domestic violence during the Covid-19 pandemic. Cases have tripled during Covid in comparison to the 1 in 4 cis women, 1 in 10 cis men, and 1 in 2 transgender, genderqueer and gender nonconforming people.

(All statistics provided by JaneDoe.org, Rainn.org, occ.ojp.gov, ncbi.nlm.nih.gov, and NoMore.org) 
*Cis means that a person identifies as the gender with which they were identified at birth.

A breakdown of how the money will be used.

We are asking for $25,000. Here is the breakdown of how this money will be used.

• School bus conversion: $10,000.

We will drive to the under-resourced area in our converted school bus. This will save us expense    of lodging, as well as provide space for material  support for the communities we will be going to. We need the following to get the bus conversion up and running:
          - solar panels, inverter, battery and electrical work $2300
          - flooring $300
          - hot water heater and plumbing $400
          - wood stove, installation and materials $700
          - exhaust fan and installation $200
          - decking on top of bus for storage $1000
          - remove rust, professional paint job on outside of bus $2000
          - refrigerator $400
          - exterior security door $200
          - living wage for person working on bus conversion, miscellaneous expenses

• Mutual aid: $15,000
     Mutual aid money will be an ongoing need. To start, we need at
     least $15,000 to get the program up and running on a national
     level. The mutual aid money will be used for... (see below)

How will Survivor Arts Collective use mutual aid to help survivors?

• We will determine under-resourced communities for survivors of sexual and relationship violence across the United States, as well as locally in Western Massachusetts.
• We will drive to the under-resourced area in our converted school bus. 
• We will build mutual relationships with the communities we are supporting based on trust and the common ground of community care and support of survivors.
• We will treat no one as disposable.
• We will provide support to the survivor community ranging from material support like groceries and clothes, to childcare, housing, emotional support, financial support and aid in navigating resources that are available, including mental health services.
• We will train community members in how to offer bystander intervention trainings as well as how to facilitate a peer-led support group, by survivors for survivors. 
• We will train community members to set up their own mutual aid for survivors of sexual and domestic violence. This will benefit their local community as well as help them to form strong relationships in a network of support for survivors throughout the United States.

What will your support mean to us at Survivor Arts Collective?

We are so grateful for every single donation and every single share. Each dollar is going to help more survivors across the US and here at home in Western Massachusetts. Everything we do at Survivor Arts Collective is through the lens of being survivors ourselves. 

We have seen a need in many communities for more resources for survivors of sexual and domestic violence. Yes, there may be a local food pantry, but do they have transportation to get there, kids in tow? Yes, there may be things like mental health counseling, but is the survivor insured? If not, do they have access to free resources in their community? Are survivors able to join support groups? 

Donations make it possible for Survivor Arts Collective to connect the dots between resources and access to those resources. We can also determine where there are holes in resources and help communities set up their own mutual aids. Our goal is to leave a community of survivors prepared to THRIVE.

story:
In the night; when all is still... that one unknown sound is heard, the sound of one's own reality....

Growing up, the dire human rights situation in Iran was something that made a major impact in my life. When I heard of the massacre of 1988 my main question was, what if?! what if someone, somewhere had heard about the situation and could've stopped this atrocity? Where 30,000 people were executed in a matter of a few weeks. 

Years later I came into contact with the victims of those atrocities, with children, now all in their late 20's who never got the chance to meet or get to know their parents. Children who grew up with the same question in mind.... what if?

In the past two years the execution toll has been on a rise, with nearly 2000 executions since Rouhani took office. 

We decided to put together this book to echo the voice of the voiceless, to actually be that 'someone' 'somewhere' who actually takes a stand and does something to prevent future "what if"s.

After hundreds of hours of work, the book has come together, but now we need help to print it!

our goal is to be able to raise the funds and have the book published by international day against executions, October 10th and to send this book to the office of human rights organizations, UN missions, the media and make it available to all those who care about human lives. 

Because we hope one day, cranes will be used for construction in our homeland instead of being used for destruction of lives.

We need help to raise money for the following,

- Layout, cover design
- Editing & proofing
- Printing

We've all pitched in ourselves but this is what is remaining from the total costs. Our request is for you to help us as much as you can, because every help makes a difference!As my mother would always say “drop by drop we can make an ocean”.

Hand in hand we can make a different....
story_txt:
In the night; when all is still... that one unknown sound is heard, the sound of one's own reality....
Growing up, the dire human rights situation in Iran was something that made a major impact in my life. When I heard of the massacre of 1988 my main question was, what if?! what if someone, somewhere had heard about the situation and could've stopped this atrocity? Where 30,000 people were executed in a matter of a few weeks. 
Years later I came into contact with the victims of those atrocities, with children, now all in their late 20's who never got the chance to meet or get to know their parents. Children who grew up with the same question in mind.... what if?
In the past two years the execution toll has been on a rise, with nearly 2000 executions since Rouhani took office. 
We decided to put together this book to echo the voice of the voiceless, to actually be that 'someone' 'somewhere' who actually takes a stand and does something to prevent future "what if"s.
After hundreds of hours of work, the book has come together, but now we need help to print it!
our goal is to be able to raise the funds and have the book published by international day against executions, October 10th and to send this book to the office of human rights organizations, UN missions, the media and make it available to all those who care about human lives. 
Because we hope one day, cranes will be used for construction in our homeland instead of being used for destruction of lives.

   
We need help to raise money for the following,- Layout, cover design- Editing & proofing- Printing


We've all pitched in ourselves but this is what is remaining from the total costs. Our request is for you to help us as much as you can, because every help makes a difference!As my mother would always say “drop by drop we can make an ocean”.
Hand in hand we can make a different....

story:
What is the EuroStars Tour?

Sixteen European Elite Club players from 10 countries taking on seven of the top US Club teams. This will take place in the last two weeks in July 2017 with planned full coverage from Fulcrum Media and Ulti Photos

Each US Club team win = 1 point for USA and EuroStars win = 1 point for Europe. Maximum of 7 points up for grabs!

Team with most points will be crowned the winner of the Americus Cup 2017.

Why do this?

With all the amazing work we have seen from the All-Star Ultimate Tour, and so many others, we wish to continue this work with a more global feel.

Our mission is to promote gender equity in ultimate through high level women’s games and clinics with key objectives to:

  • INSPIRE women and girls worldwide
  • HIGHLIGHT the widespread female talent found across Europe.
  • PROVIDE dedicated European women the opportunity to play show games with a team deep with talent.
  • SHARE spirit globally, in all it's glorious international flavours.
  • PROMOTE local, showcase playing opportunities for women’s club teams and feature female athletes in collaboration with USA Ultimate.

Who is involved?

The Founder: Rebecca Forth has played international ultimate at the highest level for twenty three years. She has played, captained and coached women’s ultimate in the UK, U.S. and international teams. Her early career exposure to N.Y. players in London framed the possibilities for UK women’s teams before the UK women’s tour existed. Throughout her playing career she has passionately focused on maximising performance and professionalism for all teams she has been involved with and increasing female players’ expectations of themselves. She captained Bliss (UK) and SuperHotPot (international) to 10 victories at Paganello. She captained Iceni and Bliss to many UK National and European titles and managed the GB world games team in 2013. 

“In my first World Championships I was impressed by the gender balance of the sport. All divisions were incredibly supportive of each other it was part of the reason I played. Since then the gender balance has been steadily deteriorating. We hope to help right some of this imbalance with the Americus Cup.”

Our roster is now fully confirmed, go check these amazing players out! We are also very excited to confirm the following games:

New York Bent (2017-07-21)

DC Scandal (2017-07-23)

Boston Brute Squad (2017-07-25)

Settle Riot (2017-07-28)

San Francisco Fury (2017-07-30)

Denver Molly Brown (2017-08-01)

Madison Heist (2017-08-02)

And the full roster of these amazing Women athletes is as follows:

Sarah Ecklund #7 (SWE)

Yannicka Kapellmann #18 (GER)

Annicka Lindqvist #6 (SWE)

Betty Schnedl #0 (AUT)

Ulla Kiili #34 (FIN)

Alisa Tizik #91 (RUS)

Maya Mileck #31 (DEN)

Essi Inkinen #30 (FIN)

Katey Forth #11 (GBR)

Laura Farolfi #1 (ITA)

Fran Scarampi #32 (GBR)

Olivia Hauser #17 (SUI)

Paula Baas #22 (NED)

Nici Prien #2 (GER)

Jackie Verralls #9 (GBR)

Bex Forth #23 (GBR)

We also plan to have some of the great voices of Women's Ultimate commentate on all the games.

What We Need & What You Get

What this campaign is aiming to achieve is to livestream and photograph every one of these games to the highest quality possible. With the help of Fulcrum Media, Ulti Photos and of course you guys we can continue to promote Women's Ultimate on the larger stage!

VISIBILITY MATTERS : inspire to aspire

Thanks to the very generous support from USA Ultimate and the Ultimate Athletes Project we have some initial funding to get things moving and so our first goal is to raise $35,000.

Breakdown

Videographers at reduced rate approx: $15,000

Contribution (approx 35%) of player travel costs: $12,000

Venues: $6,000

Photographers at reduced rate approx: $1,000

Tour Materials (banners, credit card services etc): $1,000

Stretch goals to be announced if/when appropriate

www.eurostarstour.com

story:
On April 25 a massive magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck Nepal, a small country sandwiched between India and China.

Now, only 5 days later, the death toll of this horrific natural disaster has risen beyond 6,000 people.  According to the United Nations, more than 8 million people have been affected by this devastating earthquake; more than one quarter of the country's total population.  

Clinics and hospitals in affected zones are over capacity, and the need for food, water, and shelter is extremely dire.

Join us in helping the people of Nepal in their hour of need.

Your donation will not only provide emergency relief in the forms of food, shelter, and medical care to survivors of this terrible disaster, but it will also help to fund long-term anti-human trafficking operations in Nepal and India.  

In these times of crisis, the necessity for protection of vulnerable young children is at a peak.  The chaos of the disaster zone has made Nepal even more of a prime target for traffickers to kidnap and sell young girls to brothels and private homes in India.

We are working with the Shae Foundation and 3 Angels Nepal, one of the most trusted organizations in the region.  With your help, we will not only be able to provide both emergency relief to earthquake survivors, but also to fund their ongoing anti-human trafficking programs.

                        

The Shae Foundation is a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit, all gifts are tax-deductible.  Receipts are processed and distributed by IndieGoGo and FirstGiving.

story:
We hope to prevent sex-trafficking by providing 1 year of safe housing for young women who have recently aged-out of foster care as they are statistically at the highest risk of being coerced into prostitution.

Consider this... when was the last time you went up to a little girl and asked her what she wanted to be when she grew up, and she replied "a prostitute!"

Never? That's precisely why we created this campaign!

 

How can you help?

First and foremost, even if you are unable to donate, sharing the "She Surrendered" video and this campaign with your friends and family is a HUGE contribution that we are extremely grateful for! By spreading the word with your friends and linking to this campaign as well as using the hashtag #SHIELDANDDEFENDER on your social media posts, you will help us not only raise awareness and successfully fund this project but will literally change the lives and legacies of multiple age-out foster girls!

Copy & Paste this Tweet!

Have you seen @richtidwell's new spoken word video, She Surrendered? I will be her #ShieldAndDefender, will you? - http://bit.ly/1JPXsaL
 

What is our funding goal?

We are enthusiastically endeavoring to raise $50,000 USD in order to prevent sex trafficking by providing one full year of safe housing, utilities, and other expenses absolutely free for 2-5 young women aging-out of foster care.

What if you don't meet your goal OR you exceed it?

We will utilize whatever amount is raised towards housing as many girls as possible and get the ball rolling. If we raise enough for 2 girls to live rent-free for 3 months, we will start there and continue seeking donations to extend and expand our services.

If we exceed our goal, we will provide additional housing in various other cities in Florida, eventually branching throughout the United States.

What kind of Perks are available for donors?

Tons of amazing ones! From T-Shirts to a private video series, you can even have your name engraved on a plaque we will place on the home! Check out the full list below!

 

What do Sex Trafficking, children, & Foster Care have in common?

 

Sex trafficking is a global crisis, existing not only in foreign countries but right here at home in the United States. Men, women, and children of all ages have been victims forced into doing paid sex acts by pimps and traffickers all across the country in both large cities and small rural towns. But what does it all have to do with Foster Care?

A vast number of foster care children in the U.S. enter the so-called “foster care to prostitution pipeline" every year. According to The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, 60% of young people in the business of sex trafficking and prostitution were once in Foster Care. Or in other words, 1 out of 2 sex trafficking & prostitution victims were in Foster Care at some point in their life.

Additionally, 48% of homeless youth between ages 18-23 performed paid sex acts simply because they lacked a safe place to stay according to Covenant House in NYC. Sadly, many of these victims are young girls who were coerced to engage in paid sex acts while still minors within the system, creating prime candidates for pimps and traffickers to lure into the prostitution industry once they aged-out.

When the Department of Children and Families Secretary David Wilkins was asked what the traffickers offer these young women and girls, Wilkins replied “love.” “These guys basically say, ‘I’m here for you. I’m going to be your protector, I’m going to be your support function.’ And sure, they shower ’em with gifts and drugs and parties and limousines…and then the next thing you know, they ask ’em to take the next step, and then they’re caught.”

What is our plan?

Within a single home, we can house 2-5 young women, giving them the opportunity to attend a local college and become self-sufficient; virtually eliminating their risk of being forced into local prostitution.

We will beat the traffickers at their own game and prevent the coercion of these girls by providing them with a loving community and safe housing as well as utilities, groceries, and the various other material needs of young women who have aged-out of foster care. We will be their shield and defender so that they can continue their education, utilize their federal college scholarships, and work towards a productive & rewarding career.
 

What kind of impact will providing housing have on their lives?

A HUGE ONE. According to the Children’s Home Society of Florida, by providing housing to youth aging out of foster care, they are more likely to attend college, graduate or earn a GED, as well as find employment, have fewer mental health challenges, and are less likely to be arrested. Furthermore, those who are given a safe housing arrangement are also less likely to abuse substances, less likely to engage in violent or destructive behaviors, less likely to become parents before they’re ready, are more likely to be financially stable, and are far more likely to become self-sufficient, independent adults.

Most importantly, they will not end up homeless and eventually coerced into prostitution! You will not only be dramatically altering the lives of these young women, but also their children for generations to come!
 

Where will the first home be located?

We will establish the first home in my beautiful hometown of Ormond Beach Florida where the girls will be able to thrive and continue their education in safety. We have selected the city of Ormond Beach for the first home as it will be logistically expedient to be near the girls and secondly we have selected Ormond in order to combat the increased sex trafficking activity in the greater Daytona Beach area. As we grow and exceed our funding goals, we will branch out and establish additional homes in others cities both in Florida and across the United States.
 

Why Florida?

Being a huge tourist state, traffickers provide the supply for the increasing demands of predators on vacation. For example, during the March 2015 Daytona Beach bike week, 43 were arrested in a child sex and prostitution sting named "Operation Predatour".

Additionally, an average of 1,290 children age out of foster care in Florida each year according to the Congressional Coalition on Adoption Institute. Upon the foster child’s 18th birthday the children are given a small amount of money and sent out into society with no housing or employment. As a result, youth between the ages of 18-23 are the fastest growing homeless population in Florida according to the Treasure Coast Homeless Services Council.
 

Overall, homelessness leads to prostitution, drug use, arrests and other life destroying events. Preventing orphan homelessness directly correlates to preventing sex trafficking and will positively change the lives of these young women forever!

 

FAQ

 

Is Shipping Free?

Yes, if you live in the United States, your items will be shipped for free! If you live in another country we will ship to you for an additional fee mentioned in the description of the perk you order.

How do I Select a T-Shirt Size?

Near the end of the campaign we will contact you to request your T-Shirt size.

Are my donations Tax-Deductible?

Yes! The Indiegogo campaign is linked directly to the bank account of Ormond Church. Ormond Church is a not for profit 501(c)(3) automatically tax exempt 508(c)(1)(a) Christian Church operating in Ormond Beach Florida. Rich Tidwell is the Pastor of Ormond Church and is the Chief Financial Officer of this campaign. You may learn more about Ormond Church here: http://ormondchurch.net

Who composed the music in the video?

"Removed" by Danny Klaver - http://bit.ly/1jMpejC

Who recorded the vocals in the video?

Alex Budzilek from Sound Mind Studios - http://bit.ly/1RsgCdg

Who filmed and edited the video?

Rich & Robert Tidwell - http://bit.ly/richtidwellfilms

story:
Who We Are

Our mission is to end human and sex trafficking, one woman at a time. We empower women to transform their lives through the healing power of life in community. Eden House does this by providing a safe home, coordinating recovery services, and through advocacy, outreach, education, and love.


What We Do

Eden House strives to empower survivors to overcome their pasts while developing substantive skills to move forward in their lives and become self-sufficient, flourishing members of our community. To accomplish these goals Eden House offers a two-year residential program to victims, consisting of a holistic approach to recovery that includes:
  • Free room and board
  • Outreach
  • Mental and physical health care
  • Job training and education
  • Legal services
  • Spiritual support
In addition to providing services to our residents, Eden House serves the Greater New Orleans community by providing:
  • Public policy support
  • Advocacy services
  • Education
Our goal is the all-encompassing and full recovery of each resident while preserving and embracing her individuality and dignity. The organization empowers these strong women to overcome their pasts and progress physically, spiritually and emotionally while developing skills to become productive members of society and achieve personal goals. 


What We Need

Many of our residents have never experienced the stability and community of a home; the Eden House residence is central to providing them with stability, and a safe place to call home to fully engage in their recovery. One of the founding principles of Eden House is that full, transformative recovery requires a multi-faceted approach which includes physical, emotional, and spiritual healing.  

After renting our house for four years, we have finally been able to raise more than $300,000  through individual donations, grants, and capital outlay to purchase the home.  Our closing date has been set for April 14, 2016.  At this point, we need only  $37,000 more to reach our goal and are appealing to friends and supporters far and wide to help us raise the remaining funds. 

Owning the residence creates financial sustainability for Eden House, and thus will enable us to more easily devote financial resources towards the goal of personal transformation and recovery of our residents. 

All donations made here will be put directly towards the purchase of the house until we raise the remaining $37,000. Although we have a limited number of perks available, we appreciate any and all monetary donations!


The Impact

Eden House is the only comprehensive recovery home in the Greater New Orleans area for adult female survivors of human trafficking. Since its inception in 2011, Eden House has housed 30 residents, and has assisted over 100 women through direct outreach, services, referrals, and phone consultations.  Our first resident graduated from the 2-year program in April 2015.  Many former residents are now living independently or with their families, putting to good use the skills they acquired during their stay at Eden House.


Other Ways You Can Help

Monetary donations are not the only way you can help!

  • Share our campaign on social media and with your friends, so we can really begin to make some noise about our campaign!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Email us at info@edenhousenola.org to learn about our volunteer opportunities.
  • Household and educational supplies are always in demand. Help us to better do our work by contributing items from our list of needs. 

Thank you!

Spiritual support
In addition to providing services to our residents, Eden House serves the Greater New Orleans community by providing:


Public policy support
Advocacy services
Education
Our goal is the all-encompassing and full recovery of each resident while preserving and embracing her individuality and dignity. The organization empowers these strong women to overcome their pasts and progress physically, spiritually and emotionally while developing skills to become productive members of society and achieve personal goals. 


What We Need
 
Many of our residents have never experienced the stability and community of a home; the Eden House residence is central to providing them with stability, and a safe place to call home to fully engage in their recovery. One of the founding principles of Eden House is that full, transformative recovery requires a multi-faceted approach which includes physical, emotional, and spiritual healing.  
After renting our house for four years, we have finally been able to raise more than $300,000  through individual donations, grants, and capital outlay to purchase the home.  Our closing date has been set for April 14, 2016.  At this point, we need only  $37,000 more to reach our goal and are appealing to friends and supporters far and wide to help us raise the remaining funds. 
Owning the residence creates financial sustainability for Eden House, and thus will enable us to more easily devote financial resources towards the goal of personal transformation and recovery of our residents. 
All donations made here will be put directly towards the purchase of the house until we raise the remaining $37,000. Although we have a limited number of perks available, we appreciate any and all monetary donations!


The Impact Eden House is the only comprehensive recovery home in the Greater New Orleans area for adult female survivors of human trafficking. Since its inception in 2011, Eden House has housed 30 residents, and has assisted over 100 women through direct outreach, services, referrals, and phone consultations.  Our first resident graduated from the 2-year program in April 2015.  Many former residents are now living independently or with their families, putting to good use the skills they acquired during their stay at Eden House.

    


Other Ways You Can Help Monetary donations are not the only way you can help!  Share our campaign on social media and with your friends, so we can really begin to make some noise about our campaign! Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
Email us at info@edenhousenola.org to learn about our volunteer opportunities.
Household and educational supplies are always in demand. Help us to better do our work by contributing items from our list of needs. 
   Thank you!

story:
An Opportunity to Wear Compassion

Zoë Bands are uni-sex bracelets made from the life vests refugees wear on their harrowing journey across the Aegean Sea from Turkey to Lesvos, Greece. 

This venture was created so people could provide refugees with aid while simultaneously spreading compassion in their communities by wearing an intimate piece of the refugee journey.

All profit we generate (each bands costs us about $5 to make) goes directly towards purchasing the food, clothing and medical supplies the refugees so desperately need. 

Our Story

Zoë and I (Xander, co-founder of Zoë Bands) didn't head to Europe on a humanitarian mission. In fact, we originally set out to do nothing more than drink cappuccinos and see some sites in Italy. However, our trip quickly changed as we continued to learn more and more about the refugee crisis. We eventually decided to fly into Lesvos and volunteer.

As we spent time volunteering in clothing tents, forced to turn away those in need due to lack of donations, we decided to create a way for more people to support the victims of this crisis. We needed a solution that would allow funds to funnel towards those who need it AND spread awareness in the western world.

Zoë Bands is our solution. 

You can read more about our journey in creating Zoë Bands here.

The Largest Humanitarian Crisis of Our Time

The fighting in Iraq, Afghanistan and, most notably, Syria has created the largest refugee crisis since World War 2. Among just Syrians, over 4 million have been forced to flee their country in hopes of sparing their lives.

Over a million war victims have decided to make the trek to Europe, with Greek island of Lesvos serving as the primary entry point. In the absence of aid and asylum from the global powers, money-hungry criminal organizations have begun operating dangerous smuggling routes that risk refugee lives while robbing them of their remaining life savings.

These people understand the dangers of this journey and are aware of the uphill battle that awaits them in Europe, and they still come. This lets you know how bad it must be for them back home and how much they need our support. 

We included a short video below of what remains of once-bustling Homs, Syria for a glimpse into the reality they faced before fleeing.

A Thoughtful Process


The effects of the refugee crisis is Lesvos have been devastating. The Greek economy was already in the midst of a severe depression prior to the influx of the victims of war that now come to the island by thousands everyday. In the face of this tragedy, the tourist industry, previously the largest driver of the Lesvos economy, has largely disappeared.

In spite of the economic repercussions, the Greek islanders have responded with amazing kindness, being nominated for a nobel prize for their efforts. In an effort to alleviate tension between the refugees and the Greeks, we've created a process that supports both people.

We Have Boots on the Ground - Two of our four founding members, Taxia Koskina and Vangelis Koutalianos, are Greeks living on Lesvos. It's important to have leadership that is on the ground and can react to rapidly shifting needs.
We Employ Locals - Zoë bands provide much need jobs by being manufactured in Lesvos by locals. Employees are given full time work and paid fair living wages.


We Buy Local - All clothing, food and medical supplies is purchased from local shops and restaurants. We purchase products from many different locations in order to keep many local businesses afloat. By purchasing locally, we are also able to stretch each dollar further by avoiding shipping costs.

We're Restoring the Island's Beauty - For every refugee that arrives, a life vest is left on the shores of Lesvos. By up-cycling the life vests into Zoë Bands, we are helping restore the beaches to their previous beauty.

You Serve the Most Important Role: Spreading Empathy

At the end of the day, this project is about spreading empathy and compassion. We can't do that without you. 

Zoë Bands stand out due to their unique material and bright color. People will ask you about yours. Every time you explain the history behind the band, you will be doing a service to those affected by this crisis. 

You will be an agent of compassion across borders, religions, races and so much more. You will compel people to reflect on one of the earliest lessons we all learn: do unto others as you would have them do unto you. Perhaps you will even compel them to support those in need.

Risks and Challenges

By employing local seamstresses to do our manufacturing, we are able to create beautifully handcrafted products. However, it does not help us scale quickly, so there might be some delay in fulfilling orders if our project is a great success.
Our access to life vests is also not something we have full control over. Right now there is no shortage of vests, but future regulations or government action may dictate our ability to fulfill all orders with bands made from life vests. If we do run into this issue, we will do our best to create and provide you with an alternative band to honor your order.

The Bands

Our flagship orange Zoë Band sells for $20

Our red Zoë Band costs $100. It is only available during this Indiegogo campaign.

The $250 blue Zoë Band

By purchasing a black Zoë Band, you will also be buying a once in a lifetime trip for two to Lesvos. Black bands sell for $10,000 and are exclusive to this Indiegogo campaign.

Spread the Word!

This project, up until now, has been fully funded by Zoë and I. We have no big budget for marketing, so WE ARE RELYING ON YOU TO MAKE THIS A VIRAL SUCCESS.
Please share this project!
Thank you so much for your consideration and support.

story:
Why Am I So Passionate About This project?

In Uganda you can literally be killed because of who you love. Homosexuality is still criminalised, female genital mutilation still tolerated and freedom of speech is severely restricted. People who fall outside of the countries cultural belief structure face life threatening brutality, life imprisonment or death.

As a woman alive at this time in history, I know I can no longer deny the extreme brutality that many of my sisters still live with.

Rising with our Ugandan sisters is a call for all of us to put ourselves in the shoes of these women and to ask ourselves honestly what it truly means be part of this global human family?

 

Who am I?

My name is Jenny Smith and I am a woman living in West Wales working for a Global women’s organisation. Through my work I have come to know and care for a beautiful, extraordinary Ugandan woman called Phionah who has given her life to working tirelessly for human rights.

 

Phionah's story

Two weeks ago Phionah was dismissed from her job because her employer found out that she was supporting a house of seven lesbian women by committing 40% of her wages to ensure their survival. 

One of the seven women who had previously been disowned by her family and her school took her own life that evening and had to be buried in a public cemetery as her family refused her place in the ancestral plot because of their views about her sexuality.

Another of the women was visited by her father who brutally attacked her leaving her hospitalised with severe injuries. Phionah was later prosecuted and imprisoned for supporting lesbian women.

The reason I have offered to raise funds for Phionah and the six remaining women that she supports is purely and simply that it is needed. They have access to no state support in Uganda and in order to protect their lives they need to stay under the radar of the state.

The money from this crowd-funder will create a financial buffer covering rent; food; heating and basic essentials for the next six months creating a window of time during which Phionah and her work can be linked into wider sources of on-going support. 

 

We Are A Global Human Family

Please, lets no longer sit and feel powerless to do anything about the injustices in the world, neither longer look away or towards 'those in power' to do the right thing. Rising in response with our love and offering the resources that we have is what we are able to do. Will you stand with us?

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are inviting contributions to raise a lump sum of £2500 to cover the living costs of Phionah's women for the next six months.

 £10 pays for fuel for a weeks cooking                                                                                                            £25 will buy a decent dress, new shoes and food for a fortnight                                                                 £50 will provide sanitary towels for all six women for six months                                                                 £100 pays for rent, food and heating for a month                                                                                    £500 pays for food, rent fuel and college tuition for three months

Every dollar we raise will go directly to Phionah via the organisation Equality Heals Africa, and every dollar will make a huge difference. Any dollar over our target amount will go towards longer term care of our sisters. Phionah has a dream of supporting them to create business opportunities such as hairdressing or beautician so that they can be self supporting in the future.

We are offering each one of you who contributes to Rising With Our Ugandan Sisters a place in our online Global Meditation Circle of Love Ceremony. This live event will be hosted by Jenny Smith and Sophie Mortimer of TreeSisters and will be a beautiful guided meditative journey energetically weaving our hearts and minds together, collectively raising our consciousness to co-create the beautiful heart-centric world that we all long for and that our survival depends on.

 

The Impact

We want to offer security and stability to an extremely vulnerable group of women in our global family. We also long to create a circle of love around them which energetically supports and protects them from the daily threats of their immediate world.

We want to offer people a chance to make a difference in a very simple way and in a very profound way.

By stepping into this circle you are saying yes to the shift in consciousness that our world is calling out for; you are opening your heart to suffering that may be miles away but that is still on all of our watch; and you are powerfully refusing to collude in hate, in homophobic hatred. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Stepping forward in life always calls for 'vulner-bravery'. It is both an exposing and a courageous act. My deepest wish for this campaign is that is soars far and wide and that we raise way over our target and I know that for that to happen I need many supporters and allies along the way. With my hand on my heart I ask sincerely for all the help that is available to us, both visible and invisible to support the joyful and easeful success of Rising with our Ugandan Sisters

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are several ways in which you can support Rising With Our Ugandan Sisters alongside or instead of contributing financially to our crowdfunder.

* Spreading news of this campaign through your community via email and on social media    * Sending a personal message to Phionah and the six women here on this page
* Linking us to any connections you have in Uganda of individuals or organisations who might be able to offer support longer term to our sisters and all the other LGBT people there.

story:
We are a group of women creating an integrated, diverse farm that serves multiple purposes, including:

• Ecological benefits for rivers, groundwater, soil, habitat creation, wildlife food, insectaries , carbon sink
• Welcoming beautiful food-producing landscapes for our community, including natural playgrounds and hide-outs
• Outdoor teaching and learning space
• Opportunities for participation 
• An abundance of food to share - our fresh vegetables are donated to the Kennett Food Cupboard.

This spring, we got the approval from Kennett Township to move our operation onto public land at Spar Hill Farm. While we have been hard at work, there are many things still missing to turn this first year into a bountiful success.

 

What We Need

To successfully grow an abundance of food and medicinal plants this first season on new land and to integrate an increasing number of volunteers, we need:

$1,500 irrigation supplies

$1,000 project management software

$500 signage

$1,500 tools and other supplies

$1,000 restroom rental

$500 organic pest control, cover crops and organic fertilizers

Total: $6,,000

 

The Impact

Your contribution will make a huge difference in our community. We are serving food-insecure households by directly donating the food we grow to the Kennett Food-Cupboard and Free Food for All. 

With the funds you provide, we will be able to protect our crops from drought, bugs and fungal diseases. This way, our efforts and hard work will come to fruition and will feed many families.

Furthermore, your donation will help us grow a welcoming space and improve our communication both on-site through signage and through online tools. Especially during this pandemic, we need to take care of each others emotional well-being - and participating in a beautiful and abundant community garden can do just that!

story:
Summary

The world needs a lot of love and work right now. Everywhere we turn (or everywhere we look online), there's another crisis: climate change, institutional racism and homophobia, suicide rates and mental health stigma, and the stripping of reproductive rights from women and other uterus owners, to name a few.​

The bright side is that a lot of people care about these crises and want to assist in stomping them out. The problem is that few of us know how to help, aside from talking about it on social media—which is an important part of the process, but also the easiest thing to do and only the beginning. ​

Packtivism was born after founder Adrianna Nine (that's me!) connected these dots and thought of a way to help people along their activist journeys: starter packs that included vital information, materials to write to one's elected officials, and fun yet useful tools to help raise awareness and make a difference in the real world. These packs, assembled to suit individual timely issues, would be affordable and easy to use. ​

The Rainbow Pack, Save the Planet Pack, Mental Health Pack, and Reproductive Rights Pack are the first activist starter packs to join Packtivism's online storefront. As we grow, we'll add more starter packs and exciting add-ons to the shop. 

To get more of a feel for Packtivism, check out our website: www.packtivism.com

What IS an activist starter pack?

Packtivism's activist starter packs are fun and affordable ways to kick off (or enhance!) your activist journey. Whether you've finally taken a women's studies course and want to help protect reproductive rights, or you've been at three protests already this year and wear a "THERE IS NO PLANET B" lapel pin, the stuff in Packtivism's activist starter packs is sure to help you turn your passion into power. 

EVERY Packtivist pack comes with:

  • Stuff you need to know (vital information about that cause)
  • Info on how to engage with that cause (volunteer opportunities, upcoming nationwide protests, etc.)
  • A "what's in your pack" card
  • A rep-writing kit (stationary, envelopes, and a guide card on how to write to your representatives about your cause)
  • A fun sticker related to that cause (Slap it on your laptop, car, or fancy water bottle to help raise awareness!)

The other items vary based on which pack you select. 

Save the Planet Pack:

  • Seed bombs 
  • Reusable straws + cleaning brush
  • Park/beach clean-up kit

Rainbow Pack:

  • Equality (Human Rights Campaign) pin
  • Ally/safe zone sign (Place it at your desk or even your home to let others know you're a safe space)
  • A pride-themed zine made by an author/illustrator from the LGBTQ community

Reproductive Rights Pack:

  • "Women's rights are human rights" tote bag
  • An accessory from Planned Parenthood

Mental Health Pack: 

  • A zine about mental health and coping strategies
  • Lavender-scented stress dough
  • Cards about mental wellbeing and support that you can place around work, your neighborhood, or campus

We also strive to pack our products as sustainably as possible so that individual packing materials can be reused or recycled. 

What Packtivism Needs & What You Get

If there's anything I've learned from working alongside Phoenix and Los Angeles entrepreneurs in my professional life, it's that starting a business takes capital. While some aspects of starting a business are relatively inexpensive, the problem with starting a product-based business is the total cost of sourcing. 

In order to assemble at least 10 of each pack (Rainbow, Save the Planet, Reproductive Rights, and Mental Health) and effectively market the product, Packtivism will need approximately $500 in funding. This covers:

  • Shipping materials (bubble mailers and eco-friendly wrappers for items that need them)
  • Ethically-sourced products (everything from our stickers, designed by passionate artists, to our seed bombs and authentic Human Rights Campaign merch)
  • Social media marketing and web hosting costs

The Impact

Packtivism was founded in order to help more people make a change. By supporting Packtivism, you're making it easier for a wider population to access activist resources and become all the more passionate about their favorite causes. 

Potential Challenges

A challenge that arises when sourcing many products is bulk. In order to achieve the lowest purchase price possible, small business owners are often required to buy sourced products in larger quantities than normal. This makes running the business more affordable in the long run but more expensive upfront. 

That being said, Packtivism strives to source its products in an impactful way from communities who can benefit from it the most. This means seeking low purchase prices while keeping an eye on ethical business practices and each source's monetary end-game.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help isn't only financial! If you can't contribute at this time, we'd love it if you'd share our campaign via Indiegogo's share tools or your own social media channels. Thanks in advance!

Summary
The world needs a lot of love and work right now. Everywhere we turn (or everywhere we look online), there's another crisis: climate change, institutional racism and homophobia, suicide rates and mental health stigma, and the stripping of reproductive rights from women and other uterus owners, to name a few.​
The bright side is that a lot of people care about these crises and want to assist in stomping them out. The problem is that few of us know how to help, aside from talking about it on social media—which is an important part of the process, but also the easiest thing to do and only the beginning. ​
Packtivism was born after founder Adrianna Nine (that's me!) connected these dots and thought of a way to help people along their activist journeys: starter packs that included vital information, materials to write to one's elected officials, and fun yet useful tools to help raise awareness and make a difference in the real world. These packs, assembled to suit individual timely issues, would be affordable and easy to use. ​
The Rainbow Pack, Save the Planet Pack, Mental Health Pack, and Reproductive Rights Pack are the first activist starter packs to join Packtivism's online storefront. As we grow, we'll add more starter packs and exciting add-ons to the shop. 
To get more of a feel for Packtivism, check out our website: www.packtivism.com
What IS an activist starter pack?
Packtivism's activist starter packs are fun and affordable ways to kick off (or enhance!) your activist journey. Whether you've finally taken a women's studies course and want to help protect reproductive rights, or you've been at three protests already this year and wear a "THERE IS NO PLANET B" lapel pin, the stuff in Packtivism's activist starter packs is sure to help you turn your passion into power. 
EVERY Packtivist pack comes with:

Stuff you need to know (vital information about that cause)
Info on how to engage with that cause (volunteer opportunities, upcoming nationwide protests, etc.)
A "what's in your pack" card
A rep-writing kit (stationary, envelopes, and a guide card on how to write to your representatives about your cause)
A fun sticker related to that cause (Slap it on your laptop, car, or fancy water bottle to help raise awareness!)

The other items vary based on which pack you select. 
Save the Planet Pack:

Seed bombs 
Reusable straws + cleaning brush
Park/beach clean-up kit

Rainbow Pack:

Equality (Human Rights Campaign) pin
Ally/safe zone sign (Place it at your desk or even your home to let others know you're a safe space)
A pride-themed zine made by an author/illustrator from the LGBTQ community

Reproductive Rights Pack:

"Women's rights are human rights" tote bag
An accessory from Planned Parenthood

Mental Health Pack: 

A zine about mental health and coping strategies
Lavender-scented stress dough
Cards about mental wellbeing and support that you can place around work, your neighborhood, or campus

We also strive to pack our products as sustainably as possible so that individual packing materials can be reused or recycled. 

What Packtivism Needs & What You Get
If there's anything I've learned from working alongside Phoenix and Los Angeles entrepreneurs in my professional life, it's that starting a business takes capital. While some aspects of starting a business are relatively inexpensive, the problem with starting a product-based business is the total cost of sourcing. 
In order to assemble at least 10 of each pack (Rainbow, Save the Planet, Reproductive Rights, and Mental Health) and effectively market the product, Packtivism will need approximately $500 in funding. This covers:

Shipping materials (bubble mailers and eco-friendly wrappers for items that need them)
Ethically-sourced products (everything from our stickers, designed by passionate artists, to our seed bombs and authentic Human Rights Campaign merch)
Social media marketing and web hosting costs


The Impact
Packtivism was founded in order to help more people make a change. By supporting Packtivism, you're making it easier for a wider population to access activist resources and become all the more passionate about their favorite causes. 

Potential Challenges
A challenge that arises when sourcing many products is bulk. In order to achieve the lowest purchase price possible, small business owners are often required to buy sourced products in larger quantities than normal. This makes running the business more affordable in the long run but more expensive upfront. 
That being said, Packtivism strives to source its products in an impactful way from communities who can benefit from it the most. This means seeking low purchase prices while keeping an eye on ethical business practices and each source's monetary end-game.

Other Ways You Can Help
Help isn't only financial! If you can't contribute at this time, we'd love it if you'd share our campaign via Indiegogo's share tools or your own social media channels. Thanks in advance!

story:
Our Motivation

There is currently no means to ensure the safety of an officer and a motorist during a traffic stop. This is a problem that was made painfully clear through the shootings of Philando Castile and Michael Flamion this past summer.

Unfortunately, these shootings are only the tip of an iceberg. During 2015 alone, over 100 individuals were fatally shot during traffic stops. According to the FBI, between 2000 and 2012, 127 police officers have been killed and 72,413 have been assaulted during traffic stops. Statistics like these help reinforce exactly why routine traffic stops are stressful and sometimes deadly situations for motorists and law enforcement officers alike.

We don’t believe that this status quo is acceptable. That’s what motivated us to develop and build the Sentinel Robotic System.

Sentinel Robotic System 

Features

- 170° HD Camera for 2-way video communication and  incident recording

- Driver's license scanner and digital ticketing capabilities

- Software to automatically populate driver's license information into incident reporting form

- Seven-foot lift can reach some of the highest windows on the road

- High-visibility police lighting

- Semi-autonomous all wheel drive allows easy operation in any weather 

- Sensor array capable of detecting alcohol and THC at the same sensitivity as a police officer - no more, no less

The exoskeleton of this robot was designed using 3D modeling and printed using fused deposition modeling (FDM) - in other words - 3D printing. We also designed this robot to be modular, so that it could be easily modified to meet the needs of each law enforcement agency. This also makes repair turnarounds much faster.

The result is a robotic system that is robust and adaptable and can be produced at a much lower cost compared to conventional fabrication techniques. Below are images of the 3D printers used to create this exoskeleton as well as images of the individual pieces during fabrication.

The robot assembly was completed with simplicity in mind. Most military and law enforcement robotics are complex machines that require expert robotics and mechanics knowledge. We wanted our system to easily maintained in the event of a failure in the field.

Not Just Another Military Police Robot

Just as important as what we choose to include is what we choose to leave off. Here at Trapezium, we do not believe that military robots can be effectively re-purposed for community policing. That's why the Sentinel has been designed from the ground up to serve purely as a law enforcement tool. The Sentinel does not carry any lethal or non-lethal weapons and we promise to keep it that way.

Our Progress So Far

In the seven months we have been working on this we've made tremendous progress towards our dream. From conception to prototype, the Sentinel VX1 has gone through 4 major iterations (earliest to most recent, clockwise from top right).

We designed this robot with feedback from police officers. They continuously provide us with invaluable suggestions about what would be useful in the field and we put their input into each iteration. 

Our Dream and How You Can Help

We began developing this project with the hope that our efforts might be able to save a life. If we can prevent even a single violent encounter from occurring we will feel that the Sentinel has served its purpose.  

We’ve built several prototypes and with each successive iteration have gotten closer to a product that could be deployed in the real world. But we need your help. When we started this project we pooled together our personal funds to build the first prototype. We’ve been fortunate enough to find a small sponsor who shared our vision and were awarded a small grant to help us continue our work, but with this prototype, we’ve reached the limits of what we can personally fund. In order to build the Sentinel that can be deployed to help save lives, we need to raise additional capital.

The $7,500 we are raising will go directly towards building and testing a fully functional prototype with all the features we need to have the impact we would like. If you believe in this as much as we do, we would love to have you along for the ride.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes you just can’t contribute, but if you believe in this as much as we do, there are other ways that you can help!

  • Help share this Indiegogo campaign with your friends and coworkers!
  • Help us get the word out
  • If this is something you would like to see implemented in your community or your police department, reach out and contact us here. Once we build our fully-functional prototype we will reach out to these police departments and invite them to demo our product.

story:
Overview

“Girls are the fastest growing population in the juvenile justice system.'

My name is Liz S Alexander, MA, MSW and I have embarked on a project called She Dreams of Freedom (SDF). SDF is a multimedia collaborative that uses diverse media platforms to raise awareness about the unique challenges experienced by girls in the juvenile justice system. SDF aims to provide education, promote conversation and provoke action among community members, advocates, juvenile justice stakeholders, policy makers and the general public. 

SDF also serves as a platform to empower the voices of girls in the juvenile justice system.


As an advocate for children in the juvenile justice system, SDF project was birthed in response to, what I observe to be, an overall invisibility of the plight of girls in juvenile justice discourse, prevention and intervention initiatives, diversion programs and policy.


SDF seeks to build on the existing work of experts by using innovative strategies through the use of diverse media platforms (i.e print, video and podcast)  to empower girls, to educate the general public about the plight of girls in the juvenile justice system and to push for policy and systemic change.


Objectives

  • To create spaces via diverse media outlets to empower girls to tell their stories and share their experiences in the juvenile justice system through the use of public service announcements, interviews and digital advocacy campaigns.
  • Host community conversations using the media tools in order to promote dialogue and advocacy via forums, panel discussions and community cafe's.
  • To use the outcome of these tools to work with current advocates to continue to advocate for policy and systemic change.

Goal

SDF needs to raise a minimum $10.000 to further our work. 

The money will support the following:

  • Infrastructure for SDF- Given the vulnerability and level of trauma exposure of our population, SDF is intentional about about insuring our work is done from a holistic and trauma informed framework. Your dollars will go towards the continued development and maintenance of that framework. 
  • Programming and support for girls- Using a narrative therapeutic approach, SDF will conduct most of its programming  in a support group format. Your dollars will go towards supporting programming in the areas of  writing, narrative writing, advocacy, media, empowerment and healing.
  • Media content creation- SDF prides itself on working with talented and devoted videographers, producers, and content creators. Your dollars will go towards supporting the SDF media team in the area of purchasing  supplies and the development of media content.

Other Ways You Can Help

1. HIRE She Dreams of Freedom (SDF) 

SDF offers professional development training, workshop facilitation for youth, organizations, institutions of higher learning and corporations. SDF also offers empowerment services for girls.

*Please visit our "Services" page on our website for more information.

2. SHARE YOUR STORY.

Are you a girl who is 25years old and younger who is currently or was formerly involved in the juvenile justice system?

Are you interested in sharing your experience? Are you interested in telling your story?

If yes, we would love to hear from you!

For more information, visit our website at www.shedreamsoffreedom.com

#SEEHER

story:
Dear Friend(s) of Veterans,

My name is Linda Holt.   I am a below-knee amputee and an Army Veteran.  I receive my medical care at the W.G. (Bill) Hefner V.A. Medical Center (VAMC) in Salisbury, NC. I have been accepted to compete in several wheelchair sporting events as a goal in my continued rehabilitation and in my efforts to regain confidence, motivation and both physical and emotional independence.  This will be my first time participating in this awesome event.

I am seeking to raise funds needed for sending myself and other Disabled Veterans, who also receive care at the Salisbury, NC VAMC, to the 35th Annual National Veterans Wheelchair Games where we will be competing in various sports. This year’s National Veterans Wheelchair Games will be held in Dallas, TX from June 21–26, 2015.  This is a National Rehabilitation Event sponsored by the Department of Veteran Affairs (V.A.) and Paralyzed Veterans of America. 

National Rehabilitation Special Events are physical activities, friendly competition, and recreation therapy that engage the mind as well as the body and contribute significantly to an improved quality of life. V.A.'s four national rehabilitation special events provide disabled and elderly veterans with challenging opportunities to accomplish feats many may have believed were no longer available to them because of their disabilities or age. These sports and leisure activities provide our veterans with unique environments for self-development, camaraderie and a well-earned sense of accomplishment. 

I have always been very sports-minded and physically active.  Since my amputation in 2002, it has been very difficult for me to participate in sports or be as active as I had once been.  This has affected my self-esteem and led to my becoming very isolated.  This is often the case with veterans who have undergone physical trauma. The V.A. has been a true lifesaver for me and many of my fellow veterans.  Their programs for physical and emotional rehabilitation are helping me to return to the sports and physical activities that I have missed so much.  The opportunity to attend the National Veterans Wheelchair Games will allow me to participate with other veterans in friendly competition and the training I've been receiving at the V.A. is helping to rebuild my self-confidence and self-image and, I believe, will help me to overcome my self-isolation.

It's a long way from my home in North Carolina to the Wheelchair Games in Dallas, Texas and the expenses for travel and lodging are higher than my small disability pension will allow.  The V.A. is providing me with the specialized sports wheelchair needed to participate in these sports and are paying for half of my hotel room.  I am asking for donations to help with the cost of travel to and from the Wheelchair Games and my portion of the hotel room.  Any and all help is greatly appreciated.

You can read more about the National Veterans Wheelchair Games at http://wheelchairgames.org.  You can also speak with my coaches, Almeta Mallory at (704) 213-2494 or Jane Thomas at (704) 638-9000 ext. 4259.  

if you would prefer to make a donation by check directly to the V.A., please make your check payable to W.G. (Bill) Hefner V.A. Medical Center, and earmark it to the account "General Post Fund #9173-National Veteran Events (C/O Linda J. Holt)." Please mail to W.G. (Bill) Hefner VA Medical Center, Voluntary Services (135), 1601 Brenner Avenue, Salisbury, North Carolina 28144. 

Your donation is tax deductible.

Please, share this fundraiser with others. Indiegogo makes it easy with their share tools!

If you are unable to make a donation but, would like to support my efforts, please send me a message of encouragement.  I would really appreciate it.

Thank you for your thoughtfulness, encouragement and generosity towards our disabled Veterans.

story:
US

Sin Palabras

 Sin Palabras is a multicultural Artist Collective gathered since 2013, dedicated to give theater and art workshops of introspection and self discovery to vulnerable communities in different countries.

This effort offers a non-verbal communication alternative focused on all of those who become silenced by their social environment, in which words are not a means by which they can express themselves. 

We seek results that are tangible evidence of their experiences and that they can be shared to create awareness before the ears that do not want to hear.

​

 Your donation!

Your donation is very important because to create projects of this magnitude, many things are needed, such as materials, food, clothing, and production expenses.

In addition, a very big expenss is for the exposición, and the amount recueste will serve to organize this cultural event, print the fotos, the space, all the logistics to make this exposition great.

We would appreciate your support!

The impact

This kind of projects are worth it not only for the participant, but for us too.

It is a learn to learn. We all know that asking for aylum in other country has a lot of technical and administrative path, sometimes the community stays closed to this situations and don´t have the space to libertad express in different ways their situation.. this is why we try to promote and provoque this project because we KNOW and have SEEN, this makes them forget for a while of their actual status and just enjoy and integrante to society!

 The defeats

In every project there are always altercations, but with the experience that we have been doing these projects in different countries, there is nothing that can not be solved. It is very important that people who want to donate to this project know that we have done others and we have had very good results, so we invite them to participate, since we are the brave ones who put many things behind to achieve these projects that are Impotant for the population that has been displaced without planning it or wanting it.

 

IT is time for YOU to play! 

 

THANK YOU

story:
Thank you for taking the time to drop by!

My Name is Rachel and I have decided to go on a mission before Christmas. I want to raise as much money as possible as the winter months start to draw in to help the homeless. The money will go towards accommodation/food/clothing and YOU will have the chance to see all this unfold as you come with us on our journey to 'Spreading Warmth'

My Goal is £1,500 but regardless of that target being met, the project will still go ahead.

We will keep you updated on our progress and then document it on YouTube for you to see exactly where your money has been going and the difference it has made.

Thank You guys!!! Let's spread the warmth and love this Christmas.


2 donated blankets from King Of Cotton (21/9/15)and a total of £50 raised to buy supplies to date! A massive Thank You :)
