story_txt:
NOTE: since we fell far short of the intended project funding goal in the first attempt on IndieGogo, the campaign has been re-launched under this new project URL.  Thank you to those who came thru early!  We appreciate your support!Intro
Sometimes, it takes an outsider to state the obvious.  This project is about a book & a movement.  The book is nearly finished except for a data-intensive synthesis that will illustrate the social history of the United States in beautiful visualizations that allow readers to learn and understand intuitively without important meanings being lost, buried deep in hundreds of pages of endless prose.  The movement, like the book, is nearly complete as well, except it is currently in a state of deep hibernation.  This is not my project; the project belongs to Americans, past, present and future.I cordially invite you as a teammate in this endeavor if you can make one or more of the following statements:

I love my country, but I don’t necessarily agree with everything that my country has done or is now doing;
Voicing my views, based upon well-informed perspectives rather than on unfounded opinion or baseless ideas is one of the highest expressions of patriotism;
I possess the intellectual curiosity to pursue the truth, the courage and maturity to confront it and all that its implications entail, and the intrepid and unwavering conviction to follow it;
Negativity thwarts progress, scapegoating deflects accountability, interpersonal disagreement does not necessitate interpersonal incivility or hostility;
Talking alone has never changed the world so either be about it, or kindly shut your mouth! 



The word from the draft manuscript gives a good visual for what is going into the book:

Mission

After history had been made in the election of the country’s first Black president, the New York Times reported “Racial barrier falls in decisive victory,” but is that statement really true?  Did a barrier come down, or are we looking at an anomaly?  Here we are in the year 2015, exactly 150 years after the Thirteenth Amendment was ratified by the necessary three-fourths of states. The Amendment was intended to “obliterate the last lingering vestiges of the slave system” which provides the phrase I currently favor as the title of the book.  On March 28, 1864, Senator Henry Wilson of Massachusetts delivered a long oration in the 1st session of the 38th Congress:
"Sir, slavery in America, though upheld by interests, customs, and usages, trenched about by inhuman statutes, and hedged around by passionate, vehement, and unreasoning prejudices, is fast crumbling into atoms beneath the blows rained upon it by a liberty-loving and patriotic people.  But let anti-slavery men listen to no truce, to no cry for mercy.  Let them now be as inflexible as justice, as inexorable as destiny…
If this amendment shall be incorporated by the will of the nation into the Constitution of the United States, it will obliterate the last lingering vestiges of the slave system; its chattelizing, degrading, and bloody codes; its dark, malignant, barbarizing spirit; all it was and is, everything connected with it or pertaining to it, from the face of the nation it has scarred with moral desolation, from the bosom of the country it has reddened with the blood and strewn with the graves of patriotism."
Interpreted in the most literal manner, the powers given by the Declaration of Independence and fully embodied in Constitution of the United States, there would be no need for appending articles to assign privileges that were previously deemed as “unalienable rights.” Since chattel slavery was a pre-existing condition at the time of drafting the Declaration of Independence, however, the very presence of slavery as an instrument of the national economy and badge of American culture made it necessary for either an act of Congress or executive order of the President to remove it.  Both occurred, however laws are not sufficient to change culture as they cannot regulate what persists in the hearts and minds of human beings. 
In 1968, after having been ruled in favor of an oppressive defendant seeking to deny an interracial couple the right to purchase a home in a new subdevelopment, upheld by the appellate, in a case finally reached the US Supreme Court.  In the ruling which was reversed in favor of the Black plaintiff, Justice Potter Stewart mentioned the following in his landmark opinion:
"Just as the Black Codes, enacted after the Civil War to restrict the free exercise of those rights, were substitutes for the slave system, so the exclusion of Negroes from white communities became a substitute for the Black Codes. And when racial discrimination herds men into ghettos and makes their ability to buy property turn on the color of their skin, then it too is a relic of slavery. Negro citizens, North and South, who saw in the Thirteenth Amendment a promise of freedom -- freedom to "go and come at pleasure" and to "buy and sell when they please" -- would be left with "a mere paper guarantee" if Congress were powerless to assure that a dollar in the hands of a Negro will purchase the same thing as a dollar in the hands of a white man. At the very least, the freedom that Congress is empowered to secure under the Thirteenth Amendment includes the freedom to buy whatever a white man can buy, the right to live wherever a white man can live. If Congress cannot say that being a free man means at least this much, then the Thirteenth Amendment made a promise the Nation cannot keep. "

Why This? Why Now?
Information that is not used to produce benefit is nothing more than data.  When we apply that information in intelligent and useful manners, then we transform data into knowledge. One core theme for this project is that our society has plenty of informational resources available, yet tragically, our knowledge is inadequately low.  We complain incessantly via social and traditional media, yet rather than taking proactive steps to change or improve the world we live in, we tend to passively listen, view, or otherwise consume incomplete and often erroneous data, sometimes in as small a dose as 140 characters at a time.  Has anything truly monumental ever been accomplished with such superficial techniques?  I am an advocate for technology and as an operations consultant, I have achieved proficiency in more applications than most people will ever use in their entire lifetimes, but none of the technology-enabled activities we have at our disposal today will make a positive impact on our world if we do not first open our minds and our hearts in order to enlighten ourselves as we transform and transcend all that ails us at present.
The information we just mentioned comes from many sources.  There have been thousands of new doctorate degrees awarded since the 1960s in fields such as economics, sociology, history, education, and so many more, but what has the net social impact been? There are nearly one million non-profit organizations registered with the Internal Revenue Service under sub-chapter 501(c)(3), all claiming to have an altruistic mission.  Philanthropists give, foundations spend, corporations donate, and a massive effort from seemingly credible institutions spends hundreds of millions of dollars on marketing and advertising each year to make you and I feel good about ourselves and our financial contributions to “worthwhile” causes. 
Beyond the “feel good” photo opportunities of celebrities and athletes posing with inner city children, despite the apparent “success” of the giving campaigns in your workplace, diseases continue to be manufactured at a higher rate than the drugs themselves (quite convenient for pharmaceutical companies, I know), cancers of every strain continue to adapt, millions of defenseless children are living in unhygienic environments or altogether homeless, and the sad indicators could fill more pages than anybody would have time to read.  And, if you happen to be Black, by nearly every meaningful metric imaginable, the living circumstances of the average African-American—especially younger males—has deteriorated to an alarming extent. 
Lectures at colleges and universities, blogging, etc has failed to move the collective needle of the Black male’s socio-economic status. I am not blaming others for what they have not yet accomplished; rather, I am commending them by leading this initiative to leverage their contributions, synthesize their research, and stand on their shoulders to flip on the switch that has been dark since our nation began.  I have always been amused by historians who refer to the “good old days” nostalgically.  If, like me, you are the descendant of an African slave in America, please remind me when those days occurred, because I cannot seem to remember.  Was it the day when we walked off the plantation, fearing for our lives, pockets and stomachs empty, feet bare, bones and muscles aching, probably incapable of reading a sign on the road and without any practical experience to assist us in navigating our journey to this allegedly wonderful place known as freedom?  Was it when you saw your relative or friend dragged off by a screaming mob to be brutally tarred and feathered or even lynched in a tree—two barbaric acts that even the cruelest humans alive would not likely inflict upon the lowest beast God ever created? 
Was it the day when your relatives or ancestors were sent off to war and deployed in the riskiest tours to be killed at twice the rate of others?  Was it when it seemed like every time you turned your head, another young Black leader was being gunned down in front of his family or friends?  These are questions which we need to stop asking, because in order to heal the wounds—and the wounds are as deep as they are—we need to have the resolve to revise our entire approach to the world as we know it.  We need to shed old paradigms and recognize once and for all that what our predecessors attempted was limited to their generation and their resource constraints, and now we live in a time period where we have the tremendous advantage of hindsight, yet we lack understanding and knowledge. 
At the outset, it is worth clarifying that most people misuse the word ‘equality’ as it refers to race relations.  What the Declaration of Independence and Constitution discuss is equality of opportunity, not equality in all regards.  As a simple illustration, imagine a bag containing marbles of assorted colors. Despite its color, each marble is composed of the same material, has identical weight and is the exact same as all other marbles with regard to other observable physical properties. We learned basic probability in middle school mathematics such that if there are 50 red marbles in the bag and also 50 blue, then we would be surprised to find that after one thousand random trial observations (with replacement), we pulled 750 blue marbles and only 250 red. 

Why does this outcome shock us?  Because we are smart enough to realize that with the same constituent contents, the probability of drawing a red marble is identical to that of drawing a blue marble, exactly 50%.  Anytime we find a pattern of observations that deviates from the expected value, we must conclude that there is something else causing the discrepancy. 
How does our remedial math lesson relate to the Thirteenth Amendment, over which President Abraham Lincoln would lose his life?
Dean of the School of Law at University of Pittsburgh, Michael Carter, Jr offers us a glimpse of the inherent complexity of Article XIII itself based on the cultural environment in which it was hatched.
Carter states “On the whole, however, the Amendment remains under-enforced in comparison to the broad scope the contemplated in its legislative history, the ideology of its drafters, and the historical circumstances in which it was adopted.”
This book uses research contributions from historians, sociologists, economists, legal theorists, psychologists and other notable thinkers, integrates their contributions and in so doing, answers the questions about what went wrong with regard to incomplete implementation of the Thirteenth Amendment.  Most importantly, it paints a picture of what needs to occur, and unlike other books or approaches, places emphasis on the necessary cultural shift that can only be achieved through Americans—representing the diversity and patriotic pluralismthat makes our nation great—increasing their awareness and sensitivity to subtle, often unnoticed or even unconscious factors that while unseen strongly influence the way our society functions.
Ingroups and Outgroups

We have a tendency to only pay attention to things that we believe will benefit us personally.  Although that statement does not appear to be overly controversial, it becomes a challenge for us as a society of overly-individualistic humans who refuse to come to agreement on what resources and means need to be shared—and to what extent—in order for us to sustainably co-exist within a complex network of organic communities, polities, and geographies.  We vary with regard to language, tradition, culture, political orientation, and even in superficial terms of physical attributes like skin color. When we deal with others as we would like to be dealt with, those variations could be a source for greater human understanding as the Quran describes:
"O mankind! We have created you from a single male and a female, and made you into various nations and tribes that you may become better acquainted with one another. Verily, the most honorable of you in the sight of Almighty God are those who have the most piety. Verily, Almighty God is All-Knowing, All-Aware. [Chapter 49, Verse 13]"
On the other hand, when we emphasize the dissimilarity of others, it can easily develop into dangerous interpersonal antagonism, which leads to ingroup bias.  Alfred Adler, one of the most under-appreciated thinkers, physicians, psychologists of the prior century, eloquently articulated the antecedents of ingroup bias.  The more familiar manifestation of ‘ingroup’ in vernacular can be spotted in our usage of the plural pronouns ‘we’ or ‘us.’ 
Adler tells us how the ‘us’ typically develops:
"In our present-day culture, people are still easily misled to isolate themselves, and to separate themselves into nations, creeds, and classes.  In all manners of isolation the familiar traits of ambition and vanity take the particular form of contrasting oneself with the others and of proving, by withdrawing from them, that one is different...Those who have traveled have found people everywhere are approximately the same in that they are always inclined to find something by which to degrade others. Everyone seeks a means which permits him to elevate himselfat little cost." ~ (Adler, 1927)
Just as one cannot truly know ease without having known hardship, we cannot understand ingroups without also seeking to understand outgroups as well. In order to have an ‘us’ there must exist a target reference group that we refer to as ‘them.’
Below, Adler explains how the ‘them’ can come about:
"Difficulties in earning a livelihood, bad working conditions, inadequate educational and cultural facilities, a joyless existence, and continuous irritation, all these factors increase the feeling of inferiority, produce oversensitivity, and drive the individual to seek "solutions." To an individual in this state of mind, any outside interference appears as a threat to his security and rouses him to active or passive self-defense. Motives of hatred appear most clearly in economic disturbances of our time. . . . Destruction means to the masses a release from situations felt intolerable and thus appears to them as a preliminary condition of improvement. " ~ (Adler, 1925)
Now that we understand these basic concepts, I want to direct our attention to their significance within this book and the broader project’s context.  For Blacks to be discriminated against, there must be a relatively more powerful ingroup who targets Blacks as the outgroup.  Until now, most of the “resistance” to such discrimination, at least as articulated by those who have been anointed as Black leaders in the past, has focused on the blackness of ‘us’ versus the oppressivewhiteness of ‘them.’ This dichotomy of thought—indeed of the more general worldview—plays an instrumental part towards explaining why racial disparity was created and why it has persisted. 
Last Lingering Vestiges: For those skeptics who say that the Civil Rights legislation “leveled the playing field,” we ask you to open your eyes and reconsider. #vestiges2015
In the US context, Adler was not the only pioneer of psychology and sociology to address racial tension and disparity.  Kurt Lewin and Gordon Allport, who we’ll mention more later also made deeply insightful observations, which unfortunately have not been leveraged to the benefit of American society as of yet. This book seeks to change that.  In the height of what we now look back on as the Civil Rights Era in the United States, a massive undertaking to investigate the roots of race tension was launched by executive order of President Lyndon B. Johnson. 
While it is not possible to discuss the results from the Kerner Commission Report in detail, but a soon-to-be written update will provide highlights.  I mention the Kerner Report here, to illustrate how regrettable it was to have conducted a study of that magnitude and significance without having utilized the powerful minds of Adler, Lewin or Allport, none of whom are mentioned within nearly 600 pages of detailed findings, summary and appendixes.  Adler and Lewin had long since passed, and Allport died in 1967, the same year the report was issued, but their writings were obviously available.  If society doesn’t benefit from those whom possess the most knowledge about specific issues of great relevance to the society itself, then it is no wonder we find ourselves moving backwards towards darkness rather than advancing toward the light.  Not even Abraham Maslow, whose insights were sought by Civil Rights’ activists repeatedly in order to help understand the social impact of discrimination, was listed among the hundreds of special advisor or consultants to the Kerner Commission.

Two of the more compelling statements from the Kerner Report’s executive summary published in 1967 should sober our minds enough to understand the relevance to this project and to our nation’s history:
"Our nation is moving toward two societies, one black, one white-- separate andunequal. Reaction to last summer's disorders has quickened the movement and deepened the division...Discrimination and segregation have long permeated much of American life; they now threaten the future of every American. This deepening racial division is not inevitable. The movement apart can be reversed. "
A third and final statement for this discussion highlights how the fact that the Kerner panel of experts—comprised of major city police chiefs, sociologists, legal theorists, retired judges, political activists, industry executives and economists, among others, happened to omit the human dimension that only an understanding of the mind (i.e. psychology)—is nothing less than a travesty:
"This alternative will require a commitment to national action  --compassionate, massive and sustained, backed by the resources of the most powerful and the richest nation on this earth. From every American it will require new attitudes, new understanding, and, above all, new will."
If it is not obvious already, the only way the three concluding elements—attitudes, understanding, and will—can be changed is through acquiring a better and more functional understanding of psychology.  Furthermore, and perhaps most importantly, fulfilling the promise of the Thirteenth Amendment by obliterating the last lingering vestiges is not a concern of just African-Americans, it is the moral obligation of all Americans!
Last Lingering Vestiges: For those skeptics who say that the Civil Rights legislation “leveled the playing field,” we ask you to open your eyes and reconsider. #vestiges2015
Not Ancient History
If you ask any serious scholar of American history who they consider the most influential, perhaps even most important historical figure to the founding ideology of the United States, and you might hear different responses, but without any doubt, a near majority will likely mention Thomas Jefferson, and even those who do not mention his name first will almost certainly mention him among the top three most influential Americans of his day, perhaps of all-time.
As a history major and even as a young fan of history, I do not recall ever studying the more controversial statements Jefferson made which helped to define the nature of race relations in this country from its earliest origins, and continue to shape our attitudes today.  Not only did Jefferson elaborate on the social pressures exacerbated by tensions between Whites and Blacks, but he also exposed the hypocrisy buried deep within the very foundation of this nation.  While some historians have attacked Jefferson on account of his slave ownership, insulting remarks alleging biological and genetic inferiority of Blacks, I use Jefferson in this book for a much more instrumental purpose.  Because Jefferson is of central importance to this nation’s philosophical and ideological orientation, more than George Washington as hero, or as Alexander Hamilton as a defender of the republic, Jefferson symbolizes the quintessential point of departure for what has occurred in our society since its political birth in 1776.  Africans were known to have set foot in what is now the Mid-Atlantic region in the 16th century, and African slaves are known to have been forcibly trafficked into colonial Virginia in 1619.  Yet more than these earlier historical milestones Jefferson’s life, from 1743 to 1826 is a symbol.  His writings, more than his actions, established the longstanding patronizing attitudes that Blacks could only survive under the White man’s care and supervision.  Jefferson’s writings also foretold of the explosive conditions that would emerge in the aftermath of the slave system..  In an 1820 letter written to John Holmesone of the chief architects of the Missouri Compromise which admitted Maine to the union as a free state while accepting Missouri’s union entry as a slave state, Jefferson wrote:
"I can say, with conscious truth, that there is not a man on earth who would sacrifice more than I would to relieve us from this heavy reproach, in any practicable way. The cession of that kind of property, for so it is misnamed, is a bagatelle which would not cost me a second thought, if, in that way, a general emancipation and expatriation could be effected; and gradually, and with due sacrifices, I think it might be. But as it is, we have the wolf by the ear, and we can neither hold him, nor safely let him go. Justice is in one scale, and self-preservation in the other."

Interestingly enough, while some historians point to this letter written by the then 77-year old Jefferson as the first documented usage of the phrase “wolf by the ears” to refer to Black slaves, recent scholars have shown Jefferson to have used the phrase numerous times throughout his life in various contexts and situations.  We thus see Thomas Jefferson, the third President of the United States, author of the Declaration of Independence, foretelling of the same two conditional outcomes soberly articulated in the Kerner Report to be released 147 years in the future. 
Last Lingering Vestiges: For those skeptics who say that the slavery discussion bears no relevance on current racial issues, we ask you to open your eyes and reconsider. #vestiges2015
Snapshot of Society
Before providing brief examples of some of the content the book will explore in greater detail, I want to respond to the common attitudes towards change of any significant scale.  To the one who might say, “this has been done before, and it failed, and if it hasn’t been attempted, the reason must be that it’s impossible.”  Self-defeating personalities cannot be convinced to express concern about anything that does not impact them directly, and even then they do not necessarily respond in the manner that logic would dictate.
If the above illogic is true, then we should also hold as truth that inertia of any type is insurmountable, and in the racial predicament we would then face one of two inevitable outcomes:
1)  Racial tension continue to escalate until another civil war breaks out, or
2)  Racial tension will subside and be replaced by mutual understanding
Of those two options, which one is more palatable?  Which one seems more likely to occur? If your answer to these two questions differs, then you are restricted by cognitive dissonance and other information processing biases that will limit your ability to understand how your own choice—let’s refer to it as agency—ultimately impacts your outcome.  If you expect a poor result, then at the unconscious level, you will not commit the effort to achieve anything other than the poor result you expect.  We must acknowledge how serious this topic is. 
Everyday, people are dying for no reason whatsoever while we argue, bicker, whine and so forth over matters which can in no way produce resolution.  This is not a mandate for Black Americans, it is a mandate for all Americans.  The world has always been watching, and just like our foreign counterparts admired what they thought was a sincere pledge for freedom in 1776 and again in 1787, they scoffed in utter disbelief and disgust when they came to realize that the American Dilemma had never been addressed with a suitable degree of effort or competence.  As we saw in the Kerner Commission Report earlier, 48 years ago, President Johnson tagged poverty reduction and resolving America’s lingering race crisis as a top priority for his administration.  The issue is no less important today, but for reasons that the book will detail, we have assigned little more than lip service to the quest for a solution.
Justice System
The simple fact that the United States leads the world in terms of the portion of the overall population living behind bars.  This is not just with regard to Black men, but true of every sub-population:  White Men, White Women, Hispanic Men, Hispanic Women, and most certainly, Black Men and Black Women as well.  In fact, while the United States’ general population comprises just 5% of the world’s total population, the United States’ prison population constitutes 25% of the world’s prison population.

While the book being produced synthesizes the empirical research from hundreds of studies on various facets of the American (in)justice system, one quote is sufficient to focus the reader’s attention on the significance of this human rights crisis:
"African Americans are 14% of the U.S. population, yet they constitute 28% of arrests, 40% of inmates held in prisons and jails, and 42% of the population on death row. Hispanics and Native Americans are also alarmingly overrepresented in the criminal justice system. This overrepresentation of people of color in the nation’s criminal justice system, also referred to as Disproportionate Minority Contact (DMC), is a serious issue in our society."
~ [Overview of substance use disorders and incarceration of African-American Males. Venkata Mukku, et al,  2012]
Last Lingering Vestiges: For those skeptics who say that the slavery discussion bears no relevance on current racial issues, we ask you to open your eyes and reconsider. #vestiges2015
Economy & Work Environment
Linking the impact of incarceration to the society at-large, Rutgers University Associate Professor of Political Science, Lisa Miller, writes:
"One of the most common scholarly explanations for persistent racial inequities in crime, punishment, and criminal justice is that they represent a continuation of thelong history of exclusionary practices in the United States beginning with slavery; continuing through the Jim Crow South, white flight, and race riots in northern ghettos; and culminating most recently in the prison state. Analysis of congressional drug policy, for example, illustrates how race and ethnic imagery have long been smuggled into drug policy debates and can be seen in contemporary discourse about crack cocaine and inner-city blacks."
~ [The Invisible Black Victim: How American Federalism Perpetuates Racial Inequality in Criminal Justice]
Chronic discrimination persists in all facets of the economy.  Significant Black-Other, not always Black-White gaps exist in home ownership, financial assets (i.e. stocks, bonds, commodities, etc), life insurance, personal savings, access to credit, and the list goes on.  A good example of a modern disparity between Blacks and Non-Whites can be seen between Blacks-Asians in home ownership and wealth, and a historical example of Black-Black disparity can be found between Southern Blacks in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and Blacks within Native American populations such as Cherokee Freedmen.  In her paper, The One Thing Needful: Land and Black Mobility, Melinda C. Miller describes,
"For income, the difference in the racial gap was estimated between 27% and 43%. By 1900, 90.23% of adults in Cherokee freedmen farming households owned their homes; only 28.34% of farming southern blacks households did. All black adults in the Cherokee Nation were much more likely to live in an owned rather than rented house (84% vs. 24%)."
A majority of the time, the impact appears in subtle and nuanced ways, yet it pervades both public and private sectors, all industries, all regions, and all firm sizes from small local businesses to multi-billion dollar titans in the Fortune 500.  We see a very broad-based pyramid across the board where the proportion of Blacks entering many industries, professions or job families is much closer to the proportion of Blacks in the nation, roughly 14% (13.6% according to the 2010 Census, based on approximately 42 million of Americans, 92.6% of whom declared themselves to be Black or African-American alone, as opposed to declaring mixed racial heritage). 
As we head upward from the base of the pyramid, however, a complex myriad of factors and divergent variables offer unsatisfactory explanations—sometimes justification—for statistical anomalies which cannot be refuted by anybody known to be sane and honest.  We see far fewer Blacks in supervisory, managerial and director level positions.  At present, there are more first generation immigrants leading Fortune 500 as CEOs than there are (or have ever been) Blacks leading those same companies.  Pick an industry or a profession, and the story is the same.  Blacks represent 8% of new hires at CPA firms, but less than 1% of partners at those very same firms.  In law firms, a similar finding is true.  Let’s not even mention the executive teams at the largest private equity firms in the United States.  Google them and click through the bio profiles if you need to be convinced.  Remember our blue & red marble discussion from earlier, if over an extended set of observations, the results do not conform to our expected probability distribution, then there is at least one reason explaining why.  Let’s be candid and acknowledge that whether it is due more to choices Blacks make or to a work environment seen as harmful, at some stage nearly every aspiring Black manager steps on a landmine or trapdoor.  The message here is not to tread more carefully; rather the message is that the trapdoors need to be sealed permanently.
The brilliant thinker, psychologist, sociologist, and founder of the Research Center on Group Dynamics at MIT (later moved to University of Michigan)—Kurt Lewin articulated the obstacles to culture change perhaps better than anybody before him, and although he died in 1947, his statements bear great relevance to modern times:
There is no question but that the culture of individuals or small groups can be deeply changed in a relatively short time. A child transplanted from Germany or Japan to America will, as a rule, become thoroughly Americanized. Even grown-ups who are transplanted to a different culture may acquire a new culture to a high degree, and much can be done toward this end through proper education. Experiments with both children and adults prove that the social atmosphere of groups can be changed profoundly by introducing different forms of leadership. Experiments in leadership training have shown that it is even possible under certain circumstances to transform highly autocratic leaders of long-standing within a short time and efficient credit leaders.  ~ (Lewin, 1943)
What is evident from Lewin’s words above is echoed in contemporary research as well, such as the following praise from Manchester University Professor of Management, Bernard Burnes:
Nor can one say that Lewin’s approach seems dated, based as it is on building understanding, generating learning, gaining new insights, and identifying and testing (and retesting) solutions. Certainly, there seems little evidence that one can achieve peace, reconciliation, co-operation or trust by force. Likewise, in organizations, issues of group effectiveness, behaviour and change have not diminished in the half century since Lewin’s death, though they may often now be labelled differently.
Last Lingering Vestiges: For those skeptics who say that the slavery discussion bears no relevance on current racial issues, we ask you to open your eyes and reconsider. #vestiges2015
Healthcare
Discussing the disparity in healthcare between Blacks and others in the United States, whether we focus on the Black-White, Black-Hispanic, Black-Asian or Black-Other gaps in such varied categories as general mortality, hospitalization, epidemiology, or others, this topic alone could fill volumes of books, and indeed it has. 
For our discussion here, I simply want to point to one major aspect of racial disparity, namely the Black-White gap in avoidable mortality (AM).  AM represents causes of death that are not normally expected to occur in countries/regions with available, high-quality healthcare and timely treatment alternatives.  New York University’s James Macinko and the University of Pennsylvania’s Irma Elo studied the Black-White AM gap in a 2009 research paper and the results should alarm all Americans, regardless of race.  The United States—in general—had a higher AM rate than all other OECD nations during the time period studied, while also having the worst trend in AM among these highly-developed nations.  As if that is not alarming enough, prior studies documented that the ratio of Black deaths from twelve specific avoidable causes have hovered at nearly 4.5 to 1 for decades. For the period between 1980 – 2005, Macinko & Elo found that the overall AM ratio between Black and White men varied within a range between 2.3 – 2.7 time to 1, whereas the same ratio with Black and White women oscillated within a range between 2.0 – 2.2 times to 1, which obviously represents a significantly lower average gap as well as a lower range of variation. 
But the question remains—why is any statistically significant gap considered acceptable?
Other studies, which are discussed in your book depict aspects of health-related disparity between Blacks and Whites in terms of quality of life, and show that while Black women tend to outlive their White counterparts, they have significantly shorter active lives, which describes the period of life lived without a substantial impairment due to the onset of mental or physical disability. For men, the picture is bleaker at nearly every step of the way.  Still other studies, which we obviously incorporate into our synthesis for greater impact, reflect the specific demographic and social variables which account for the persistence of these healthcare disparities between Blacks and Whites, such as neighborhood, family composition, and other factors, both environmental and non-environmental in nature.
Last Lingering Vestiges: For those skeptics who say that the slavery discussion bears no relevance on current racial issues, we ask you to open your eyes and reconsider.
Education
During Senator Henry Wilson’s same 1864 address to the 38th Congress that we referenced previously, he stated that the symbols of slavery “disappear from the land they have brutalized, and the school-house will rise to enlighten the darkened intellect of a race imbruted by long years of enforced ignorance.” Here is perhaps the earliest known confession and acknowledgement that Black education, more properly miseducation as Carter G. Woodson wrote, is a direct consequence of the oppressive chattel system that persisted for many years indeed. 
Source: USA Today
Over 100 years later, the 1967 Kerner Commission Report stated, “The bleak record of public education for ghetto children is growing worse. In the critical skills--verbal and reading ability--Negro students are falling further behind whites with each year of school completed.”
Has that improved in the 48 years since?  Sadly, no.  While it barely improved from the Thirteenth Amendment to the Civil Rights era, it has stagnated since. A few additional bulletpoints from the Status and Trends in the Education of Racial and Ethnic Groups from the National Center for Education Statistics’ July 2010 report will provide adequate motivation for our understanding:

In 2007, across all racial/ethnic groups except Blacks and American Indians/Alaska Natives, the majority of children under 18 lived with married parents. About 34 percent of Black children under 18 lived with married parents and 56 percent of Black children lived with a female parent with no spouse present. (Indicator 3) 
The percentages of children who were living in poverty were higher for Blacks (34 percent), American Indians/Alaska Natives (33 percent), Hispanics (27 percent), and Native Hawaiians or Other Pacific Islanders (26 percent), than for children of two or more races (18 percent), Asians (11 percent) and Whites (10 percent). (Indicator 4) 
In 2008, a higher percentage of Asian children (51 percent) had a mother with at least a bachelor’s degree than did White children (36 percent), children of two or more races (31 percent), Black children (17 percent), American Indian/Alaska Native children (16 percent), and Hispanic children (11 percent). (Indicator 5) 
In 2007–08, about 25 percent of secondary mathematics teachers who taught in schools with at least half Black enrollment had neither a certification nor a college major in mathematics, compared to 8 percent of secondary mathematics teachers who taught in schools with at least half White enrollment. (Indicator 9.1) 

Last Lingering Vestiges: For those skeptics who say that the slavery discussion bears no relevance on current racial issues, we ask you to open your eyes and reconsider.  #vestiges2015
Quick Review
Perhaps too much information has already been shared in this project summary.  I want that information to become knowledge, so to that end here is a brief step-by-step answer to the question of, well what happened after the Kerner Commission report and why didn’t things improve?
• Assassinations of 1965 and 1968 replaced the outspoken leader with theunassertive status quo maintainers;
• Immediate aftermath of Vietnam caused the entire nation to re-assess the class dynamic—a new breed of sociologists emerged to study phenomena with no tangible impact, because they failed to integrate their observations with those from other academic disciplines;
• OPEC jarred manufacturing industry, industrial productivity lags, which eventually paves way for financialization;
• Black middle class grows in uncontested & artificially-protected sectors creating a new “Black Elite;”
• Financialization accelerates, prison sentencing norms become more restrictive;
• High quantity of lower quality educational opportunities emerge, widening the Black-White knowledge/attainment gap……….Welcome to the 21st century!!!
Risks & Challenges
One significant concern to the success of your book is that the rapid pace of rising consumerism and media “noise” related to serious matters addressing socio-economic or racial concerns could drown-out or even crowd-out commitment and support for this project.  To combat this risk, my focus is on engaging with many of the other movements—both nascent and well-established—to engender a spirit of collaboration rather than of competition.  A great many books have been written about topics that “sound similar.”  Further, a great number of non-profit organizations or philanthropic missions have been launched for what might appear to be similar purposes.  I want the viewer / reader to understand without any doubt or uncertainty that what the aforementioned projects and publications share in common is the credit due to the creator. 
In other words, authors want to be acknowledged for their intellectual contributions just like donors or philanthropists want acknowledgement for their financial contributions.  I am not seeking fame or status.  I feel compelled to produce this ambitious effort due to the fact that the CUMULATIVE COLLECTIVE IMPACT of the prior initiatives has been negative.  It sounds impossible or perhaps even borderline blasphemous, but based purely on the indicators that thousands of independent studies have produced and that this book will synthesize and integrate, after adjusting for human and financial capital differences, the socio-economic plight of the average American has not improved over the past 50 years, and in specific regard to African-Americans, the socio-economic status has deteriorated at an alarmingly accelerated rate.  More young Black males in jail or prison, for longer terms, beginning at earlier average ages upon incarceration; fewer Blacks attending quality schools—education always a lagged effect—but essentially most students who start off behind find themselves increasingly behind (as seen above); college entrance for all sub-groups is up, but the Black-White gap in attendance and dropout rates has widened; after a longer and lower quality average job search (i.e. having been out of work longer), Blacks find themselves in a wide array of discrimination configurations on-the-job; affirmative action plans / programs, when used at all, have been shown to produce negative effects that outweigh the benefit and challenge the validity of the programs overall.
As Justice Potter Stewart wrote just two months after the assassination of Martin Luther King, the Thirteenth Amendment made a promise the Nation has not kept” (emphasis mine; Justice Potter used ‘cannot keep’ where I have inserted ‘has not kept’ for historical emphasis).
Project Budget
This budget is divided into three phases:

Critical Distribution -- covers pre-production (i.e. research tools, support) and production and distribution costs to ship the final book to influential leaders throughout the United States (see Table 1 below);
Book Production Costs -- outside of the production costs that have already been factored into the phase above, we have a need for additional production costs normally associated with publications, and our plan is to raise these in a separate campaign to run simultaneously (see Table 2);
Secondary Distribution -- beyond the elected officials in the first phase of critical distribution (Table 1), we will apply any overage from this campaign (i.e. stretch goals) to sending the book to other influential decision makers as shown in Table 3 below.  Since production costs will have already been recovered during Phase 1, the per book cost of production and shipping during Phase 3 will be $10.

Other Ways You Can Help

With your help, we're reshaping the face of freedom in the United States.  You can also help our cause tremendously by:

story:
Care 2 Tri is a non-profit corporation 501 (c) (3) of caring individuals with the common goal of helping those with disabilities gain a sense of fulfillment by giving them opportunities that they wouldn’t otherwise have.

Our organization acts as a vessel to include them in the sport of triathlon. In doing so, our goal is to place them in the limelight and give them the respect they deserve as they are the true inspiration and heart of what we do.


Nadia who has cerebral palsy, was the first participant who raced with us when we began 6 years ago. She enjoys being part of the race and the positive attention that it has brought her in the community. 

See a piece on the story of Nadia when she began racing with our team

http://www.yourobserver.com/news/east-county/Front-Page/090220091943/PERFECT-PAIR


In 2013 Care 2 Tri began a program called Together We ARE. We wanted to be able to use what we do to help raise funds for individuals with disabilities who have a need.

Recently, we found out that Nadia's wheelchair van was totalled and her family is in need of a replacement. Its difficult for Nadia to travel without it, as she has to be lifted in and out of a car and can not bring her electric wheelchair with her.

story:
Bridge to Justice is a 501(c)(3) non-profit law firm in Boulder, Colorado providing a variety of civil legal services to economically disadvantaged Coloradans. Many ordinary citizens in Colorado face significant obstacles navigating the legal system as a result of the lack of affordable attorneys in civil and domestic relations matters, creating a significant gap in who can access the resources they need to ensure a fair shake at justice. Bridge to Justice's mission is to bridge this "justice gap” by charging significantly reduced rates to assist those who do not qualify for free legal services but  cannot afford a market-rate attorney in civil matters. Areas of focus for Bridge to Justice include family law, landlord-tenant disputes, will drafting, bankruptcy, and consumer protection.

The Bridge to Justice team is committed to promoting justice in the community at large, not just among those who are financially privileged. With your help, Bridge to Justice can continue to provide life-changing legal assistance to those who are otherwise left to confront their civil matters alone and devoid of the resources and training they need. With your donation, you are helping Bridge to Justice empower individuals and communities throughout Colorado by promoting equal access to justice for all. Help support Bridge to Justice Today.             

MEET THE BRIDGE TO JUSTICE TEAM

                             
                                                
                                  Bruce Wiener, Executive Director and Attorney

Bruce is the Executive Director of Bridge to Justice. He is also an attorney who practices in the areas of family law, landlord-tenant, and consumer debt. Prior to the formation of Bridge to Justice, Bruce practiced labor and employment law and general civil litigation at a corporate law firm in New York City. After relocating to Boulder in 2009, Bruce volunteered for Boulder County Legal Services and worked as a staff attorney for the Boulder Law Shop representing modest means clients in family law and landlord-tenant matters.

In addition to his work at Bridge to Justice, Bruce is a contract attorney for Boulder County Legal Services taking dissolution of marriage, allocation of parental responsibilities, and civil protection order cases and is a court-appointed attorney representing the mentally ill in civil commitment hearings.

Recognized on several occasions by the Boulder County Bar Association, he received the Boulder County Bar Association Young Lawyer of the Year Award in 2012.

Education:

Fordham University School of Law, J.D., 2008
Cornell University, B.S., Industrial & Labor Relations, 2005, cum laude

Awards:

Boulder County Bar Association Young Lawyer of the Year, 2012
Colorado Supreme Court Pro Bono Legal Service Commitment and Recognition Program, 2013-2015


                                               

Samantha Bainbridge, Staff Attorney

Samantha Bainbridge is the newest addition to Bridge to Justice. Samantha knew a legal career was in her future after volunteering with Community Legal Aid (CLA) in Worcester, Massachusetts while in college and witnessing the enormous impact that attorneys have on resolving problems that seem insurmountable without legal help. She returned to legal aid as an AmeriCorps Fellow, assisting indigent individuals with government benefit and landlord-tenant issues. While in law school pursuing a career in public interest law, Samantha interned with the Colorado Legal Services Family and Children Unit, the 18th Judicial District, Denver Urban Ministries Pro Bono Legal Clinic, and the Department of Education Office for Civil Rights. She observed the frustration of individuals trying to navigate complicated areas of law without qualified advice and the drastic difference that dedicated attorneys can make in achieving positive outcomes and peace of mind.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN CONTRIBUTE TO THIS CAUSE

For those who cannot make a monetary contribution to Bridge to Justice but still wish to support its mission of providing equal access to justice for low-to-moderate income Coloradans, there are plenty of ways to contribute. Here are just a few ideas of ways you can help!

Volunteer: Organizations providing legal assistance to modest income clients are often looking for volunteers to help them with a variety of tasks, including translating, organizing files and resources, and engaging with clients. Having this help available enables these organizations to expand their client base and continue to reach out to more community members in need of affordable legal services.

Spread the Word: In order for Bridge to Justice to help as many people as possible, communities throughout Colorado first must know that Bridge to Justice is available. Those who feel it is their only option to navigate the justice system alone deserve to know that our doors are open to them, and we cannot spread this message to every modest-income Colorado household without your help!

Start the Conversation in Your Community: One reason why the justice gap has been able to grow to such startling proportions is because this phenomenon often goes overlooked amongst lay community members and legal practitioners alike. It is up to us and those who support our mission to continue to act as catalysts for change. We must engage one another in this conversation and reach out to others as well. Through these efforts, we can create networks of support with collective voices that speak louder that of any individual.
story_txt:
Bridge to Justice is a 501(c)(3) non-profit law firm in Boulder, Colorado providing a variety of civil legal services to economically disadvantaged Coloradans. Many ordinary citizens in Colorado face significant obstacles navigating the legal system as a result of the lack of affordable attorneys in civil and domestic relations matters, creating a significant gap in who can access the resources they need to ensure a fair shake at justice. Bridge to Justice's mission is to bridge this "justice gap” by charging significantly reduced rates to assist those who do not qualify for free legal services but  cannot afford a market-rate attorney in civil matters. Areas of focus for Bridge to Justice include family law, landlord-tenant disputes, will drafting, bankruptcy, and consumer protection. The Bridge to Justice team is committed to promoting justice in the community at large, not just among those who are financially privileged. With your help, Bridge to Justice can continue to provide life-changing legal assistance to those who are otherwise left to confront their civil matters alone and devoid of the resources and training they need. With your donation, you are helping Bridge to Justice empower individuals and communities throughout Colorado by promoting equal access to justice for all. Help support Bridge to Justice Today.

story:
MAKE AMERICA INCLUSIVE AGAIN

Why This? Why Now?

Nearly 1 in 10 working-age U.S. adults is considered Limited in English Proficiency (LEP). Among them, only 15% hold a college degree. Add in refugees and undocumented immigrants, and a large population arises—one vulnerable to disenfranchisement from poor communication.

We strongly believe that by helping non-English speaking communities gain better access to social services and opportunities, we can help them break out of the perpetual poverty cycle. We are already active in helping these groups face the following challenges:

  • Understanding and reacting to legal and financial matters
  • Making informed medical decisions
  • Communicating with bosses, co-workers, HR staff and others tied to employability
  • Corresponding with local, state, and government agencies—remaining in compliance and taking advantage of services
  • Conferencing with teachers, caregivers, and administrators responsible for children and elders
  • Being heard in public forums, in the media, and as part of cultural and civic debate

Our Track Record of Results

Since our inception in early 2016, we have built a team of more than one hundred language assistants. We offer services in Spanish, Cantonese, Mandarin, Vietnamese, and Arabic and provide document translation, phone hotline, or in-person assistance. Recent projects include:

  • Working with LGBTI refugees to help with resettlement
  • Helping homeless people with limited English proficiency access social services
  • Assisting non-English-speaking parents in communicating with teachers and administrators around the health and well-being of their children both in and out of the classroom
  • Providing free language support to responders to hurricane-stricken areas
  • Helping shelter workers communicate with victims of the earthquakes in Mexico

In addition to serving individuals, we have served the following organizations:

How This Campaign Will Help Us Do More

Community need for our services exceeds our current capacity, particularly as it relates to emergency response. In order to scale efficiently and meet demand, we need your help. To date, we have funded our services through operating revenue and grants, including a $30,000 grant from the Westly Foundation that we received as a 2016 winner of the Westly Prize. Your support of this campaign will help us:

  • Recruit and train additional language assistants with linguistic and cultural proficiency
  • Support additional languages such as Haitian Creole, Mam, Tagalog, and others with thin representation

Our Team

Ladon Language was created in the Spring of 2016 by students at the University of California at Berkeley. Shared values around social and political activism, as well as shared exposure to the struggles of immigrant families, galvanized an early collective to take action.

Anh-Thu Ho – Co-Founder

Anh-Thu is the Grand Prize Winner of the West Prize for Young Social Innovator in California, a Fellow with The Resolution Project, and was named an Exemplary Commitment Maker by the Clinton Global Initiative. She is currently pursuing a Master’s Degree in Vietnam.

Melvyn Sng – Co-Founder

Melvin led the Ladon team to win the Social Entrepreneurship Challenge Lab for the UC Berkeley team and is currently pursuing an MSc in Technology Management at Nanyang Technological University, the #1 university in Asia.

 

Mariana Olivo

Mariana is a sophomore at UC Berkeley, a first-generation college student, and an overcomer of all odds. Since arriving at Berkeley, she has been vital to the success of Ladon and is driven to continue ongoing work with underserved communities​

Risks and Challenges

Given our track record of success in bringing programs to the communities we serve, we believe that there are few risks related to funding our project. We have already done the hard work of launching an organization and operating for upwards of a year. This campaign is about supporting our growth and positioning us to serve more members of our target communities. We believe that the following factors enhance our credibility:

  • Strong Leadership. Founder Anh-Thu is a graduate of UC Berkeley, and the leader of Ladon Language. After leading the team to win First Prize in their class at Berkeley for the project concept, she went to Washington, D.C., to present the initiative to key personnel at American Red Cross headquarters. Over the past eighteen months, she has led the initiative from a prototype concept to a fully-actualized, fully operational organization. To date, Ladon has served around 200 individual clients and 15 non-profits.
  • A Strong Team. Our team members are not just employees—many of them are students or former students at UC Berkeley, who remain involved because of their experiences as immigrants, their belief in our mission, and their desire to support communities with limited English proficiency.
  • Support From Other Major Organizations. Ladon is a social initiative supported by The Clinton Global Initiative University, The Resolution Project, and The Westly Foundation.
  • Status as a Public Benefit Corporation. Ladon Language is not a traditional for-profit translation service—we are a Public Benefit Corporation. This means that we have pledged to serve a socially-important charter purpose in addition to serving traditional corporate goals.

Check Us Out Online

For more information, please visit the Gallery or our Website www.ladonlanguage.com or contact us at team@ladon.us 

https://www.facebook.com/ladon.team

https://twitter.com/TeamLadon

https://www.linkedin.com/company/13249098/

story:
2018 SFA Encuentro 

The Student/Farmworker Alliance (SFA) is a national network of students and young people organizing with the Coalition of Immokalee Workers (CIW) to eliminate sweatshop conditions in the fields and build a food system based on justice and dignity for farmworkers. The CIW’s model of worker-driven responsibility has given hope to many in an era of countless attacks on labor rights. 

Since 2000, SFA has stood shoulder-to-shoulder with farmworkers who are leading – and winning – their own struggle for systemic change in the U.S. agricultural industry. This September, we're continuing the decade-long Encuentro tradition by bringing together brilliant SFAers – past, present, and future – to lay down some solid groundwork for the upcoming year! 

     

Here's an inside scoop of what will be going down at this year's gathering:

  • Celebrating and learning from the CIW’s incredible 25-year history of fighting for dignity and respect in the fields;
  • Crafting back-to-school escalation plans in the Wendy’s boycott and the Boot the Braids campaign;
  • Building strength and solidarity across grassroots movements for justice;
  • Sustaining the future of SFA's organizing through skill-building workshops and tools for leadership development;
  • Taking action together to inspire us to make change in our home communities, and ;

  • Building strength and solidarity across national grassroots movements

Why We Need Your Support

Hurricane Irma disrupted our ability to meet in Immokalee last year. That’s why this year, we are dedicated to making this Encuentro more powerful, accessible, and joyous than ever! But we need your help to make that happen. 

Students and young people from every corner of the Fair Food Nation are headed to Immokalee for a weekend of creativity, strategizing, skill-building and reflection in solidarity with farmworkers. SFA dedicates itself to providing this opportunity to anyone who desires to become part of our vibrant and diverse network. That's why we're raising funds for travel scholarships to make this gathering as accessible as possible. 

Your donation will go a long way in supporting the students and youth traveling thousands of miles to be part of the #2018Encuentro. Financial support for this gathering is being drawn from a variety of fundraising efforts. For example, all participants are encouraged to get creative in raising the funds necessary for their own journeys to the Encuentro. 

So, chip in a little – or a lot! – to make this year’s Encuentro spectacular!

(And don't forget to check out some of the amazing perks available to donors!)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially but would still like to support student and youth participation in the Campaign for Fair Food, you can:

  • Share this fundraising opportunity with your friends, family and community networks
  • Get the word out on social media (use #boycottwendys and @sfalliance)
  • Become an SFA sustainer to support student organizing year round
  • Visit the SFA website to find out how you can stay involved locally

If you've got ideas or questions you'd like to share, just drop us a line at organize@sfalliance.org or give us a ring at 239-657-8311.

story:
https://safespaceapp.com/

 

OUR STORY

My name is Mondo but everyone refers to me as ‘The Black Tech Guy’

When stopped by cops I've always pulled over in a well lit area with people nearby, hoping someone stops to watch. But with the fear between police and communities of color growing, I couldn’t continue to sit back and rely on chance, especially after the death of Philando Castile.  As a St. Paul local and former High School classmate of Philando, reality hit too close to home, to do nothing.

For years I had a vague vision for SafeSpace, but the technical genius to build it was well beyond my know-how.  Fortunately, about a year ago (April 28, 2017) a tweet connected me with some amazing people at Software for Good. The stars must have been aligned because within a few weeks we were partnering on this project.

Now that the app is built, it's up to communities fighting against police brutality to band together. We must become selfless ALLIES in a united mission to SAVE LIVES.

 

MILLION DOLLAR MISSION

This campaign is phase one of a new movement that leverages technology to maximize the voice of the PEOPLE.    

We support all other past, present, and future movements FIGHTING for JUSTICE because there is no one-way to solve this problem.

Contributing to SafeSpace will support 3 main goals:

1) Development of SafeSpace for Android users. 

2) Add more safety features to the app, like streaming audio to your emergency contacts while engaging with the police.

3) Supporting a strategic rollout into communities outside of St. Paul/Minneapolis. 

 

STRATEGY 

Exploiting every misstep a cop makes with an intent to PUNISH officers is NOT our goal.  In too many cases our justice system has not generated equitable outcomes despite overwhelming evidence.

Instead, we believe our role is identifying smaller nuances in the behavior of cops over an extended period of time.  Building robust profiles of every cop serving our communities.

Imagine your community in 3 years after residents have reported 100,000+ POSITIVE and/or NEGATIVE ratings with detailed feedback about their experience with the police.  True colors of individual officers and departments will shine bright.

This data will position us and other organizations around the country to focus on PREVENTATIVE actions. Communities can advocate for individualized professional development and remove UNFIT officers before their behavior leads to an unfixable outcome.

In addition, we'll have consistent community feedback identifying exceptional officers who continuously showcase their GREATNESS in the field.

Imagine right before engaging with an officer, SafeSpace informs you that Sergeant Anderson has been UPVOTED 750 times by the community, with ZERO negative ratings.

Thats the type of future we are building towards.  

Special Shoutout

We want to extend a special shoutout to the amazing team at Youth Lens 360 for your exceptional video production and story telling capabilities.  In addition to your mission; empowering youth through passion and entrepreneurship.

story:
All contributions will be deposited into the account of our Cooperative with Piraeus Bank in Athens for the specific purpose of the Campaign.

Όλες οι συνεισφορές κατατίθενται μόνο σε λογαριασμό της Κοινωνικής Επιχείρησης στην τράπεζα Πειραιώς για τον συγκεκριμένο σκοπό.

Our Hellenism and Democracy Academy  headquarters will be located in a building owned by the editor at  82 Lenorman street in Athens with view to Akropolis and a stone's throw away from the original Plato's Academy.  Photo of the building below:

Related is the page in the Facebook https://www.facebook.com/agonistes.dimokratias/

The building includes space for studies and a reception hall where conferences will be held. Scholars willing to deepen their philosophical approach to Hellenism and Democracy political science will be most wellcome.

Conferences will also be held at an open air amphitheatre in Thrakomakedones 27 km away at 510 m altitude.

We are a Cooperative of engineers, a BUISNESS OF COLLECTIVE AND SOCIAL BENEFIT

Our name: HELLENIC ENGINEERS COOPERATIVE with SOCIAL REGISTER'S NUMBER 000013003011 and VAT No EL997026524, office address: 82 Lenorman str, Athens, GR10444, T. +30 2105127764, mob: +30 6970360025, email hellengtee.coop@gmail.com and our site:

https://hellenicengineerscooptee.blogspot.gr

Our members are:

Dr Engr George Vamvakousis, Mechanical/Electrical Engineer, president of the steering commitee

Engr C. Kokkinos, Civil Engineer, secretary of the steering commitee

Engr Architect Stavros Vidalis

Engr Dimosthenis Agoros, Civil Engineer, cashier of the steering commitee

Engr Zacharias Giachos, Civil Engineer, member

Chemist Nikos Vamvakousis, Chemist of University degree, member

All six of the above are aware of the high social impact of our profession and of their responsibilities to work for the improvement of the life standards for all citizens.

We have already agreements with political scientists who are offering their services for education conferences about Democracy and its real meaning.

- Comparison with what politicians usually understand about Democracy, which is rather a Parlementary oligarchy born in the medieval Kingdom of Britain and not in Greece.

- The nature of choosing deputees by vote based on promises they usually do not keep.

- Comparison with the way it was done in ancient Athens securing that the chances of election to authority positions were equal for the rich as well as for the poor.

The main aims of the Academy's political science research and related conferences are:

A) Democracy as a condition for securing the National Independence

B) Democracy and Public Interest.

C) Democracy as a guarantee for safequarding the public interest and the human rights

D) Hellenism, Philosophy and Democracy, what are the ties ?

E) Religions and Democracy

F) Re-establishment of Democracy today

Your suggestions and support would be most welcome

Greek text follows:

Η πρόταση μας είναι για να στηθεί ένα ίδρυμα έρευνας και επιμόρφωσης πάνω σε θέματα πολιτικής επιστήμης και ειδικότερα στο μέγιστο θέμα της Δημοκρατίας. Θέμα ζωής ή θανάτου για τον Ελληνισμό πλέον.

Δεν υπάρχει καμιά πρόθεση των οργανωτών της καμπάνιας και μελών της Ακαδημίας για σχηματισμό ή υποβοήθηση σχηματισμού πολιτικής παράταξης ή κόμματος, ιδιαίτερα κάτω από τις σημερινές συνθήκες.

Ένας από τους πρωταρχικούς μας στόχους είναι να προστατεύσουμε αλλά και να αποκαταστήσουμε τις έννοιες που αφορούν την Κοινωνία και οι οποίες υφίστανται επίθεση από κύκλους που αντιμάχονται την Δημοκρατία και την Ελληνική γλώσσα, ύψιστο εργαλείο της ελληνικής φιλοσοφίας και διανόησης.

Η Ακαδημία Ελληνισμού και Δημοκρατίας θα φιλοξενηθεί σε χώρο που διαθέτει αφιλοκερδώς το μέλος μας Γεώργιος Βαμβακούσης στην Λένορμαν 82 στον Κολωνό και κοντά στην Ακαδημία Πλάτωνος.

Διάφορα σχετικά κόστη όπως και η διαμόρφωση υπαίθριου αμφιθέατρου στους Θρακομακεδόνες θα γίνει με την βοήθεια του crowdfunding .

Σχετική η σελίδα μας στο Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/agonistes.dimokratias/

Διαλέξεις και εκπαιδευτικές εκδηλώσεις σχετικές με την Δημοκρατία και τις δυνατότητες επανίδρυσης της θα μπορούν να γίνονται και σε αμφιθέατρο στον χώρο δασικού περιβάλλοντος εντός κατάλληλα διαμορφωμένου οικοπέδου στους Θρακομακεδόνες στην οδό Ηαμθιας 3. Χρήση που παραχωρεί αφιλοκερδώς το μέλος μας Δρ Γεώργιος Βαμβακούσης

Η Ακαδημία παράλληλα με την διδασκαλία και επιστημονική πολιτική έρευνα σε θέματα Δημοκρατίας δηλαδή θεσμοθέτησης της Κοινωνίας, έχει στους σκοπούς της ακριβώς την φροντίδα ενίσχυσης της Κοινωνίας ώστε να απαλλαγεί των συνεπειών της υποταγής της σήμερα στις ολιγαρχικές δυνάμεις. Έτσι με ε βάση χορηγίες από υγειείς παραγωγικούς φορείς φροντίζει για την ενίσχυση Κοινωνικών δράσεων και πρωτοβουλιών τρίτων όπως:

Το Κοινωνικό Ιατρείο Ελληνικού http://www.mkiellinikou.org/,

Τα χωριά SOS http://www.sos-villages.gr/,

Το Χαμόγελο του Παιδιού https://www.hamogelo.gr/,

Την Κιβωτός του Κόσμου http://www.kivotostoukosmou.org/el/ .

Στον ιστότοπο μας ως παρακάτω σύνδεσμος γίνεται μια παρουσίαση της μη κερδοσκοπικής επιχείρησης μας: https://hellenicengineerscooptee.blogspot.gr/     Είναι η Κοιν.Σ.Επ. Σύμπραξη Μηχανικών ΤΕΕ όλων των ειδικοτήτων που ανέλαβε την διεκπεραίωση των απαραίτητων για τον σκοπό έργων. Τα μέλη μας με σειρά ηλικίας:

Γεώργιος Βαμβακούσης, Δρ Μηχανολόγος-Ηλεκτρολόγος Μηχανικός, Πρόεδρος ΔΕ

Χρυσόστομος Κόκκινος, Πολιτικός Μηχανικός, Δομοστατικός, Γραμματέας ΔΕ

Σταύρος Βιδάλης, Αρχιτέκτονας Μηχανικός, Μέλος

Νικόλαος Βαμβακούσης, Χημικός Παν/μίου Αθηνών, Μέλος

Δημοσθένης Αγόρος, Πολιτικός Μηχανικός, Ταμίας ΔΕ

Ζαχαρίας Γιάχος, Πολιτικός Μηχανικός, Μέλος

Συνεργάζονται και άλλοι επιστήμονες ειδικοτήτων που έχουν κοινωνικό πρόσημο.

Με το ποσό που θα συλλεχτεί με το crowdfunding θα εκτελεστούν οι παρακάτω εργασίες:

Μελέτη αρχιτεκτονική/κατασκευαστική και άδεια οικοδομής τα οποία έχει ήδη αναλάβει το μέλος μας αρχιτέκτονας

Διαμόρφωση του χώρου στην πρασιά και κερκίδων υπαίθριου αμφιθέατρου για τις εκδηλώσεις/διαλέξεις της Ακαδημίας Δημοκρατίας

Περίφραξη με καλαίσθητη πρόσοψη ως εδώ αρχιτεκτονικές 3διάστατες απεικονίσεις

Χάραξη και Κατασκευή μονοπατιών στον υπόλοιπο χώρο δασικής βλάστησης του οικοπέδου.

Χάραξη και ετοιμασία βοτανόκηπου για φυτά/θάμνους που απαντώνται στον περιβάλλοντα δασικό χώρο της Πάρνηθας με σκοπό την εκπαίδευση ιδιαίτερα των παιδιών αλλά και των μελών και επισκεπτών μας. Θεωρώντας ότι μια Κοινωνία ενημερωμένη πάνω στο φυσικό περιβάλλον και γνωρίζοντας τους θησαυρούς του είναι ισχυρότερη. Έτσι, και ευκολότερα δυνάμενη να αναλάβει την εξουσία ώστε η Δημοκρατία να κατισχύσει.

Οργάνωση γραμματείας και χώρου διαλέξεων στην έδρα της Ακαδημίας στον Κολωνό

Πρώτα έξοδα οργάνωσης για την πρόσκληση ειδικών εισηγητών πολτικής επιστήμης

Προυπολογισμός για τα παραπάνω έργα: 58.000 ευρώ ή 70.000 $ περίπου.

Ξεκινήσαμε την σχετική καμπάνια με την εταιρία crowdfunding INDIEGOGO και σας καλούμε να μας επισκεφτείτε στον ιστότοπο της καμπάνιας https://igg.me/at/Ephialtes

 

Στον ιστότοπο μας ως παρακάτω σύνδεσμος γίνεται μια παρουσίαση της μη κερδοσκοπικής επιχείρησης μας: https://hellenicengineerscooptee.blogspot.gr/
story_txt: All contributions will be deposited into the account of our Cooperative with Piraeus Bank in Athens for the specific purpose of the Campaign.Όλες οι συνεισφορές κατατίθενται μόνο σε λογαριασμό της Κοινωνικής Επιχείρησης στην τράπεζα Πειραιώς για τον συγκεκριμένο σκοπό.Our Hellenism and Democracy Academy  headquarters will be located in a building owned by the editor at  82 Lenorman street in Athens with view to Akropolis and a stone's throw away from the original Plato's Academy.  Photo of the building below:Related is the page in the Facebook https://www.facebook.com/agonistes.dimokratias/The building includes space for studies and a reception hall where conferences will be held. Scholars willing to deepen their philosophical approach to Hellenism and Democracy political science will be most wellcome.Conferences will also be held at an open air amphitheatre in Thrakomakedones 27 km away at 510 m altitude.We are a Cooperative of engineers, a BUISNESS OF COLLECTIVE AND SOCIAL BENEFITOur name: HELLENIC ENGINEERS COOPERATIVE with SOCIAL REGISTER'S NUMBER 000013003011 and VAT No EL997026524, office address: 82 Lenorman str, Athens, GR10444, T. +30 2105127764, mob: +30 6970360025, email hellengtee.coop@gmail.com and our site:https://hellenicengineerscooptee.blogspot.grOur members are:Dr Engr George Vamvakousis, Mechanical/Electrical Engineer, president of the steering commiteeEngr C. Kokkinos, Civil Engineer, secretary of the steering commiteeEngr Architect Stavros VidalisEngr Dimosthenis Agoros, Civil Engineer, cashier of the steering commiteeEngr Zacharias Giachos, Civil Engineer, memberChemist Nikos Vamvakousis, Chemist of University degree, memberAll six of the above are aware of the high social impact of our profession and of their responsibilities to work for the improvement of the life standards for all citizens.We have already agreements with political scientists who are offering their services for education conferences about Democracy and its real meaning.- Comparison with what politicians usually understand about Democracy, which is rather a Parlementary oligarchy born in the medieval Kingdom of Britain and not in Greece.- The nature of choosing deputees by vote based on promises they usually do not keep.- Comparison with the way it was done in ancient Athens securing that the chances of election to authority positions were equal for the rich as well as for the poor.The main aims of the Academy's political science research and related conferences are:A) Democracy as a condition for securing the National IndependenceB) Democracy and Public Interest.C) Democracy as a guarantee for safequarding the public interest and the human rightsD) Hellenism, Philosophy and Democracy, what are the ties ?E) Religions and DemocracyF) Re-establishment of Democracy todayYour suggestions and support would be most welcomeGreek text follows:Η πρόταση μας είναι για να στηθεί ένα ίδρυμα έρευνας και επιμόρφωσης πάνω σε θέματα πολιτικής επιστήμης και ειδικότερα στο μέγιστο θέμα της Δημοκρατίας. story:
Brooklyn Bowl Staff Needs Help 

Hi! The staff of Brooklyn Bowl need your help. 

On Friday, March 13th, Brooklyn Bowl announced that they would close their doors until further notice in an effort to help prevent the spread of COVID-19. We understand and fully respect the extremely difficult decision that NYC and Brooklyn Bowl have made - but we now need your help.  This global health crisis has left us, the staff of Brooklyn Bowl, suddenly without any source of income. 

We, your friendly bartenders, security, bussers, etc., collectively make sure you and all your favorite bands have the best night, every night. This is what we love to do and what we have done as a team for the past 10 years! We are a team, we are friends, and we are family. Covid-19 has left our community without live music, and without that we are left without the tips we depend on. 

Our Brooklyn Bowl family is looking for your help!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need as much funds as possible to equally distribute amongst all the staff of Brooklyn Bowl. You may not be aware of this but Brooklyn Bowl has a very large staff of workers which is how our home away from home is able to run so smoothly.

These workers include:

  • Bartenders
  • Security
  • Servers
  • Food/Drink Runners
  • Shoe Desk
  • Bussers
  • Concierge
  • Hosts
  • Production
  • BOH staff

Contributions will come with certain perks which you can check out for yourself below.

Your Impact

Your impact will be massive. 

We are all desperately trying to make things work with what we have but considering the amount of time we had to plan ahead ( no time ) it's been difficult for all of us of keep up with our bills,  let alone figure out a new creative way to make ends meet.   

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that this is a hard time for everyone. 

If you cannot contribute please consider sharing this campaign to others and posting it on your various social media platforms - sharing is caring!

story:
What do Dan Akroyd, Albert Einstein, Henry Ford, and Simone Biles have in common? They are all neurodistinct! 

Link OT’s mission is to link neurodistinct talents to job opportunities. The problem is that the vast majority of people (and employers) do not accept and APPRECIATE what it means to think differently. This lack of understanding results in homogenous thinking and cultural norms, which stifles new ideas and ways of thinking. Bigotry, anti-intellectualism, and marginalization are just a few of the inherent risks when diverse thinking isn’t embraced.

Neurodiverse conditions include Autism, ADHD, Dyslexia, Dyspraxia, and more. Further, 17% of the US population can be considered neurodistinct. Yet, this segment of our population encounters unemployment rates as high as 80%! On the flip side, many companies, such as Microsoft and HP, have uncovered the unique value of integrating diverse thinking into their workforce. Research also indicates that hiring neurodistict talent results in greater productivity, creativity, innovation, and work engagement in comparison to peers. So, where is the breakdown happening and what do we do about it?? This is where the Link team comes in! 

I started Link OT with the mission to change the narrative, break down barriers, reduce the stigma, and change perspectives about diverse thinking in the workplace. We help our clients FIND & KEEP JOBS while also assisting employers in development of NEURO-INCLUSIVE hiring, onboarding, integration, and retention practices.

Your contribution to this campaign will mean so much to us as we pursue our mission. We truly appreciate your support, even if that means just forwarding this message on to your friends and family.

At your service,

Liz and the Link team

 

Your contributions will be used for:

Client Scholarships: $5000

Company Sponsorships: $5000

Product Development (On-demand virtal learning platform): $1000

Telehealth & Therapy Equipment and Testing Tools: $1000

Recruitment and Hiring of Key Personnel (Occupational and speech therapists): $2500

Press/Media: $500

Marketing/Business Development: $5000

Operations Management: $7000

Legal & Accounting: $3000

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, we would LOVE your help spreading the word! Here are a few ways you can do that:

  • Forward our campaign onto your friends on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram and unlock some cool rewards just for referring!

  • Don't forget to use share tools to help spread the message!

 

***Details about our perk: Exclusive Custom Rap by Flobots

Jonny 5 from Flobots will write and record an original verse for a recipient of your choosing, based on your specifications! Think of it as a modern day singing telegram, customized to your lucky loved one. For this package, you will be given the opportunity to provide any insights, information, and inside jokes you'd like included, and Jonny 5 will then weave them into a 1-2 minute verse that he'll deliver over acoustic guitar provided by Flobots' guitarist Andy Guerrero. They'll capture the piece in a video you can send to the lucky recipient.
