story:
Help for Syrian Child Refugees in Lesvos

There has been an increase in Syrian's leaving their home due to the Russian air strikes. They are arriving cold, wet and hungry.  Most of the world's media and governments are turning a blind eye to this humanitarian crisis. But together we can make a difference to a child's life.

This situation is getting worse  and with winter fast approaching help is urgently needed now.

There are no big charities in Lesvos - it's mainly volunteers.

Children are living in dismal conditions, without adequate food, clothes and shelter.They urgently need children's winter clothes and shoes.

What We Need & How You Can Help

If you are in a position, please donate what you can.  Any amount is greatly appreciated.

100% of the money raised will go directly to purchasing items for children which are urgently needed.

Through the money you donate, I will send boxes filled with the following items: 

  • Jogging / tracksuits
  • Water proof jackets and trousers
  • Underwear
  • gloves, hats and scarves
  • shoes / Willies / Gumboots
  • Warm jackets like skyi jackets

The Impact

 All money raised goes directly to those that need it - children. 
Please donate what you can.
Any amount is greatly appreciated and will make a huge difference to a child's life. 
Thank you

story:
As some of you may know I have been working for a non-profit project called Days For Girls for the last few years.  What we do is sew and put together re-usable menstruation kits for girls in need around the world.  These kits enable girls to live a normal life all month long and, more importantly, not miss school and/or work due to having their period.  

Last year my family and I made our first kit delivery at the Delhi Council for Child Welfare in India and it was a huge success.  We saw first-hand how much these kits help girls and how terrible it is to lack something as fundamental and essential as feminine hygiene products

After another year of working hard to sew up the kits (which will last the girls at least 3 years) we are ready to make another delivery.  This year I will be traveling with my fellow Days For Girls team member and good friend Mirjam and my enthusiastic mother who will be meeting us in Delhi all the way from Nova Scotia.  We'll also be meeting up with our good friend and local expert Kanchan Singh when we arrive in Delhi (we're so lucky she is involved!). We are all really excited to visit several schools in the mountains of Uttapradesh where they are eagerly awaiting the kits.

We’d really love to make the most of our trip by helping as many women/girls as we can while we’re there.  Therefore, we have decided to try and raise funds to buy a supply of Silicone Menstrual Cups to distribute to women in the local community (the Days For Girls kits are distributed to young girls).  These cups are great because they produce no waste and are very reliable and easy to use. They will help improve the lives of many women who usually have no access to sanitary products. The cups cost approximately $10 each and last for many years.

Please note, we pay for our own travel and expenses so all money donated is used directly for the purchase of supplies for the girls and women of these communities.

If you’d like to donate to the purchase of the silicone cups we’d be so grateful and make sure every cent is spent on improving the lives of as many girls and women as we can.  

Thank you thank you thank you!

Jillian, Margaret and Mirjam

story:
Summary

Voices Of The Street is a documentary series of interviews with New York City's homeless, created to give the homeless a platform to speak – not just to tell their story and say anything they like, but to talk specifically about what they think the city lacks to provide for them, and what’s keeping them on the street.

We need to capture and document the Homeless themselves, speaking about the model used to take someone from living on the streets into permanent housing, and expose to the people of the city and city council what's not working, what's keeping people there, and propose a solution - a real solution which is already in place or in the ten-year plans of over 300 cities in the world.

We know that hearing this directly from the homeless themselves is the most effective and compelling way for the government to listen, and therefore the best chance we have to start to bring about real change in the model implemented and ultimately the lives of the people living on our streets.

Each interview is made with both a journalism and documentary filmmaking approach – fact finding and story telling together.

 

Why?

There are some distinct broken parts to the model New York city has in place, for taking a person living on the streets to gaining permanent housing.

Its time to expose and address these truths head on.

 

What IS the solution?

When we ask people what they want, the answer is remarkably simple: Housing. Contrary to much of the rhetoric we hear, people who are living on the streets do want to come indoors, however, they usually don't feel safe or comfortable in shelters where they have likely faced violence and theft.

Models that have been successful across other cities, such as "Housing First," have moved people directly from the streets into housing first, rather forcing them to go into shelters and transitional housing. 

This approach is guided by the belief that people need basic necessities first like food and a place to live before attending to anything less critical, such as getting a job, or attending to substance abuse issues. 

This is a complete REVERSE of the current model. In the current New York model, being granted permanent housing is the "final" step in the process. Many people never make it that far for various reasons either due to their own circumstances or obstacles the model presents (which are especially hard to accomplish when living on the streets). Aside, most still aren't granted housing even if they do make it through the process.

This is why in New York it's so hard to get off the streets.

 

The Housing First model has proved a success many times over. Here's at look at how the Housing First model is successfully performing in other cities around the world:

In DC: https://www.pathwaystohousingdc.org/about-us

In Utah: http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2015/02/hou...

In Canada: https://www.canada.ca/en/employment-social-deve...

In Europe: http://housingfirsteurope.eu/guide/what-is-hous...

 

How will the interviews be used?

The plan in place involves reaching influential journalists, elected officials, and city workers through a combination of earned and social media and policy conferences. The campaign will address the broken elements of the current system and highlight a solution proposed by people on the street. Our videos will be the most crucial aspect of the campaign.

This proposal will be the first homeless policy proposal shared with the homeless themselves doing the talking.

The interviews will be the property of Voices Of The Street, copyright to JazzElm Films, and will still remain part of the regular Voices Of The Street documentary series, on the VOTS website.

 

Why do we need funding at all?

Voices Of The Street until now has been an entirely self-funded project by creator/director Matt Baker. Other than a Patreon page currently serving us with $80 a month, we have no private, government or corporate sponsorship.

This is a documentary film project. Running a team, crew, producing the interviews, which in themselves are individual short films, comes with huge cost.

Simply said, Voices Of The Street won’t be able to follow through with this opportunity we have, unless we get strong funding support from the community.

 

What are some of the expenses?

•     Paying the interview subjects 

•     Film crew, assistants, a producer, editors

•     Video/Editing software, plus camera, video and audio supplies

•     Project management costs: websites, subscriptions 

•     Music licensing, promotion and advertising on social media.

 

Why don’t any funds go towards food, clothing or shelter for the homeless?

The purpose of this project is not to support anyone homeless directly or individually, but to create a platform for New York's homeless as a community to be heard, and to document what New York is lacking to provide through the model it has in place, that’s keeping people on the streets.

There are plenty of avenues already available for people to donate to, which provide resources the homeless need day to day.

 

Why do we think we have a real chance at this?

We think the closest thing to getting the mayor and government officials onto the streets, seeing the conditions, and talking to homeless people, is to have the homeless come to them.

This is what’s needed here – for the city council to hear from the homeless themselves. There is a great disconnect between how the city believe the model is working, and the realities of how the model works, in practice, in the life of a homeless person.

Why are there still 60,000 people still living on the streets? If the model worked, wouldn't most of them be off and into housing, or at some point along that journey?

The city is aware there are this many homeless on its streets, so why doesn't it do anything about it? Many reasons, but one major reason is this:

Because of the true nature of conditions of a lot of the shelters and other services the city provides, and the lack of awareness of this by the city, for the most part homeless people are safer and more comfortable sleeping on the street, so the government often deems them as “service resistant”, or essentially “If they choose to stay on the street, that’s their choice”.

This is why its vital through this project and campaign, that we expose to the city what conditions are really like of some of the services it provides, and how the steps a homeless person has to take to get off the streets are near impossible, when deprived of their essential needs like food and a roof over their head.

There couldn’t be a more compelling way to expose this than with our approach - video interviews with the homeless, aimed at directly addressing the problems in the system, targeted at the Mayor and government, and outlining a proven workable solution.

 

 

Who is the team at the moment?

Matt Baker: Creator, Director of Photography, editor, content/project manager.  

Molly Bareiss: Editor 

Ben Cassara: Assistant and Audio.  

Katie Barbaree: Assistant and Audio.

Hakook team: Josh Dean, Isaac Marshall

Website: Voicesofthestreet.com 

Facebook: VoicesOfTheStreetNYC 
 

 

VoicesOfTheStreet.com

#ItsTimeWeListened

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing this link helps of course, on Facebook, email and other social media! Tell your friends too!
